https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Old Rag Mountain Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Old Rag Mountain Loop is a 9.5 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Etlan, Virginia that features a river and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from May until October.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This hike, although challenging, is one of the most popular hikes in Shenandoah National Park. It has been referred to as a “brutally awesome” hike by many. Your climb to the peak includes many rocky switchbacks, so you will not be going straight up, but the trails are still at a steep grade. The descent, which will be slightly longer than your ascent, is a much more gradual grade that ends on a fire trail.

To start, this hike begins with a one-mile walk up the road to the original Old Rag parking area. Turn left onto the Ridge Trail and begin your approximate two mile ascent along switchbacks before reaching the boulder scramble section. There are handwritten numbers below the blue trail blazes throughout the trail. You’ll be going up, down, in between, around, and underneath granite boulders throughout the scramble. While going through the rock scrambling, keep your eyes open for the blue blazes, as sometimes they are in strange places.

Throughout your journey to Old Rag Mountain, each time you think you’ve reached the summit – you haven’t! This mountain has several false summits. You’ll know that you’ve reached the Old Rag Summit when you see the brown ‘Old Rag Mountain’ sign. Find a lovely rock with a fabulous 360 degree view for your lunch spot here before starting your descent back down by way of the Saddle Trail.

Rock hopping down, you’ll pass two shelters. First is the Byrds Nest Shelter, then the Old Rag Shelter (privy here) before hitting a junction. Stay to your right to continue back on the Weakley Hollow Fire Road for about four miles to return to the parking lot. You will pass through beautiful forests and see Brokenback Run that leads into the Hughes River.

This is a challenging hike that will take most users several hours. It is highly recommended that you bring plenty of water on your trip. Hiking Old Rag is an adventure that should be on every Virginia hiker’s bucket list.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
This is a very challenging hike. Do not attempt this hike unless you are fully prepared. Do not attempt this hike if it is icy or rainy and stay within your group.  Shenandoah Park Emergency Number (800-732-0911) In the event of an emergency, please note the closest number on a blue marker to provide to the emergency responders.

Bring at least two liters of water per person, food, cell phone, and an emergency kit. Plan on this hike taking at least seven hours to complete. You will be using both upper and lower body strength due to the boulder scramble. A pair of workout gloves is helpful on the boulder scramble section.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there:
From the Baltimore Beltway:  Take I-70 west towards exit 32 (39 miles from I-695.) Go 39 miles to Exit 52 onto US 340-south/west to Front Royal. Go 58 miles and turn left onto US 522 in Front Royal. Go 16 miles and turn right to remain on US-522/US-211. Go 8 miles, and turn left to remain on US-522 in Sperryville. Go 1 mile and turn right onto VA-231. Go 6 miles and turn right onto VA-707 (brown sign to Old Rag). Go 1 mile and turn right onto VA-600, bear left to remain on VA-600. You’ll see large grass National Park parking area to your left. Register your car at the self-service fee station in the lot. You must have a valid Shenandoah National Park pass to enter.

NOTE: This is a very popular hike and during the summer months, this lot gets quickly full. Plan on an early start to get a jump on the crowd.
reviews: Beautiful hike with so many cool lookouts! As others have already said, the scramble near the summit is no joke so be sure to wear the right shoes. The descent is boring and you’ll feel like it goes on forever but it’s probably better than doing an out and back

“Don’t get cocky.” My best advice for the ENTIRETY of this trail. It is an amazing experience to hike it but it is challenging the ENTIRE time (except maybe like 2 miles on the fire road on the way back.)

The scramble: I am 5’3” and I needed a friend to actually give me multiple boosts during the rock scramble. It’s not short-queen friendly, but there were also time’s when the guys I was with were in pretty tight pickles and I had to help them navigate time things bc I could carry their packs more easily. Unless you are EXTREMELY  skilled I would absolutely do this with a few friends. 

One thing to be aware of - when you start your descent be super careful. It’s still very rocky and it would be very easy to turn an ankle if you are not nimble. Just something to be mentally prepared for. 

Otherwise a this is an amazing hike with a few very difficult parts and you will feel like you won the Olympics when you finish. 

We got there at 6:45 am on a Friday and it was not crowded.
Absolutely lives up to hype.  Pretty tough climb up to the false summit, then the fun begins.  The views from the summit are good but it is the scramble to the top that is the highlight.

This is a very strenuous hike in the July heat. We started early at 6:30 AM and finished the hike by around noon. Both I and my wife are moderately fit hikers but I ended up having sore ankles at the end of it (first time ever that my ankles have been sore). I recommend carrying at least 2.5 l of water per person and perhaps 3 l if one is starting the hike later in the day. Rock scrambles were indeed tough but enjoyable.

This was she best hike I’ve ever done. I am very fit and there were a lot of spots even I was struggling. It isn’t for the faint of heart. Pack lots of water. New bigger parking lot so there are way more spots then before.

Old Rag has been on the list for years. I finally had the chance to do it and am so glad I did. It was strenuous in some ways. I am in moderately good shape, strength training twice a week and I trail run. I still found the rock scrambles on the Ridge Trail challenging but doable. I was grateful other people were around and offered to assist if I needed it (which thankfully I didn't need). The Saddle Trail back down was steep but easy going and the fire road fun to run.  I did it in July and did not have enough water. I went through 2.5 L before I had to bust out my Life Straw flex bottle at the stream alongside the fire road and guzzled 750 ml like it was nobody's business.  All in all I drank 3.5 L. Make sure you carry enough. Saw signs for bears but thankfully no wildlife other than bees, flies, butterflies, and some random deer. Oh and another word of caution on the note of insects... be careful applying sunscreen or bug spray! I was so greased up between that and my sweat that I was slipping on the scramble. Enjoy. It is totally worth it!
definitely a must for everyone willing to  take it on the forest, hills and super cool views
One of my best  mountain hikes, it was adventurous trail in the first half and filled with beautiful mountain scenic spots.

This was my very first mountain hike ever! What a hike it was! beautiful scenery and an amazing view at the top.   The first mile was very inclined so I recommend pacing yourself. Especially if you have never done a hike like this. the trail is inclined for the most part and zig zags up the mountain side. when you approach the rock scramble be prepared for a lot of rock climbing. It then turns into more like a boulder scramble. It was an amazing experience and would do it again. 

I did very well throughout the hike until we hit the flat two mile walk to the parking lot. For some reason it really got me. I packed a CamelBak, cliff bars for the summit. I recommend hiking shoes or an amazing pair of tennis shoes. I wore tennis shoes, but the rocks were rough on my feet. Something I wish I had done was trim my toenails before the hike. I cracked two of them and bruised underneath one, but other than that. It was amazing!
My very first mountain climb ever! it was so.amzong and challenging! I oved every minute!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: McAfee Knob via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: McAfee Knob via Appalachian Trail is a 7.8 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Salem, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, and backpacking and is best used from April until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
This is a slow and steady climb to the most photographed spot on the Appalachian Trail. The peak at McAfee Knob is 3,171', giving it some of the best views in the state which is no surprise why it is one of the area's most popular hikes. Follow the white-blazed Appalachian Trail marker for panoramic views of the beautiful Blue Ridge mountains.

There are plenty of water sources throughout the hike up to the peak. Hikers also recommend going a bit further south after reaching the peak to view some cool rock formations and outcrops. Make sure to bring some bug spray in the summer months.

Please practice leave no trace and be mindful of trash! The Roanoke Appalachian Trail Club maintains this section of trail and volunteers regularly pack out trash and maintain campsites to keep it beautiful. Please see the park’s website for more information on rules and regulations on the trail.
reviews: Hike is difficult but sooo much fun! we got to McAfee Knob with enoigh time to see the sun start to set but a storm was rolling in so we set off just past the knob to one of the shelters. my 11 year old son and SO set up camp and had such a relaxing evening. woke up early enough to catch the sunrise the next morning. so perfect!

Took the fire road up and the AT down. 7.6 miles total. Took just about 4 hours and we were at the top for a while. Loved the trail. Got there at 10am on a Sunday and there was plenty of parking. Make sure you lock your vehicles and hide any belongings as some cars were robbed while we were hiking. Glad we took the time to do this part of the trail.
Great view at the top. Probably the most crowded trail on the Triple Crown. Get there early to find a parking spot!
The trail is well maintained and well marked. Beautiful sunrise!!!
Amazing views!!!

Great day hike
The creeks are all dry in July though, so take plenty of water. It's a 3 liter hike for me.
views so stunning i can’t put into words. the hike itself is a doozy and longer than it seems, so be sure to bring lots of water and pace yourself.

Very easy and pretty hike (if you take the fire road). We were short on time so we took the fire road up and down. Doing this, you can finish the trail in 2:30 + whatever time you spend at the knob. Came on a Sunday around 2:00pm and there was plenty of parking.
well marked, moderate to difficult terrain
Amazing! Great people and worth the hike for the view!! Would definitely do it again!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: White Oak Canyon and Cedar Run Trail Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: White Oak Canyon and Cedar Run Trail Loop is a 9 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking and backpacking and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This route is made up of the White Oak Canyon Trail and Cedar Run Trail to make a great backpacking trip or long day hike in the Shenandoah Valley! 

The 1st section of the trail takes you to the right along about 30 big and small waterfalls! This is the strenuous section of the trip. There is a great rock wall for climbers on this section approximately 1-1.5 miles from the trailhead (road 643) parking lot (weakly hollow road) which also makes a great place for lunch.

The yellow trail, marked by yellow markers, is the 2nd part of the loop, you will go over a steel bridge crossing the river where there is a fork. The yellow trail is to the LEFT, and the blue trail on the right goes 3 miles to skyline drive (which is not part of this loop). The yellow trail is a horse trail, but still climbs to approximately ~3200 feet gradually. There are no stair steps here, and you still may need to stop and catch your breath. You will encounter the next intersection which you should follow to the left (still yellow blazes). This leg of the loop ends at the skyline drive parking lot which can be your other entry point for this trail. At this intersection (4 way) you will take the blue blazed trail which returns in the direction that you came.

The 3rd and final part of the trail is blue marked and starts from the skyline drive parking lot intersection. This leg has a very notable waterfall called "the slide" because it is a sheer gradually sloped face with lots of waterflow over it, kind of like a slide. Having reached the peak of the hike in the 2nd leg end, this leg of the hike is downhill all the way. BEWARE that there are 3 river crossings, and this can be dangerous because they are on logs if you don't want to get wet. You can safely scoot along on the logs and make all the crossing. The final crossing will have red blazes on the trees marking all the crossing (approximately 4 log crossings). Be careful as the rocks may be slippery and can result in serious injury.

This hike can be considered more strenuous than Old Rag Mountain, which is right near by. If you are taking tons of pictures of the falls, stopping at the swimming holes, or taking an extra long lunch, then you should plan on 6-7 hours for this hike. 

The trail has groups come through heading to big meadows and can be busy at times, so start early. Larger wildlife such as black bears may be present, especially on foggy days.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
Bring 3-4 bottles of water or gatoraid, a good lunch with sodium (salt).

A hiking stick or pole is a must for this one.

Recommend the road 643 parking lot (weakly hollow road) as parking will be more available than on skyline drive.

Recommend you start early, 7 am is good.

For those with ankle / knee issues this hike may take you all day as 2/3 of it is stair stepping on rocks / loose rocks so know your own limits and beware.

This hike is more strenuous than old rag hike.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Pick up route 231 just south of Sperryville, headed south.  At Etlan turn right on Rte 643 and about 4.5 miles down 643 turn right on Rte 600.  4.7 miles up Rte 600 is the parking lot on the left.
reviews: good hike. did counter clockwise. generally steady uphill til midway. cut across river which cut some distance out. the horse trail is boring. then it is a sharp and rocky decent for 2.5-3 miles. agree the markers are off on the cedar run side by about. 25 miles. the rock slide is fun and both sides up offer ways to cool off. took just over 5 hours with stops for wading and snacks.
Tough rocky hike but one of the best in Shenandoah. Love the waterholes to jump in and of course you can’t beat a 40’ natural waterslide.

Fun hike. Went up counter clockwise. The hike up is steep but going down there are a couple of places to swim in. The markers for the swimming holes on the map were off for me. We had to hike an additional quarter mile down until we hit the swimming holes.
Great hike! Waterfall/swimming hole spots all along White Oak side of the loop.
Wow, lives up to its rating of very strenuous! Nice thunderstorm half way through but all the waterfalls makes it worth the effort.
Good hike! Went counter clockwise from parking lot, that trail is no joke very good workout at times.

Beautiful hike with water falls and pools along the way. It’s very up and down but we late 60’s, early 70’s women did it in 7 hours and that’s with stopping for lunch and wading in the water along the way. It’s strenuous but worth every minute!

Great trail, popular for a reason. Did the full loop in ~4 hours including water breaks at the falls and swimming holes. Should’ve brought my bathing suit! Counterclockwise, the two miles after the falls are thighburners so be ready for that

Definitely a hard one- especially if you’re going when it’s hot out. Not much flat trail here- very up or down. Took us about 5.5 hours but we stopped for lunch and a quick dip. We did see a water snake from a distance. Very crowded for the first two miles and last 2.5 miles, but pretty empty in between.

amazing hike with beautiful waterfalls almost the entire way. highly recommend for any experienced hikers.

actual trail length is a little over 9 miles. my distance is slightly off

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Hawksbill Gap Loop via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Hawksbill Gap Loop via Appalachian Trail is a 2.7 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Syria, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and walking and is best used from April until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Hawksbill Gap Loop hike is short and steep using the Appalachian Trail system. The AT is a white-blazed marker that leads to Hawksbill summit overlooking the Blue Ridge Mountains and Shenandoah Valley. Hawksbill Gap parking lot can be a challenge, so it is advisable to get there early. 

There are lots of waterfalls and a great panoramic view atop Hawksbill. The trail is rocky in some spots on the AT portion. Not very steep over most of the trail except for the ascent. Hikers say the best view is from the rocks on the upper portion of the Salamander Trail right before it connects into the Summit Trail.

During the winter months, this trail can get icy. Users recommend having a pair of microspikes.
reviews: Nice climb to the top.  Most people come back down the Hawksbill trail so take the loop via the AT to get the trail to yourself on the way back.
Cool, not humid, but wish I brought a wind breaker. Amazing views!
Quick hike to some great views!! We went up to the summit and back down the same way in about 1 hour. Highly recommend if you’re visiting the area on a time crunch
Wonderful hike.  Almost saw nobody on a Thursday afternoon.  I love walking along the historical AT.  Could be a little cloudy in the afternoon.
Awesome!! Went on a Thursday so it was very quiet and the weather was perfect
beautiful short hike definitely worth seeing. phone issues for the first half mile.

Awesome trail with tons of tree cover on a hot sunny summer day. Went counterclockwise on the AT/Salamander to the summit and Lower Hawksbill on the way back. AT is less strenuous going up, Lower Hawksbill is pretty much uphill the whole way to the summit, so be prepared for that if you want to take the shorter trip to the top. Awesome trail either way you go with great views.

Amazing hike.. 

Recommendations: 
1. Bug spray won’t work and there are lot of bugs on this trail…
2. Hawksbill Loop is the best option - Moderate, a bit rocky and steep.
3 Summit is at 4050 ft

Very well maintained lower hawksbill trail. We went clockwise which worked as finished the ascent and let the kids relax and then essentially down the trail to the AT on salamander trail. We added the extra mile + to crescent rock which has an ok view of stony mountain. The summit of hawksbill was worth the hike for the 10 and 13 yo who loved the view. Not overly strenuous for those who hike even somewhat regularly

It was a great trail. The whole loop is pretty long. Going up was little challenging because of elevation but the summit was worth the view. It’s the highest point of the park. Coming back was easier and much quieter. The trail was quite crowded. Ours was on july3rd

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Rose River Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Rose River Trail is a 3.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

The Rose River Trail, or Rose River Loop Trail, is best known for the Rose River Falls, but it also offers other smaller cascades to view along the route, a beautiful hike along the Rose River, and an off-the-path cave cemetery.

To begin the hike, go to the Fishers Gap Overlook parking lot and carefully cross Skyline Drive to get to the trailhead. The best direction is clockwise, taking you along the river and to the falls first, then ending with a walk back to your car along Rose River Fire Road.

Be aware of black bears in the area.
reviews: The first half on the fire road was nothing special but once you get past the falls we got a good workout. AllTrails estimates this at 3.8 miles but my Fitbit claimed 4.6 and my hiking buddy’s Apple Watch clocked 4.25. We both also tracked more than 860 ft in elevation gain. Just be aware!
Nice, go clockwise.

Great hike! Started at Dark Hallow and worked our way up to Rose River Trail. Youngest in our group is 9 years old and he loved it. It does have a few hard clubs for him getting close to Rose River Trail and then coming back towards Dark Hallow. All in all, he survived and enjoyed the hike.
A little rocky, but a great hike!
Nice trail; great weather
A great hike. Doing it clockwise is best. You’ll get to actually see the River and various levels of falls. If you go counter clockwise you’ll be looking behind you at it a lot.  A great time!
Some intense inclines but the river and falls are amazing!

Beautiful trail with many waterfalls along the way.  My kids powered through the elevation changes and enjoyed sticking our feet in the waterfalls when we needed a rest. This was the family favorite hike in Shenandoah!

Stunning. There are a few swimming holes. The first one is the rockiest the others are easier to get to. Not 3.8 miles. Uphill and rocky at the end just before the fire road. My 9 year old handled it but it's definitely a strong moderate.
Great, not as hot as it could have been.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Dark Hollow Falls Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Dark Hollow Falls Trail is a 1.4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Stanley, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and walking and is best used from April until October.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Dark Hollow Falls is one of the closest scenic falls to the Skyline Drive in Shenandoah National Park. This is a fairly easy walk down, but the trek back up on the way out may be slightly challenging.

This is a very popular hike at mile 50.7 of Skyline Drive that starts at the Dark Hollow Falls parking area. There are some sitting rocks along the trail if you need to rest especially on your way back up. In the spring the blossoms of Mountain Laurel adorn the path with bright pink blossoms. The trail follows the Hogcamp Branch stream as it leaves the Big Meadows spring and eventually drops over the falls. The trail is cool and shaded by a canopy of trees that offers welcome relief in the summer. As you are hiking down listen to the sounds of the water and also to the sounds of nature. One of the birds that may serenade your hike is the Blue Headed Vireo. This neotropical migrant that breeds at high elevations in the park has a very sweet melodious voice that seems to say "Look-Up, In-the-Trees". If you happen to see a dragonfly it may be one of the uncommon species that requires pristine, shaded mountain streams. When you spot one of these you know you are in a special place. Near the bottom of the trail you will come to a viewing platform where you can see the top of the falls. If you continue another tenth of a mile down the trail you will reach the base of the falls for a much more impressive view. Legend says that Thomas Jefferson was quite fond of these falls and spent time quietly contemplating the wonders of nature at the foot of Dark Hollow falls.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
This can be challenging for some, so come prepared.  

Wear sturdy shoes, carry plenty of water and perhaps a snack, and dress for the weather.  

Summertime storms can cause dramatic temperature changes.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park at Dark Hollows Falls parking area at mile 50.7. Trailhead is located in the north end of the lot.
reviews: Easy hike down.  The water is a bit low but I still was lucky enough to find some fish and shenandoah salamanders in the ponds!  The waterfall is truly lovely!
Crowded trail. People all over the waterfall. Really underwhelmed with this one.
Nice little hike. Fairly average hence the 3 stars.

Well maintained but extremely crowded. The trail ends at a waterfall with some rocks for pics but if continue down to fire road a better view of higher falls (all trails marks the trail to the bottom Shenandoah park marks to the first falls). Hike up is moderate but nothing strenuous if do some hiking. If with folks who don’t usually hike then the downhill to the falls is misleading and takes some time and multiple stops to get back up (and maybe consider stopping at the top falls and not continuing onto the fire road)... only real issue with the trail were the crowds but large parking lot and waterfall so lots of folks stop there.
Crowded, not much water during this time of the year, but a nice and short hike.

Scenic downhill walk that feels steep going back, definitely need to pace yourself but relatively mild.  The weekend crowd was a turn off but to be expected, despite that enjoyed wildlife and views of the falls

The trail is short and scenic. It is somewhat challenging going back up, and I heard several kids on my hike asking parents to carry them. It's not long, but plan for a lot of breaks on the way back up if you think you may need it with your group. I liked the Rose River Loop hike much more than this one, and it passes by the falls at the bottom of this hike.

Great small trail. 1.4 miles round trip. Park at Dark Hollow Falls Parking Area. Then follow the signs. It’s all down hill till the falls. Get nice steady hiking boots. And getting back is obviously up hill. I would say easy to moderate. But if you would like to continue, you can continue on the trial to Rose River Falls for another 3 miles. And do a complete loop back to the parking area.
Heavily trafficked and crowded. Would look look else where if you're looking for something more secluded in shenandoah.
Busy area. Recommend parking at the Harry F. Ford Sr. Visitor Center and taking the Story of the Forest trail over to the Dark Hollows trailhead.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Raven Rocks via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Raven Rocks via Appalachian Trail is a 5.7 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Bluemont, Virginia that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
This is a moderate trail with the final view point being the most magnificent. This out-and-back hike -- which some locals call "the roller-coaster" -- winds up and down several ridges, some of which are fairly steep. When leaves have fallen, the valley peeks through in the distance. Terrain is similar to other sections of the AT in the area and there are some sections that are very rocky. Due to the terrain it’s recommended to wear good hiking boots to get through this great hike.
 
You will pass over a few creeks, including raven rocks hollow on your way to the great views at the lookout. Take a few minutes to enjoy the view before you retrace your steps back to the parking area. Please note that parking is scarce, especially on weekends.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Virginia Route 7 - Pine Grove Road - (Trail head and parking area is right off the highway)
reviews: Great morning hike. Heavy traffic, but a fantastic view at the top.￼
Fun hike! There is a lot of elevation on this hike and it’s very rocky. I’d say moderate to strenuous.

Tiring but great trail
Ups and downs
A wide well trodden trail & a nice view on top. It is a little work to get up, mainly on the shade.

The hike was great, but it is not for the faint of heart. There are 3 pretty tough elevation gains over the nearly 4 mile hike in and then you have to hike them all back out, not really for the casual hiker. Bring plenty of water! The view at the overlook is nice! Though just as nice as the easier Bears Den hike.

favorite hike so far, my fiancee our 2 dogs (11 month german shepherd and 1.5 yr Staffordshire) and i are very active and hike alot. I will say we had kind of a hard time on this hike however I am asthmatic and neither of us have actual hiking boots which you will need on this trail it really is VERY rocky. my dogs did well and we got done in about 3 hours. fantastic view at the top. super busy on a Saturday at noon but we managed to grab the last parking spot.

The trail was awesome! As a moderate level trail-user this seemed to be the exact amount of effort and time for what I was looking for. Our relatively athletic doggo alao made this hike with us in about 85 degree weather on leash with a cooling vest and no issue. There were other dogs on and off-leash as we went who also seemed to be doing great.  

It was very warm, but not terrible as the trees offered a great deal of shade for most of the hike. The overlook was beautiful. From parking lot to overlook and back, it was a 3.5 hour trek for us with time for a snack and lots of water. There are no trash cans so expect to carry poop with you when your dog needs to go. Also no bathrooms that we ran into, but with all the sweat we didn't need it. ;) 

A little more than an entry-level environment: LOTS of ups and downs amongst rocky terrain. I need to use a cane sometimes for back/knee issues and I would not come here in the future while cane-bound. Please be mindful of your step here too! Sure-step hiking shoes are a must. We passed by a woman who had fallen when navigating rocks and appeared to have hurt her ankle. Clumsy dogs may also have a hard time navigating the terrain. 

People we encountered on the trail were super nice, and folks who had their dog off-leash always asked us if they needed to leash up before passing, which was nice. Plenty of spots to step aside if your doggo needs room passing dogs or people also.

We hiked this trail on July 4th. It was tough, but enjoyable! For inexperienced hikers like me and my wife, this trail isn't moderate; though, for experienced AT hikers, it'd likely rate as moderate. Trail distance to the peak and back is about 6 miles (I recorded 5.75 miles) and took us a little under 3 hours to complete, including ~20 minutes at the top. We hiked at a decent clip because we started the trail at around 5:00 pm. It's a very up-and-down trail--roller coaster is a good term--with moderately steep inclines and declines, and one or two steeper sections, though short. Hiking shoes with stiff soles and good lugs or skid resistance for rock surfaces are advisable since most of the trail is strewn with medium-sized rocks, many with sharp edges facing up, though surprisingly we saw hikers wearing tennis shoes and Tevas. If you're inexperienced, take your time and you'll be fine. Bring ample water to stay hydrated (we had a couple of 32 oz water bottles and a 16 oz bottle), and energy snacks, especially if you have kids with you. Some hikers had dogs, which would seem challenging in sections. The view at the top is panoramic and splendid, especially in the early evening, when we were there. Note that a couple we passed encountered a black bear. It gave them a stare and a scare, though, based on their description, it did not seem to take interest in them (or they didn't stick around long enough to find out).
The trail is more like 6.3 total miles, not 4.8 like AllTrails says. Lots of ups and downs throughout but well marked

Initial 2miles were pretty decent after which the switchbacks started.. Alltrails is incorrect and the trail is more than 5.6miles
Nice view from Raven Rock

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Stony Man via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Stony Man via Appalachian Trail is a 1.5 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Syria, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and bird watching and is best used from April until September.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

From the parking area, you will take the Appalachian Trail to the trail post where you will connect to the Stony Man Trail (blue blazes). You will continue until you rejoin the Appalachian Trail and this will return you to the start.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park in the Stony Man parking area located at mile 41.7. Trailhead is just inside the lot.
reviews: great view
super easy took me less than 20 min to get to top
Easy hike with a great reward, picturesque view!!!!!
Awesome trail, definitely easy and very kid friendly. Multiple spots at the summit to enjoy the amazing views.
Beautiful easy hike. The view from the summit is amazing. You can spend sometime at the summit and enjoy the view.

Our RECORDING was 1 point 8 miles. - My plan this year was to hike up the Little Stony man trail but we ended up going our favorite route we take every year. - We do the round about route to all three viewpoints then we return via the horse trail.
Great short hike to a beautiful view!

Weather was great! 
Trail in very good condition.
Parking area is limited so the earlier you arrive the better,  also it tends to get a bit overcrowded at the top at times.
Other thing to keep in mind...mosquitos, they are everywhere so bring your repellent.
Nice quick hike. Beautiful view.
Fun hike that seems doable for families. I took the bigger loop around, which is more challenging, but the shorter trail had lots of kids on it. The views from the top are incredible!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Dragon's Tooth Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Dragon's Tooth Trail is a 4.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Catawba, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, camping, and bird watching and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
The Roanoke Appalachian Trail Club maintains this section of trail and volunteers regularly pack out trash and maintain campsites to keep it beautiful. Please be mindful. 

Park rules and regulations are enforced:
-Maximum group size, day hikes: 25
-Maximum group size, backpacking/camping: 10
-No alcohol
-Dogs must be kept on leash at all times
-No camping or campfires outside of 7 designated areas (north of VA 624/Newport Rd, the only legal campsites are Johns Spring Shelter, Catawba Shelter and campsites, Pig Farm campsite, Campbell Shelter and Lambert’s Meadow Shelter and campsites)
-No camping or campfires on McAfee Knob or Tinker Cliffs
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Roanoke, VA: Take I-81, Exit 141 to VA 311 north for 10 miles to Dragons Tooth Parking Lot. Sign is on left, just past Catawba Grocery (also on left).
reviews: Great hike with a rewarding view at the end. Trailhead is easy to find with a bathroom at the gravel parking lot. Gradual uphill with slight scramble and more intense uphill at the last 1/4 mile.
Quick, fun hike. The rock scramble is the best part.

It was hot out there. I thought getting there at 9 would be too late on a Saturday, but there was actually plenty of parking. The lot for McAfee Knob was full today though. Be prepared for the rocky climb at the top. That was my favorite part of the hike. Recording finished at the top instead of resumed so the time is only showing the hike up.
Tough but the summit is worth the effort
Amazing views and fun rock scrambles! A little challenging but totally worth it :)
It was good I don’t see how any one could bring a dog out it tho other then that near the end was hard and very rocky terrain but the view was amazing and if you do it climb the rocks at the end
Awesome hike.  The last half mile is tough, but the view makes it worth the effort.  If you walk around the back side of Dragon’s Tooth, you can scramble to the top!!

We’re from Ohio so we’ve never dealt with this type of terrain. I wouldn’t say it was difficult just a little scary if you have issues with heights. Definitely not an easy hike but getting down went by quick
Ample parking space, nice hike, it is not that hard to get to the top.

Great trail with a great view. Like the signs say the last mile is very Rocky. My 80 lbs dog did a great job climbed everything with ease. I would be concerned taking small dogs on this trail unless you plan on carrying them for some of it.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: South River Falls Trail and South River Fire Road Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: South River Falls Trail and South River Fire Road Loop is a 4.6 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Elkton, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and bird watching and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This route is well-marked, with a good balance of steep terrain, rocks, roots and switchbacks on the way down on South River Falls Trail and smooth trail on the way back up on South River Fire Road. The moss and waterfalls are beautiful, and depending on what time of year you visit, you may find the breathtaking fall colors that are typical of Shenandoah National Park. 

Pets must be on leash at all times. Be prepared for a water crossing.

If you want to go to the base of the falls, continue past the observation point about 1.5 miles until you see the base of the waterfall marker. This additional viewpoint is highly recommended. On the journey back to your start point at the South River Picnic Area, make sure you turn onto the Appalachian Trail from the fire road - if you stay straight you will end up on Skyline Drive instead of at the parking lot.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park in the South River Picnic Area where the trail begins near the third parking area. The milepost is 62.8.
reviews: Great trail conditions. Falls are worth the trek down and fire road back. Lots of shade & constant breeze.
Cool steps in the beginning and a beautiful view of the falls and swimming hole from the overlook above. We got rained out, but had a little motivation from our friend, Bombay.

Never will I ever do this again. 
The waterfall was cute but not worth the struggle of coming back up hill. I mean UPHILL battle.

A great trail to hike with the kids. There were multiple swimming holes and even a natural water slide. 
Beware of the copperheads. We saw two sunning themselves peacefully during the hike.
Gorgeous. Definitely worth it when you get to the falls. Copperheads, rattlers, and black snakes everywhere. Eyes open! Need good shoes with traction. It’s wet and slippery in spots.

Great trail, as others say take it all the way down. Follow the marker that says “base of the falls” and then climb up the rock steps to the top. I did the fire road back out with my 10 year old twins which made all that uphill slow but manageable. Be aware that there’s a nest of rattlesnakes on the overlook, and we almost stepped on a copperhead at the base of the falls.
Beautiful trail, nice downhill, just be prepared to come back up. This said the falls are worth the work.  You must go all the way down in order to see the fall. Gorgeous falls.

Really enjoyed this trail!  Went the way that the app indicates - it's a little difficult to see the falls from the overlook, but as others have said, it's hiking down to the bottom of them that makes the trail so cool.  Be aware, it's very rocky as you're approaching the bottom of the falls.  Though the fire road is all uphill (which I was dreading), it's made much easier by the fact that it's not very rocky at all; so you're not having to step up and around rocks, it's a relatively smooth ascent.  I still felt pretty good by the time I reached the parking lot.

Also saw all kinds of wildlife - a muskrat, chipmunk, deer, birds and some interesting insects.  Overall took me about 3 hours (including a stop for lunch).

Nice trail down to the waterfall, and save your energy for the hike back up. I did the fire road first (opposite direction of most hikers), and I liked it more. Some wet/muddy spots, so I’m glad I wore boots. You can probably walk the trail in sneakers if it hasn’t rained in a few days so the trail can dry out.

There are restrooms and a picnic area at the parking lot / trailhead. Plenty of parking either near the trail or further away on the road that loops around the picnic area.
Just beautiful waterfall. You must go all the way down to see this beautiful gem. Highly recommend.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Crabtree Falls Trail in George Washington and Jefferson National Forests is a technical and moderately difficult trail to Crabtree Falls. This day-use area is managed by the Glenwood and Pedlar Forest Service Ranger Districts.

Great trail to enjoy.

it's a great trail. I am 75 years old and I'll let you know what was a bit harder than expected for me. Great Hike! Lots of stairs but a cool breeze around the waterfall and nice views on top.

Awesome trail - make sure to go the full 1.7 out as the overlook is 0.2 miles past the sign that says last view of the falls. https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Bearfence Mountain Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Bearfence Mountain Trail is a 1 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Hood, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and bird watching and is best used from April until October.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

No pets are allowed on this trail.

After parking in the Bearfence Mountain parking lot, cross Skyline Drive and follow the blue blazes of the Bearfence Mountain Trail, one of the most popular trails in Shenandoah National Park. 
 
The Bearfence Trail leads up a steep slope that eventually turns into rock scrambles until you reach the summit of Bearfence Mountain. Blazes mark the best scramble climbing route. The view from the summit is well worth the climb as it is one of only three summits in the park that has a 360-degree view.

Getting down from the summit requires a short scramble climb, after which the Bearfence Trail returns to a normal hiking surface. The Appalachian trail can be accessed from either one of two right turns from the Bearfence Trail. The second right turn should be followed to complete the one-mile loop. The Appalachian Trail leads back down the mountain to Skyline Drive.
 
The scramble climb makes this trail a unique hike to a great view. Anyone who is reasonably fit and flexible should be able to handle the scramble climb, but hikers who have issues with heights may want to skip this trail. Near the summit, the climbing path occasionally passes within eighteen inches or so of sheer drops. This is also definitely not the trail for families with kids small enough that they have to be carried, and older children may also find the climb difficult.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: From Washington DC follow I-66 West and exit onto US 29 at Gainesville. Follow to Warrenton, and take 211 West. Take 211 to Sperryville until you reach Skyline Drive. Take Skyline Drive south towards Big Meadows. Pass the big meadowns and drive down to either Bootens Gap (mp 55.1) or the Bearfence M

this trail was great, amazing views at the top!! the rock scramble is super cool, but definitely is a little dangerous at points so be prepared for a few instances of pulling yourself up on the rocks, a little bit of climbing & such! great experience & definitely would go again, just wish we were more prepared for its strenuous nature at times. one of the best 360 panoramic views in the park!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Little Stony Man Loop via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Little Stony Man Loop via Appalachian Trail is a 3.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Syria, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and bird watching.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

The Little Stony Man Loop is a great hike that begins on the Appalachian Trail and heads to Stony Man Mountain and Stony Man Overlook in Shenandoah Valley. It continues on the AT to Little Stony Man. The second part of the loop is along Passamaquoddy Trail, which brings you back to the start. It offers spectacular views from the top. The lower part of the loop is beautiful too, with a lot of lush, green moss. Bring your picnic or time if right for the sunset and hang out on the Stony Man cliffs for a while.

The parking lot is off of Skyline Drive, just before the mile 40 mark. You can also access it from the Skyland Resort if you are staying there. Dogs are allowed on the Appalachian Trail portion only.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park in the Little Stony Man parking area located at mile 39.1.
reviews: Not the best views because you see the roads weaving through all the mountains but a nice, quick hike if you’ve already done the other trails in the area
Great trail and multiple views along the way.
Great day hike.  Multiple very nice overlooks.  Stony man outlook very easy to get to. Did full loop.  Either way is fine.

FYI: this wound up tracking at 3.9 miles for me instead of 3.3, and I did it counter-clockwise, though if you don't love rocky descents, I might recommend doing it clockwise - there were a few areas that were quite rocky that I would've preferred hitting as an ascent rather than descent.
Amazing!!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maryl.name: Billy Goat Trail and Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Trail Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maryl.region: Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maryl.overview: Billy Goat Trail and Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Trail Loop is a 7.2 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Great Falls, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and camping and is accessible year-round.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maryl.description:
One of the best hikes in the Washington DC area and a short drive from Virginia and Maryland, the Billy Goat Trail consists of three main trails - A, B, and C - in the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historic Park. The trail, marked by blue blazes, features fun rock scrambles and spectacular views between the C&O Canal and the Potomac River. All three sections can be accessed off the canal towpath between Great Falls Tavern and Carderock.

The Billy Goat Trail is open year-round and protected by the National Park Service and The Nature Conservancy. The park was established in 1961 as a National Monument by President Dwight D. Eisenhower to preserve the neglected remains of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal and many of its original structures. 

You can purchase a vehicle permit or an individual permit (foot, bike, equestrian). The Great Falls Tavern visitor center (Wednesday through Sunday) has more information about hiking trails and the history of the area. Pets are not allowed on the Billy Goat Trail Section A, or on the boardwalk to Great Falls. 

Vehicle passes are $20 for 7 consecutive days. Motorcycle passes are $15 and hiker/biker passes are $10. They also have annual passes.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maryl.tips: Start this hike early to avoid the crowds as this trail gets very busy.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/maryl.getting_there: Section "A" is accessible via the Great Falls Tavern Visitor Center on MacArthur Blvd (ample parking). Access Section "B" via the towpath at Old Anglers Inn on MacArthur Blvd or Carderock off of Clara Barton Pkwy. Access Section C via Carderock off of Clara Barton Pkwy.
reviews: Great!!! Very rocky and can be a little slippery so make sure you are wearing the right shoes but you are gonna love it !the rock scramblings are so much fun! A lot of people around which is great as well very fun and beautiful

Nice trial with a lot of optional routes for climbs.  We actually climbing straight up at one point instead of following the trail around the rock and it was very rewarding.  Very rocky but a nice hike and it’s only 4-5 miles.  Start early as it’s hot and bring water.

Really nice trail, A loop has the rock scrambles.  This part was a lot of fun.  Take the spur trail to view the falls.  Leave the dogs at home, they are not allowed on A for good reason, it would be dangerous for them.  C loop is closed due to erosion so that shortened our hike to about 5.5 miles
Too crowded…the people had no trail etiquette.
Pretty easy with not much steepness. The views are good ,specially around the river falls.
Cliffs and rocky, but good views and beautiful.
Gorgeous hike. Lots of people on the main path. Billy goat A requires lots of scrambling, but that’s why this trail is awesome.
Great rock scrambling!
very rocky - lots of fun climbs but quite difficult for beginners

Honest assessment of this trail:

- We timed our entry to the park perfectly; we followed the Memorial Day 5K, so a lot of people were leaving as we entered, and the trail was not very crowded at all.  HOWEVER: generally speaking, this trail has become SO crowded since COVID hit (and, really, well before that), that they’ve instituted (and are enforcing) a one-way direction on the trail (starting from the Great Falls Tavern) to try to mitigate the degradation people have caused to the trail
- The trail is continually rerouted due to human use that it can be different each time you go out
- The rocks can get very slick when wet or when covered in dirt (actually more slick); some people come unprepared and attempt to hike in flip-flops, etc 
- If you are not physically fit, you will have trouble with the scrambles, especially the ones that require some upper body strength (the steep ledge toward the end of the trail comes to mind; frequenters of BGA know which one I’m talking about)
- On the plus side, the locks are operating fully, and the water on the towpath side is crystal clear (clearer than I can ever remember)
- BGB is closed due to trail damage; don’t be a jerk and try to hike it anyway

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Sharp Top Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Sharp Top Trail is a 2.6 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Bedford, Virginia that offers the chance to see wildlife and is rated as difficult. Because of the now closed weather observatory at the top it has been quite developed up there. But it is still a beautiful view; well worth the hike up. Amazing views and a good challenge for a new hiker like me!
Short uphill hike to amazing views. Plenty of parking on a Saturday around 10am. Mostly shaded, with lots of people.
Great hike! Amazing views from the top.
Excellent hike, a bit strenuous for us 67 and 75 year olds with many Rock steps but doable. Amazing view at the top!  Go early as it gets crowded quickly.

Was rocky but great. Was my first all by myself hike. Challenge but doable for 52 year old in good shape. I did it in my Teva sandals and was fine. Well marked and traveled. Beautiful 360 view.   Also stop at Buzzard overlook.

A lot of steps

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Cascades Falls Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Cascades Falls Trail is a 3.8 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Pembroke, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
The Cascades National Recreation Trail is a highly scenic, easy to moderate 4 or 5 mile out and back round-trip trail features a shaded mountain creek to a 66-foot waterfall within Jefferson National Forest.

Cascades 66 Foot Waterfall Hike is the same trail as the Cascades National Recreation Trail, a highly scenic, easy to moderate 4 or 5 mile out and back round-trip trail featuring a shaded mountain creek to primarily a cascading waterfall within Jefferson National Forest. Near Pembroke in Southwest VA, the hike up the lower trail travels 2 miles along Little Stony Creek before reaching the 66 lower falls and in another half-mile the Upper Cascades. Travel uphill another 2 miles and reach a view of the New River Valley from 700 cliffs at Barneys Wall (8 mile RT and 1600 elevation gain).

The trail begins to the right of the bathroom and Information Center at the far end of the Cascades parking lot. Go across the first bridge and take the lower trail as it is the more scenic route. If users want, they can return on the upper trail to get a different view of the creek. The lower trail travels alongside the creek for a mile before reaching the second bridge and rejoining the upper trail. From the 2nd bridge to the lower falls is another mile. The lower falls is a turn-around point or users can continue to the Upper Cascades and/or Barneys Wall.

To continue to the Upper Cascades and Barneys Wall, head up the wooden stairs to the left opposite the falls observation deck. In about 200 yards reach an open area with a sign post showing the Conservancy Trail, a 0.4 mile fire road. At the fork in the road bear left and take another left in about 50 yards at the Conservancy Trail sign post. This trail is Yellow-blazed and crosses a small creek and reaches the Barneys Wall intersection on the left in 1.1 miles. The trail to Barneys Wall is also yellow-blazed and passes through a few stands of Hemlocks, and just before the cliffs take the trail past the campsite to the right. Barneys Wall features a view of the New River Valley looking towards Blacksburg. If you take the right at the fork exactly one half mile above the lower falls there is an unmarked but well established path that leads downhill to the Upper Cascades located about a tenth of a mile down the hill.

$3 fee to park.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Pembroke, VA: Take Rt. 460 to Pembroke and turn right onto Rt. 623. Travel 4 miles to the Cascades parking lot.
reviews: Lovely trail. Lower side can be a little slippery. Trail to upper falls not marked or maintained but worth the extra walk.
Wow! One of the most beautiful trails I’ve been on so far. I recommend taking the lower trail across the bridge when you’re going up, and the higher trail when going down.
Took a little time on scenic route but wonderful view and was very enjoyable.

It was a moderate trail, it was a steady incline on the way up. Very rocky and steep in a lot of places. Please bring trekking poles. Very satisfying once you make it to the end. Water was cold. You can swim there too.
We took the lower trail up to the falls and the upper trail back down.
This was a beautiful trail, the water was clear it’s the most beautiful trail. We drove two and a half hours to get here and it was worth it!!

Did lower out, upper back. There’s a tree across one part of the lower (I had no problem ducking under it) and some of the rocks got washed out at one spot of the lower leaving a very narrow trail that happened to be under an overhanging rock (so had to duck under that as well). Otherwise both trails in great shape! Waterfall was gorgeous, lots of great river scenery along lower trail.
Absolutely beautiful!!!!
Lower trail had beautiful water views. Rocky but worth it. Stunning falls
Magneficient !  Recommend...

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Marys Rock via Appalachian Trail (North Approach)
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Marys Rock via Appalachian Trail (North Approach) is a 3.4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Sperryville, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This route typically takes about 3 hours and 30 minutes to complete. Pets must be on a 6-ft leash.
reviews: This was a beautiful hike. We started at about 11:30 and finished within 90 minutes, including a long lunch break at the top. It was super buggy - come prepared with bug spray and ready to swat away the gnats. We went on a Friday and wasn’t overly crowded at all, plenty of parking right at the trailhead.
Very rocky! Brought our dog and recommend not to bring in the future. Very steep on the way down! Great hike though and got poured on at the end

Loved this hike! The trail was easy to follow, dog friendly, and shaded. The summit was very windy and also smaller than anticipated - it got pretty crowded so we had to wait a few minutes to see the spectacular views. There are a few rocks along the way to the summit where you can take a nice pit stop and get a better view than at the summit itself. The return to the trailhead is a somewhat steep downhill path.
Gorgeous spot for a sunrise

Great trail. All uphill from trailhead. Nice views to the east most of the way up. Nice summit with great views. Started at 6:30 am. There were 3 separate groups coming down the trail that passed us. No one at the summit

Great trail with incredible views at the peak. Busy today but the other hikers were great.  Steady climb with a relatively flat area 1/2 way up which was a nice break. Mostly rock covered trail so wear steady hiking boots. Only downside was the road noise from loud motorcycles on nearby Skyline Drive.
Amazing.
Tough trail due to the trail being made of large rocks. Wear proper boots with support. The view is worth it
Great
Great tree cover

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Little Devils Stairs Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Little Devils Stairs Trail is a 6.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Sperryville, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from April until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: If you think you’re going in the wrong direction trying to find the parking lot to the trail, you’re not. I thought our GPS messed up because it looks like you are just driving out to someone’s remote house. We got there early as other reviewers said the parking lot fills up quickly. We were the 2nd car in the lot when we began and the lot was full when we finished. Hiked the trail counter clockwise as suggested as well, so we were climbing up the falls and took the fire road back down to the parking lot. When you get off of the trail, make a left onto the fire road. Was a good challenge hiking up the falls and a relaxing walk back to the car via fire road. Not many scenic views, but great rock scrambles.

This was a great trail! Did it counterclockwise this morning, thanks to previous AlllTrails users' reviews. I was first to arrive so got All the Spiderwebs, of course. I agree with the previous hiker review that said they weren't sure if they were trespassing at the parking lot. I was first and I backed in, so was facing giant NO PARKING signs and was a bit confused. But I think the no parking is just on that one side. When I got back down, the little lot was full. I don't think it can fit more than 7-9 cars, so I was glad I arrived early. 

Trail up was beautiful and rocky, lots of neat water stuff along the stream. A lot of it is well-maintained, and some is overgrowing. I put on tick spray as others have recommended in reviews, and didn't have any issues. The fire road down is beautiful and easy, and after you get on the fire road, .4 miles down there is a tiny trail off to the left with a beautiful, limited view. Shady the whole way. Would do this one again, and would take visitors here - it's a nice easy distance but challenging on the way up, as one expects from a hike!
We parked at the top of this hike, so our hike had a bit more mileage. We went clockwise,

We went counterclockwise as many people suggested here, and I think this was the right decision. The climb was at times challenging for our kids and 11 months corgi, but manageable. The whole route was shaded, which is a very nice feature on a hot day. Tick defense spray is a must.
Too boring, tiring, hot, and mostly no views
Fantastic hike! Challenging and fun :) getting to the parking lot is interesting, as it seems to be private property (I couldn’t tell if I was trespassing at first!).

Lovely trail - tough rock scramble on the way up (super scenic!) but pretty fire road on the way down. Don’t miss the overlook - about .5 away from the top of the fire road. Go counter clockwise so you go up the scramble and down the fire road!
Crazy pretty, top 5 fav hikes for sure! However, it’s pretty technical, with a half dozen stream crossings and lots of loose steep rocks. Rated as strenuous which is accurate

Great trail, spectacular scenery, we did it backwards so you go up the falls. Once you get to the top be sure to go left on the service road to get back to the parking lot. The blue trail continues across the service road and the cell signal was nil so we continued on for about 3/4 of a mile before realizing our mistake. There is a really cool old graveyard on the way back as well.
Gorgeous water features. Little slippery after the storms.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: White Oak Canyon Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: White Oak Canyon Trail is a 9.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, camping, horses, and backpacking and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

The White Oak Canyon Trail is a great hike that users especially enjoy given the opportunities to splash around in the waterfalls of the Shenandoah Valley. The trail is well maintained and has a few markings to keep users on track - downloading the offline map is always helpful. The path is sometimes narrow, with lots of rocks and fallen leaves. As a result, it can be a bit slippery close to the waterfalls and creek beds, so users should wear hiking boots or shoes with good traction.

The upper falls are quite large and feature small pools to swim in during summer. Upper White Oak falls is the last waterfall along the trail, although users can hike further if they would like to add extra distance and to see more of the blue ridge. If users are interested in swimming the biggest swimming holes, they are close to the lower falls and the White Oak parking lot and are more crowded. And users climb the trails the holes get more shallow, but are fun for a dunk and more secluded. Make sure to bring some swimming gear or shorts if going to swim, since inside of the covered forest it can be cool.

There are upper and lower parking lots and a $20 fee to park. Arrive early as this is a popular hike. The parking lot on Skyline Drive fills up fast. Users can also use the White Oak Canyon parking area, which is accessed from outside of the Shenandoah Park. Parking fees also include park entry.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park in the Whiteoak Canyon parking area at mile 42.6. Trailhead is located in lot.
reviews: It was longer than I anticipated but worth doing the whole climb! Get in early and less people on the trails!

One of the first Shenandoah hikes I did…. Before AllTrails. It’s in the park so a pass is required to get in. Good beginner trail. Not too challenging but a good distance. Some pretty little falls along the way. Well marked.
Awesome! Believe the sign when it says strenuous but the waterfalls and swimming holes are worth the hike!
Great trail!  The area between the 2 falls was steep!

I enjoyed this trail but if I were to do it again I would still start at the Southern trailhead but would only hike about 3.5 miles before turning around.  Hiking to the nice view that is marked with a concrete pillar would be optimum.  Not too much to see above that IMO.  That said the falls are beautiful and the forest is beautiful.
Awesome!
I loved this trail, did it in the rain. great bang for your buck with beautiful waterfalls. good mid length vacation hike.
Nice hike. Started at lower parking lot which made the 2nd half downhill. Swimming holes would be great on hot days, but trail does get busy.

started at the top from skyline drive. it was a bit of a rainy sunday and not many people were out on the trail but it was a lot of fun and a good workout! the best part was hiking up looking at the waterfalls
Hiked to second falls, ate lunch, easy pace about 3 1/2 hours.  would do again.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Hawksbill Summit Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Hawksbill Summit Trail is a 1.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that offers the chance to see wildlife and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and bird watching and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Tallest peak in Shenandoah, nothing to see until summit, then 360 degree view.

This trail is steep for nearly the entire hike. You are well inside the tree line for the entire hike, so there is not much to see. Once you reach the byrd shelter the views abound, and just another 100 feet or so, you reach the summit overlook, a beautiful 360 degree view. The NPS has a stone overlook built on the summit, so it's easy to know when you have gotten there.

It's a tough walk but worth it. Within an hour you can bag the tallest peak in Shenandoah!

There is an alternate version of this hike that is a loop. The hike described in this report is an out an back route.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: The trailhead is actually a small parking area on the side of the Skyline drive, near mile marker 45.6. There is a typical NPS trailhead sign with a map on the edge of the lot, which holds only 4-5 cars.
reviews: Nice view but hazy day. Fairly busy trail. Good footing.

Did this hike after doing both Table Rock and the Chimneys. Lucky to find parking at 12:30pm on a Sunday. Got last spot. Pretty steep towards end but wonderful payoff. Great 360 views. Well worth the effort. Hiked with wife, two kids (13&11) and big dog.
extremely steep, definitely a nice view at the top! a little overhyped but definitely worthwhile seeing if you’re up for it, plus a lot of cool rocks to climb around or sit and rest on at the top.
Great hike with great views. Must do in shenandoah
Steep but well worth the effort. Yes
Difficult climb but worth the view - went for a sunset dinner picnic and it did not disappoint!

We took this one meaning to take the loop trail (loop is to the right, this trail is the straight shot up the Mountain). Incline was a little more than anticipated but it was a nice short hike with really extraordinary views. Took us maybe 30 mins to get to the top. I recommend going passed the little shelter and up to the rocks, much better views in my opinion!
great incline to get to the summit. the view at summit was worthwhile. the only drawback was the lack of scenery along the way, maybe it's because of the time of the year.
Super steep and all uphill. Beautiful summit.
Part 1 of a 4 day backpacking trip. great views

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: River, Ridge, CCT and Swamp Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: River, Ridge, CCT and Swamp Trail is a 4.6 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Great Falls, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Great Falls Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, bike, or horseback the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

$15 entrance fee.

This trail is a lot of fun. Lots of rock scrambles, optional side trails, and a ton of gorgeous views. Lots of people there with kids, baby carriers and dogs! As others have noted, the park gets very, very busy so you should go as early as you can.
reviews: More climbing than I thought. Glad I had my poles!
Very crowded
Beautiful park. We’ll marked. I was surprised of how busy it was being that it’s Thursday.
Wicked awesome

Good walk in the area. The park is very crowded on the weekend (arrive early).  The trail closest to the river is rockier (and more crowded). As you get away from the visitor center / parking, the crowds thin out. A few steep sections and not flat/paved in many parts - but overall not difficult.
quiet at 7:30 am.  great trails with some rick scramble and a little incline here and there.  Nice and shaded for a summer morning.
The river section is nice but very busy. Pretty foliage and little creeks on the Ridge and Difficult Run sections.
Gorgeous!!! It was super busy next to the River.  There are tons of fun rocks to climb on along the trail.
Very busy on the weekend but a great workout regardless. Definitely some areas for some good bouldering. Great views.
Absolutely gorgeous. It was just challenging enough to make it interesting and fun. 10/10 will probably come back

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Wilburn Ridge via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Wilburn Ridge via Appalachian Trail is a 4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Mouth of Wilson, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Day use parking is along the road at Massie Gap with overflow at the Visitor Center. Overnight parking is now limited to the Overnight Backpackers Lot and reservations are required. Backcountry camping is not allowed within the state park boundaries, so you must hike onto USFS property before setting up. 

Check the park’s webpage for the most up to date information on reservations, trail closures, fees or requirements at .
reviews: Bring a lot of water. If you wanna challenge yourself a little bit more and also avoid crowds follow the blue blazes. Very nice.
Poggers

Very peaceful 4mile to and back hike! Wild ponies are seen just a moments away from the start, seen grazing and napping in open fields and even surprising you on the skinnier bits! If you decide to continue up to the top, it does get quite rocky but nothing too horrible that you don’t get to take your time on!
Really amazing!!!!

Beautiful experience and just enough elevation gain to get a good workout. 

My wife and I hiked it on a Thursday, early-July, morning (started @ 9am) and we had the trail almost to ourselves. Coming back down 90ish mins later we passed lots of groups coming up. So if you like solitude, get there early. 

Incredible views and seeing the ponies was cool. Wear sunscreen since the vast majority of the hike is in the open. Highly recommend.
Great trail, wild horses are awesome. It rained on us today and trails were like a pond but that was expected.

Amazing hike. Several trail options to get to the ridge.  Stunning vistas and added bonus of the ponies and Longhorns. Not a lot of tree cover so sunscreen is a must. Also good bug spray! Highly recommend this trail:)

This place is a magical wonderland. I'll go back any chance I get!  Views literally everywhere you look,  ponies,  longhorns, rock scramble to your heart's desire, & rhododendrons are blooming right now!  Always windy, terrain is rocky so bring a jacket & proper footwear! My dog loved it but I could see where a dog could get hurt on the rock scramble parts if you aren't careful.  It's such a unique experience!

I’ve obsessed over this park for years and finally got to do it! I had 3 small children in tow, so my husband and I were only able to do half the trail. We opted to do the AT where it paralleled the trail and that was a treat. 

Very rocky, but completely manageable even for parents with kids in carriers like us. It was surprisingly cold up there. I’m so glad other hikers mentioned wearing and bringing a jacket because it was brisk. The ponies were so cute and we found lots of them within a mile.
