I can’t believe the incredible views on this trail! The spruce trees and open vistas fell like you’re in a completely different place than you are. Feels like Scotland or California! 

Can’t recommend this one enough. My new favorite!!
Perfection

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Humpback Rocks Recreation Area
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Humpback Rocks Recreation Area is a 1.8 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Lyndhurst, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and bird watching and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
SEASONAL ROAD CLOSURE: Blue Ridge Parkway is subject to seasonal closure. For more information, please visit https://www.nps.gov/blri/planyourvisit/roadclosures.htm. When Blue Ridge Parkway is closed, you can park on Howardsville Turnpike and walk about 1.2 miles on the Parkway to the trail. 

Fun hike and a great view at the top. Poles would be helpful to bring.
reviews: Beautiful hike overall, a little steep going up but it's not bad. Go early, hike gets a bit crowded by mid day, especially on weekends!
This trail is beautiful! There is so much vegetation & flowers. The view is worth the steep hike.
Definitely an intensive hike up, but well worth it for the spectacular views at the top!￼

This was our first hike of the morning. It definitely is all up hill on this trail for the most part. Got the heart rate pumping but felt good. Just took our time and took the rest stops. Putting in the effort was well worth it. The view is unbelievable. Worth every step.
very steep but fun!
Great short hike. Some parts are moderately challenging.
The trail is short but steep. A nice hike if you just want something easy and simple, can get crowded at the top though since it’s heavily trafficked
The trail is very steep, and gets rocky but the view was worth it!
I tried this hike 10 years ago and failed.. my husband pushed me and we were able to do it together. Even if I cussed him out in my head a million times haha well worth it.

The end has amazing views but you earn it on the way up. Steep incline for the majority of the way up.  Lots of benches for breaks if needed though. First half is gravel while the second half of over rocks and boulders.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Tinker Cliffs via Andy Layne Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Tinker Cliffs via Andy Layne Trail is a 7.3 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Troutville, Virginia that features a river and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, nature trips, and bird watching and is best used from April until September.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Offers beautiful views south of the Catabwa Valley and McAfee Knob area. Trail runs through a private farm and requires climbing a few fence ladders (to prevent those cows from straying). There's a pretty neat trail bridge that crosses a stream. Once past all this, there is a continual incline. Views at the cliffs are the big payoff.

Please leave no trace and be mindful of trash. This trail sees a large number of traffic and has been having problems with rising trash, illegal camping and misuse of the area. The Roanoke Appalachian Trail Club maintains this section of trail and volunteers regularly pack out trash and maintain campsites to keep it beautiful.

Park rules and regulations are enforced:
Maximum group size, day hikes: 25
Maximum group size, backpacking/camping: 10
No alcohol
Dogs must be kept on leash at all times
No camping or campfires outside of 7 designated areas ( north of Va 624/Newport Rd, the only legal campsites are Johns Spring Shelter, Catawba Shelter and campsites, Pig Farm campsite, Campbell Shelter and Lambert’s Meadow Shelter and campsites)
No camping or campfires on McAfee Knob or Tinker Cliffs
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there:
Take exit 150B for US-220 N toward Daleville/Fincastle 0.2 mi
Turn right onto US-220 N/Roanoke Rd 1.4 mi
Turn left onto VA-779/Catawba Rd about a mile or so.
Destination will be on the left. Lot is somewhat hidden. 

If you reach the fork in the road, turn around and go back a few 100 yards.
reviews: The most rewarding trail out of the Triple Crown! The steps really make you earn it. Multiple overlooks at the top, take the time to check each out.

**Trailhead begins on the Andy Layne Parking lot side. There is a trail across the street, that's not it. We saw two sets of people that asked us this question. Hope this helps! 

At 1.5 miles in there is a brutal staircase for about a quarter mile. 1 or 2 more small steep sections, but not so bad. 

This trail was well maintained. Two nice bridges...one even went over 5 or 6 Cows trying to keep cool. Walking through the open field amongst the Cows was pretty neat as well. 

Great hike! My son (10yo) rated the Virginia Triple Crown as follows: McAfee Knob, Dragon's Tooth, and lastly Tinkers Cliff. I thought they were all worth it!

It was a great view at the top but man, it is definitely a difficult hike. I also don’t recommend doing it right after a rain because there were some real slick spots coming back down. The trail was very well kept though and some nice small wildlife sightings.
Beautiful forest trail even on a hot day it’s not so hot, good workout, especially at the steps section. I always enjoy a good climb. The view is great, nice cool breeze.
Nice cool trail in the forest, great view of the valley!

Great trail, beautiful forest and awesome rock formations/cliffs up top. Hiked on a rainy morning and didn’t see any people until the parking lot. Did run into a black bear on the way down, 20 feet off the trail. Gave it space for a few minutes and it wandered off. If you’re hiking solo, make some noise!

Half mile in, I realized I was following BIG bear tracks didn’t realize at first that that’s what they were..Hiking alone I really didn’t wanna be confronted by bear so unfortunately one out of my Triple Crown I will not be completing..did Do Dragon’s tooth and McAfee knob., which were amazing￼
It's the cliiiiiiiimb, yeaah yeeaahh
Phone died halfway but trail was great and as described by others.
Very peaceful and challenging hike. Great views at the top!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Buzzard Hill via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Buzzard Hill via Appalachian Trail is a 3.4 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Bluemont, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, camping, and nature trips and is best used from July until December. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Great hike along part of the Apalachian Trail to the summit of Buzzard Hill.

Along the way you'll experience a stream crossing, 2 ridge climbs, a very unique water fall with lots of interesting features, and the ruins of a cabin.

The hike is loaded with 3 possible campsites, 1 equipped with a fire circle.

The chance to view wild flowers, and water fauna are ever present in this hike.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
Bring bug spray.

Bring plenty of water for the 2 strenuous sections and hiking poles or stick for the rocks and stream crossing

There are lots of through hikers on the AT on this hike, so you may not find that much solitude present.
reviews: Nice short hike to the falls; about 1.5 miles out. It was easy enough for our 5 year old to manage, but there is some up and down. It is well marked, but once you get to the creek where the big bolder is there are two paths. Facing the bolder the waterfall is to the right, and the left continues the Appalachian trail.
My civic couldn't get up the road to the parking lot so I can't actually rate the trail.  Make sure you have 4wheel drive if you're going to head out there!
Didn’t get a chance to get out and back before the storms rolled in. Well defined trail though, enjoyed what we saw. As others mentioned be ready for a challenging drive to the trail head.
great out and back when you're short on time. maintained trail but watch out for ticks still. view is ok. left my foldable dog water bowl at the summit so nice souvenir for someone else!
Great trail. Love the waterfall. Nice cold water for a nice break. Will have to come back in the fall or spring for a better view.
Nice trial with a water fall and creek with some cool flowing H2O.  The view is somewhat obscured this time of year but I bet the view in late fall and winter is great.

This was a fun, easy to moderate trail that gives you a taste of the Appalachian Trail in Virginia (and you’ll likely meet some AT thru hikers along the way). Take note of the 1,000 mile marker on the path. The waterfall is not huge, but a nice spot. Look for the waterfall trail on the right side after crossing the stream. Fun rock scramble at the peak of the trail. 4-stars vs. 5 because the view at the top is largely obstructed, a very enjoyable hike. Also looks to be a fun 5K or so trail run for intermediate trail runners. Note: the drive to the trail is better for 4x4, but manageable without 4x4 (if you’re confident in your brakes)
Some fellow hikers pointed out a rattle snake sunbathing on the rocks around the summit off trail. Definitely a memorable hike!
Great little hike, lots of wild berries and paw paws along the way.
Early rise hike take a light.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: First Battle of Manassas Trail Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: First Battle of Manassas Trail Loop  is a 5.2 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Manassas Park, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and running and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
First Battle of Bull Run.

This was the first major land battle of the armies in Virginia.  On July 16, 1861, the untried Union army under Brig. Gen. Irvin McDowell marched from Washington against the Confederate army, which was drawn up behind Bull Run beyond Centreville. On the 21st, McDowell crossed at Sudley Ford and attacked the Confederate left flank on Matthews Hill. Fighting raged throughout the day as Confederate forces were driven back to Henry Hill. Late in the afternoon, Confederate reinforcements (one brigade arriving by rail from the Shenandoah Valley) extended and broke the Union right flank. The Federal retreat rapidly deteriorated into a rout. Although victorious, Confederate forces were too disorganized to pursue. Confederate Gen. Bee and Col. Bartow were killed. Thomas J. Jackson earned the nom de guerre "Stonewall." By July 22, the shattered Union army reached the safety of Washington. This battle convinced the Lincoln administration that the war would be a long and costly affair. McDowell was relieved of command of the Union army and replaced by Maj. Gen. George B. McClellan, who set about reorganizing and training the troops.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
Some trail intersections are not clearly marked. Make sure to bring a trail map with you. 

Bring plenty of water and snacks.
reviews: Awesome
Very nice - nature view history river bridge rabbits deer spiders took shorter loop off the beaten track
Nice trail. Lots of history. It was a hot day in July as it was when the first battle took place. Hard to imagine all the young men fighting in uniforms in the summer.
In the summer, if you’re going to run. So hot. But great mix of train in the fields and forest
Always a beautiful walk.

Really nice hike thru the battlefield. Bring plenty of water, at least half the hike is in full sun. We followed the trail and added the Carter Cemetery spur and a little walking around the Stone Bridge and came in at 6 miles.  Love the interpretive signs throughout explaining what happened and when.
Awesome

Interesting trail with lots of history.  Trail was maintained really well.  The terrain varied from open/rolling fields to shaded woods.

I suggest wearing thick/sturdy sole shoes or boots.  Several areas were paved with sharp gravel stones.
Awesome......   restoration projects being conducted......  great work park service!!!
Wonderful got in just before the rain set in met some nice people who were a lil lost. Saw a few butterfly’s. Very nice views

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Upper Hawksbill Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Upper Hawksbill Trail is a 2.1 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that offers the chance to see wildlife and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and running and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

The Upper Hawksbill Trail is the easiest route to the summit of Hawksbill, which is the tallest mountain in Shenandoah National Park. 

From the parking lot, begin hiking from the Upper Hawksbill Trailhead. This trail has blue blazes.  The lower portion of the trail is very wide and well maintained and follows a gradual slope that makes for relatively easy hiking.  The trail is heavily wooded, so no views are available, but wildlife sightings are possible.

About three-fourths of the way up, the trail levels off and turns northwest for a few hundred yards.  The trail actually goes slightly downhill before intersecting the Hawksbill fire road.  Turn right on fire road, which heads northeast to the summit.

The park fire road is steeper and rockier than the rest of the trail, so the hiking is more difficult.  The first sign that you have reached the summit is a Byrd's Nest shelter.  From the Byrd's nest, follow the signs to the summit, which has a stone observation platform.

The views from the summit are well worth the hike, and include commanding views of Betty's Rock to the northeast, Old Rag Mountain to the east, and the Shenandoah Valley to the west.  One could easily spend thirty to sixty minutes at the summit, so allow time to enjoy the view.  To return to the parking lot, retrace your steps.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Enter Shenandoah National Park at the Thornton Gap entrance from U.S. 211.  Turn right on Skyline drive, and follow Skyline Drive to the Upper Hawksbill parking area, which is about 3/4 mile past Mile Post 46.
reviews: Beautiful lookout at the summit however it was VERY buggy! It is a well maintained trail and pretty family friendly, although it wasn’t too crowded.
Lots of bugs but super pretty
30 min hike. Great view. Easy and suitable for all ages.
Very nice and can be great if you go at a fast speed. Excellent view on the top.
A short steep hike to a good view. Was easy to see the rain coming in! Thank goodness there is a picnic shelter at the top.￼￼
Nice, relatively easy trail with some elevation towards the summit. The view is spectacular, but it is a busy spot.
Pretty simple hike. View at summit  is stunning
Great short hike to a gorgeous viewpoint
Short,sweet and steep.  Great for dogs.  Wonderful views from the top.

Fun, didn’t do hawksbill, worked out way down to rose river falls, absolutely stunning, no high vantage point views but the the water falls are gorgeous and provide little pools of water for cooling off along the way. Some of the connecting trail is a bit overgrown. Watch out for wildlife, bears are common.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Riprap Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Riprap Trail  is a 9.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Crimora, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This hike takes you along a beautiful covered forest and over several stream crossings. There are scenic views of the valley along the way.
reviews: Great day on Riprap and Wildcat. We went counter clockwise starting from Riprap parking lot to try to get a bit more of a sweat on the way back up. Enjoyed the water and rock features. Not a lot of people out on a Sunday morning. Only saw one group of hikers and a camper. I would say this is rated as hard because of the distance (we came in right at 9.3) because there is no steep terrain. Even going CC it was pretty gradual heading up. Would definitely recommend this hike.

This trail is NOT hard. The incline is gradual and with enough flater portions to break it up. The AT section is flat, narrow and enclosed, close to the road, and boring. I would definitely do this again but as Wildcat to the Calvary Rocks section of Riprap and back.
Awesome
Pretty good trail

Lovely trail! Started at wildcat at 92.1 and went clockwise. Got all of the elevation down then up done in the beginning that way, and then had easier flat/rolling Appalachian trail at the end when I was tired. There’s a BEAUTIFUL swimming hole that was a few miles in; I wish it were toward the end of my hike when I was hot but it was with trading to not have a long uphill at the end. I’d call the difficulty moderate—nothing technically challenging. Just long. Lovely!
Great trail! Not too many views. Went CCW and backpacked. Took about 5 and a half hours over 2 days with 30 LB packs. Definitely 10 miles, not 9 as AllTrails says. Moderate to strenous!

Overall a lovely hike! I’d definitely recommend going clockwise so that you can get the intense incline over with and enjoy the rest of the walk!

The reason I’m not giving 5 stars is because there were fewer lookout points that I was expecting, we passed maybe 3 in total all around the mid-way point. The trail was also pretty overgrown in points, so definitely best to wear long pants!
great trail few bugs, posted for bear activity some some scattered at the beginning but nothing more. water levels are way down.

A good hike, if you want to do the hike as it looks here go to the wildcat trail head. The Riprap Trailhead is a little further north on skyline. With hindsight I would go clockwise from wildcat so that you go by the stream and small waterfall. makes for a more pleasant incline hike to the overlook which is well worth it. Keep an eye out though as I had a close call with a copperhead on the trail.

I did this loop CCW today. Chimney Rock has great views, then you will come to an amazing waterfall section and a little swimming hole that is magical looking! So many great flowers in bloom. This really is one of the top hikes in SNP in my opinion.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: The Great Channels via Brumley Mountain Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: The Great Channels via Brumley Mountain Trail is a 6 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Cedar Bluff, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Incredibly scenic hike along Clinch Mountain from Hayter's Gap to Middle Knob along the 14-mile Brumley Mountain Trail, one of the East's newest long hiking trails. Although the Brumley Mountain Trail runs all the way from  Hayter's Gap to Hidden Valley Lake off of US-19 in Moccasin Gap, this guide features the trail's most heavily used, easternmost 3 miles that travel to the Great Channels of Virginia. 

The Channels are a series of deep sandstone crevices worn into sandstone outcrops on the mountain's summit and form one of Virginia's most fascinating ecosystems. It is possible to easily walk within the maze-like channels, which harbor an almost cave-like microclimate and often hold snow cover long after temperatures have risen above freezing. Coupled with outstanding views from the top of these outcrops and a firetower on Middle Knob's summit, this hike forms one of southwest Virginia's most scenic and popular hiking destinations.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips: Parking is limited in Hayter's Gap and is located at a small gravel pullout at the gated entrance to Raven Ridge Road. The first portion of this hike travels alongside private property - please respect landowners and stay on the trail.
reviews: The trail is borderline Hard and moderate due to the altitude. Beginner hikes may find it hard. Trail is well kept and the channels are great.
Great! Very well marked, every turn was clearly labeled. The slots were amazing and long!
loved the trail

Definitely up hill all the way up, that's a tough climb, but worth it! I loved wandering all around in the Channels, nice and quiet at 7 am start time on a Thursday! Sandstone & dirt parts of the trail were slick & muddy from rain the night before, so be careful but have fun!!!
Really good

Nice gradual incline once you hit the trail after walking up the gravel road. Trail itself is ok, the cool part is at the very end with the rock channels. Keep an eye out for snakes once you are there! Encountered a rattlesnake on one of the rocks. Lots of bugs, gnats and bees.

A steady incline over 3 miles gets you to the fire tower and entrance to the Channels. It’s a gravel road for the first half of the climb but the scenery is nice with a diverse forest on both sides. The Channels are great fun to explore. After checking out the Channels, I made a loop by continuing towards the Channels Trail and Clinch mountain rd, but unless you’re looking for miles I wouldn’t recommend following my route; it was overgrown throughout and not especially scenic.

I loved the Channels and the view of the mountains. I always think the moderate hikes are challenging for me. This hike was steep but had a nice shade the entire time. Get there early. There was only one parking place left when we arrived at 9 o’clock.
Steep trail, but not too bad. Definitely worth it in the end when you get to the channels. Feels like you are in another time and place.
Great hike, a bit challenging but the channels are otherworldly

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Turkey Run and Potomac Heritage Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Turkey Run and Potomac Heritage Trail is a 3.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near McLean, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and bird watching and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Users report that the directions to this trailhead can be misleading. After exit 43, and once on GW parkway, take the first exit once you see Turkey Run Park sign. 

This trail can get very washed out after significant rainfall and flooding. Dogs are allowed on this trail however users report that it may be difficult for them due to scrambles and creek crossing.

Great river views plus stream, falls and woods

The trail starts in the C1 parking area and heads down to the Potomac River.  The markers are yellow until you reach the river where you follow blue markers of the Potomac Heritage trail to the northwest along the river.  You cross over Turkey Run and continue to Dead Run.  Cross over Dead Run and go up stream, following the yellow markers again.  Just after passing under the GW parkway bridge, turn left, cross the run and follow the yellow markers southeast until you reach Turkey Run again.  Turn left and at the bridge cross over the run and follow the yellow trail up the hill and back to the parking lot.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Trail starts at the C1 parking lot in Turkey Run park on the George Washington Parkway, about 1.5 miles southeast of the DC beltway.
reviews:
This is a good trail to test new footwear out on; in ~4 miles, you have dirt trails, tree roots, stream crossings, large rocks, light scrambling, steep dirt sections, and depending on the weather, mud. For the same reasons, I would only recommend this trail if you own hiking boots/shoes.

I would recommend doing the trail in the direction suggested in All Trails. After crossing the first stream, take a right and follow the blue blazes. When you get to the large river, maneuver across it and follow the yellow blazes UP the river. This is the best section of the trail, so take time to enjoy it. Then you will continue to follow the yellow blazes until you reach that first stream crossing and can retrace your steps back to your car.

On the yellow blazed trail, you will encounter a ditch that requires a rope to maneuver down and across. It is not as difficult as it looks, but make no mistake that this section is very intimidating/challenging since this is not something hikers typically encounter (climbers should have no problem with this). I was lucky enough to have met up with an AMAZING group of people who helped me across the ditch, and I am very appreciative of their help. Because of this obstacle, this won't be a good loop for children or dogs, and it may be a good idea to do this hike with another person who can help you with your footing. 

Aside from that main obstacle, this is an easy-moderate trail for a quick but fun hike.

This is a fun trail and I can hardly believe it's this close to DC! Most of the trail is pretty easy but there are two sections that are more technical and I would consider moderate. Though, if you're not used to rock scrambling, this can be difficult and you have to be very careful.
It’s moderate trail, signs are not visible around the river and too rocky. It’s near the highway and too noisy.
Very rocky and overgrown along the Potomac River, plus lots of poison ivy. Other hand, we saw butterflies!￼
Amazing Hike.. It’s all worth it.. Watch out for the slippery slopes and rocks

This was a wonderful hike! At times it was difficult due to me having to climb over large rocks. I had slipped a couple times due to it rained a few days proper. You have to be extra careful even if it’s dry.
not the most dog friendly except water areas. water and rocks beautiful! current strong.
Great trail, good rock scrambles and water views

My son (12) and I are new to hiking.  This trail was beautiful, but it was *so* much more challenging than other trails rated “moderate”!  Some confusing navigation, plus rocky creek areas where we slipped and fell numerous times.  I’ll do this one again, but my son was spooked and is unlikely to join me.

AllTrails directions to parking are incorrect. It takes to US police HQ. After exit 43, once on GW parkway, take the first exit once you see Turkey Run Park sign. 
Trail was shaded, but very hot,humid. Turkey Run trail markings (yellow) are pretty confusing to follow. Once you are past the first stream crossing, small waterfall, search for markings on rock.. that section has bit of rocks to be scrambled. few downed trees that you need to jump on to pass. One section througha pit, has wooden plank that needs to be crossed with rope hanging overhead for support.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Buzzard Rock
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Buzzard Rock is a 3.8 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Front Royal, Virginia that features a great forest setting and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Nice panoramic view. Hiking boots or shoes with ankle support recommended as the second half of the trail is rocky. 

Get there early as possible. Parking space is limited. Don't park on the side of the road (on grass) or along private property. Your car will get either towed or ticketed. Another option is to start your trail from Signal Knob Trailhead since parking is limited at the Buzzard Rock Trailhead.
reviews: pretty easy minus the final ascent. we hiked it with a eight and three year old.

Great nice little hike! We arrived early and had great parking. The trail is very well taken care of - the path is easy to follow, very wide for the most part, and easy sailing. Sprinkled with a few scattered rocks every now and then. Most of the climb is toward the end, from about mile 1.5 to 1.7. At 1.7, you get a great wide open view of the valley. If you want to keep going for another .5 miles, you’ll follow the ridge line and get amazing views looking straight down the mountain. Definitely recommend!
The trail is really fun. Lots of rock scrambles as you get higher and incredible views.
Rocky and pretty steep. Enjoyable hike with plenty of places to take in nature.
Good moderate hike.  Great views
You want to start at signal knob trail parking lot. Organe I
Nice trail.  It was rocky!  The views were great tiday
Really nice trail. Great views along the top. The section between the two lookouts is a bit aggressive but aside from that it's smooth sailing.

It's a nice trail, the view at the top is really pretty, HOWEVER, I think it's too much effort for the prize you get. I hiked carrying my 18lbs baby in a 95F degree day, so also keep that in mind... 
Trail begins with an easy path some uphills and downhills, then gets rocky but not too difficult.  After you get to the first overlook, then things really pick up, Rocky uphill all the way up (get those calves ready lol).
I couldn't actually go to the Buzzard Rock itself, carrying the baby it seemed very dangerous to get too adventurous.
Definitely needs to be better marked, closer to the outlooks as it can be confusing. Great hike otherwise, mainly shady for sunny days.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Blackrock Summit via Trayfoot Mountain and Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Blackrock Summit via Trayfoot Mountain and Appalachian Trail is a 1.1 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Grottoes, Virginia that offers the chance to see wildlife and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking and bird watching and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This short hike leads to the summit of Blackrock featuring amazing views of Shenandoah Valley and Massanutten Mountain.
reviews: Nice short and scenic hike for a family
Short and easy hike, very well marked. Some great views open up midway.
Nice easy hike and very satisfying views. some rocks to climb on too!
Nice views, clear easy path with slight hill part of the way.
One of my favorite hikes and one of the easiest. Slight constant elevation gain but nothing hard at all. You HAVE to scramble to the top of the rocks it’s amazing.
great trail for kids
Great trail took our 3 kids (ages 5 & 3x2) and my parents.
Ignore my splits on here, I accidentally clicked into the wrong trail when I recorded.
Manicured trail, beautiful view at summit
short, well marked, easy

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Burke Lake Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Burke Lake Trail is a 4.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Burke, Virginia that features a lake and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Nice flat loop around lovely Burke Lake. This is a mixed use trail for walkers, hikers, runners and bicyclists. The trail runs from concrete to gravel to dirt and is well maintained. Dogs are not permitted in the lake.

Accessibility: There are at least 6 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Ox Road at the southwest end of the trail marked with waypoint #2. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement or gravel and dirt and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) uphill and downhill sections from about 4.3 through 4.8 miles when going clockwise from the start. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the moderately steep sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved sections.  There are benches along the route for resting.
reviews: Great
Super easy and very crowded
easy with fishing spots
Easy, flat trail. Used to come to this park as a kid!  Tends to get a bit busy with all kinds of folks either walking or biking. Very dog friendly as well.
It's a cute trail if you're staying at the campground or if you're looking for just a long walk. After the pavement ends, the trail is still all gravel.
Tranquil and peaceful, very shaded. loved the nature all around
Great walk, flat trail, hardly no one on weekdays
Nice flat trail￼
It was beautiful and humid. My drawers are now sauce.
Peaceful

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Lake Accotink Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Lake Accotink Trail is a 3.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Springfield, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Lake Accotink features many activities for the whole family including: pedalboat rentals, an antique carousel, mini-golf, picnic areas, and a lake boat tour.

Accessibility: The trail surface is a combination of boardwalk, pavement, and dirt. The first 1.8 miles of this trail is mostly gentle with a grade less than 5% and is typically over three feet wide. The northeastern section of the park is the most accessible - paved and the levelest surface. Beyond these two miles, the grade gets steep, with an estimated max grade of 10%. Where the grade increases has been marked on the map with a waypoint. Just the accessible portion of this trail can also be viewed on its own trail page here:
reviews: Busy with bikes but pretty balanced.
A little crowded close to the marina.

It was nice! Pretty busy and some bikers had no regard for the foot traffic. Saw some people almost get mowed down because the guy was going so fast. Other than that everyone was friendly and the trail was nice. Trash cans were available just when you needed them.
Very easy

Great trail for a stroller ride- partially paved. Did have to go out into a neighborhood briefly to link up with the other half of the trail. At the end- or beginning if you go counterclockwise is a nice park for kids and some picnic tables and cover
Crowded, had to run through a small brook so prepare to get your feet wet if it just rained. Overall nice outdoor run away from the urban environment. Shaded and cool.
Very good
Easy walk around the lake. Shade for most of it so the heat & sun was tolerable.
Very easy hike. Nice and well shaded. Be alert for lots of bikers, runners and other hikers.
Loved the trail.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Humpback Rocks Loop Via the Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Humpback Rocks Loop Via the Appalachian Trail is a 3.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Nellysford, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, and bird watching and is best used from April until September. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
SEASONAL ROAD CLOSURE: Blue Ridge Parkway is subject to seasonal closure. For more information, please visit https://www.nps.gov/blri/planyourvisit/roadclosures.htm. When Blue Ridge Parkway is closed, you can park on Howardsville Turnpike and walk about 1.2 miles on the Parkway to the trail. 

Beautiful hike with stunning foliage, wide path and amazing views! This loop can be done in both directions, if done counter-clockwise you get the climb done in the first.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: From Interstate 64 you want to take the Blue Ridge Parkway south until you see the entrance to the Humpback Rocks parking lot on your left. The parking lot will be on your right if you are coming north.
reviews: black bear bluff charged on the switch backs. bear was 30 yards away and charged in 10ft or so.

A great hike to a spectacular view. However, we did see a bear close-up just after the top, on the way to the Appalachian Trail intersection, and then about a third of the way down the switchbacks we encountered a large timber rattlesnake on the trail. Talk about a rock and a hard place! The snake announced (thankfully!) that it meant business, so we accepted its invitation to take our chances with the bear, which we did not see again in retracing our steps.
Great Hike! We passed by a black bear on the way back but it was all good
Saw two bears. Taking the long way to the viewpoint was definitely easier.
Excellent view

Amazing view at the top. I recommend getting the incline over with so do the short trail up then wind back down using the switchbacks. Didn’t bring the dog on this one as I wanted to climb around on the rocks but he would have been fine
Beautiful views from the top & a fairly easy trail, not too steep

Beautiful hike! My husband did it with our 25 lb toddler on his back which made it a bit difficult for him but he managed! Totally worth the view and our dog also loved the hike! The drive from wintergreen resort was very easy, lots of parking and well marked trail. We will be back!
The Mile up to the Rocks is steep but totally worth it. Went midday on Friday and it was quite crowded. Took AT back to parking lot and much fewer people.
Great hike clockwise. Got to go up the switchbacks. Fantastic views.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Mount Rogers via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Mount Rogers via Appalachian Trail is a 10.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Troutdale, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, horses, and backpacking and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
$7 entrance fee ($10 on weekends Apr-Oct). State Park is open Year round. Also, off line map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked and confusing to get around. 

Take the Appalachian trail to Wilburn Ridge, Pine Mountain and Mount Roger, the highest point in Virginia. Plenty of camp spots and a shelter are located along the AT making this a great place for an overnight.

Day use parking is along the road at Massie Gap with overflow at the Visitor Center. Overnight parking is now limited to the Overnight Backpackers Lot and reservations are required. Backcountry camping is not allowed within the state park boundaries, so you must hike onto USFS property before setting up. 

Check the park’s webpage for the most up to date information on reservations, trail status, fees, and requirements at .
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips: Keep an eye out for wild ponies! and manure on the ground.  Easy to follow trail but make sure you have a paper map or offline maps downloaded.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there:
829 Grayson Highland Lane
Mouth of Wilson, VA 24363
reviews: Not for the weak kneed. Lots of variety and wildly

Beautiful scenery, difficult but not impossible. Markings were excellent except to find the tiny medallion at the top. We hiked on Monday July 12 and the weather was perfect. We got to see the ponies, a cow maybe a chipmunk, and lots of birds. We loved it.
Incredible views

Extremely well maintained trail with a wealth of incredible campsites. The trails were rocky, so boots would be preferred. There were several small springs to fill up on the way. 

The views were incredible, though Mt Rodgers was very woody. That being said, due to the moisture at the summit, everything was coated in moss. It really felt like an enchanted forest. 

We spent the night on Pine Mountain which had a great view of the sunrise. Some ponies graced us with their presence in the morning. 

It was a magical trip. Would recommend.
Most amazing hike I’ve ever experienced. Lightly lightly trafficked. Beautiful, peaceful, wildlife, perfect sights everywhere you look. Birds are loud and singing proud - paradise!

Good hike. Beautiful scenery all the way, with the added attraction of the resident ponies and longhorn cattle. Between the elevation gain and the rock climbing, it was as challenging a hike as I’ve ever taken on the AT. The rain forest at the MR summit was something I didn’t expect.
Cool hike

A fun time! Got to see a lot of wild ponies! A few things: a decent amount of loose rocks on the trail, wear and bring sunscreen (there's little/no shade for almost all of the trail, and while it's not super hot, the sun is very bright), and bring an offline/paper map (there are blazes to follow the AT, but it can get a bit confusing if you don't see those blazes for a little while).

This might be my favorite hike in the Appalachians so far. Saw at least 5 separate groups of wild ponies and cows. Amazing views right from the start. The final summit (mt Rogers) had no lookout point, but it’s the part of the hike with the best enchanted forest vibes. Lots of backcountry campsites all throughout the trail once you’re on the AT. Download your map, some places are difficult to follow the trail markers, and there are lots of splits, but it’s pretty easy to get back on the main trail if you take a wrong turn so long as you’ve been recording the map.
The Wild Horses are so cool!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Lace Falls via Cedar Creek Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Lace Falls via Cedar Creek Trail is a 2 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Natural Bridge, Virginia that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and nature trips. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
The Cedar Creek Trail begins with the walk down Cascade Creek and ends about a mile later at Lace Falls. Natural Bridge is included in the Virginia Birding and Wildlife Trails Peaks of Otter Loop.

Admission Fee:
Ages 6-12: $6
13+: $8

Users have reported there are many stairs at the beginning and end where equipment would need to be carried so it is not marked as wheelchair or stroller friendly.
reviews: Be sure to check out Skyline Trail while at the park too - really pretty meadow trail with flowers, wildlife, and insane mountain views
Nice easy walk along with a well groomed trail. Plenty nice site along the way. However, in the afternoon super crowed, best to go in the am.
Did this one back in 2011. Short stroll with the family. Easy, the kids had no problems.
Incredible!  Well maintained park trail with spectacular views along the entire hike. Also wheelchair accessible under the bridge and all the way to the falls!
Natural bridge is enormous and beautiful.  Went early 8am when they open up and nobody there for most of our hike.
Challenging with a lot of stream crossing and a deep gully.
The bridge was impressive but you couldn't get very close to the waterfall. Everything was walled off so it wasn't much of an adventure. For $9 a head it wasn't worth it.
This place is a state treasure.
Easy trail mostly along Cedar Creek and relatively cool on a blistering hot day
Short easy hike. Great for a quick stroll. The bridge is right at the beginning. The falls are nice but nothing spectacular. I'd come back again.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Devil's Marbleyard via Belfast Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Devil's Marbleyard via Belfast Trail is a 4.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Natural Bridge Station, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Follow 501 North to the Blue Ridge Parkway. From there take a left onto the park way and follow it for about 7 miles then make a right onto Petites Gap rd. (Petites Gap rd. is a single lane dirt/gravel road on the side of a mountain. Be very careful on your way there and back.) The trail head is about 2.7 miles on your right.
reviews: It’s great hike, lot of physical workout! But when you pass the large boulders it’s not obvious how to proceed further. Trail is not well marked at that point.

Be ready for the uphill walk! The trail itself is well cared for and clear.  Definitely a workout! We only hiked to the Marbleyard. The views and the boulders and rocks to climb were awesome. My teenaged boys loved it! We did bring our dog, a 10 month old Golden Retriever,  but we had to take turns on the rocks because it was a bit much for a dog to navigate. Next time we’ll leave the dog at home. There was a loose hood dog up there and she wouldn’t even attempt the marbleyard. She stuck to the creek walk and went down the mountain with us.

This is pretty close to Natural Bridge so the trails can be busy. The parking lot is tiny but parking just off the road on the parking lot side is fine. You won't have cell signal until you make it onto the boulder field. The hike to the base is easy going. Once you arrive at the bottom there are two routes. The boulder field is NOT PART OF THE RED OUTLINED TRAIL. Look at the trail map on here, that grey line branching off is the boulder field.

Go up the boulder field or go beside it. I have done both. THE BOULDER FIELD SECTION IS IN MY TOP 5.

TAKING THE TRAIL AROUND:

This trail continues beside the marble yard then turns right, away from the boulder field to go to a peak of sorts. You can follow a trail directly beside the boulder field to the top, BUT THE TRAIL IS ROUGH. The rocks are loose, the grade is steep and there is vegetation (Oak, Ivy etc). There is also no marking on this section, if you look left you clearly see the boulder field 10-15 ft away, so it does not need to be marked. Basically you are making your own trail directly beside the boulder field to make it to the top. Honestly it sucked... Just take the boulders up.

CLIMBING THE BOULDER FIELD:

This is why you are here right? Cool. Now understand when you are at the base, the tree line, there are a total of three of what you see in front of you. It's ok, you've got this! The top of what you see is only the beginning. The rocks are large and there are endless ways to climb up. It seems miserable at first mostly from the heat of there being no shade. Take your time and don't rush it, grab edges and rough sections of the rocks for grip and better friction. Edges of rocks give better friction to your shoes, the smooth areas can be slick depending on your soles. If the way in front of you looks impossible then change directions, there are endless ways up. A few boulders slightly shifted on me but that was toward the top left. You are going to see hundreds of spiders. It's ok, they don't like you either so they scurry off into the depths of the rocks. Toward the upper left is a cool valley feature and slightly before that is the entrance to a opening in the rocks below. I climbed in a few feet, felt some shifting rocks and saw plenty of spiders. So I assume that is where the devil lives. I would not recommend climbing in, it's big enough for a normal sized person to squeeze in but all of the surrounding rock is loose. 

TIP: If you don't know your way around the area put your destination in before your hike down, while on the boulder field. It will deplete your battery but there isn't any semblance of cell signal at the trail head.
trail next to the devil's marble yard is brutal if you take it to the top
Very fun, but super hot with little shade on the rocks. Lots of spiders.
good hike. worth the rock scramble at the top!
Awesome trail! Lot’s of rocks to scramble, great views at the top, take plenty of water and snacks

One of my new favorite hikes/scramble! Challenging a with rewarding views! 

The trail is relatively easy up until the scramble. You have the option to “choose your own adventure” and climb up the rocks or there is a steep path along the side. There is no paint marking a path up the rocks, so you do pick your own path and may have to back track sometimes. Only encountered two loose rocks. I personally loved the scramble and the challenge it imposed. Even though the hike is shorter, I would actually say the scramble is harder than Old Rag for comparison. Lots of quad and upper body strength (especially if you are short like me!) needed. We scrambled up the rocks than came down the path (which is towards the right side when heading up). 

Lots of big black spiders, but they were harmless and scurry away if you stepped on their rock. Saw a couple lizards and turtle, and thankfully no snakes.

Only Con: Parking lot is small and you might have to park along some dirt along the road.
The marble yard at the top was amazing- by far one of our favorite hikes.
Was tough and fun! Did it with my dog so we did the trail up the right rather than scrambling for most of it. Beautiful!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Virginia's Triple Crown Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Virginia's Triple Crown Loop is a 37.1 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near Salem, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from May until September. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
The Virginia Triple Crown is comprised of what many consider to be the state’s three best hiking destinations: McAfee Knob, Tinker Cliffs and Dragon’s Tooth. All are conveniently located within a few miles of each other just outside of Roanoke.  McAfee Knob affords a 270-degree view of the Catawba Valley far below and has been called the most photographed spot along the Appalachian Trail. Just a few miles north on the AT is Tinker Cliffs, another prominent outcropping of rock offering a view of the same valley and distant mountain ranges.  A few miles southwest just inside the boundaries of Jefferson National Forest resides Dragon’s Tooth, a unique geologic feature consisting of spires projecting up to 35 feet from the surrounding rock.

Any of these is a worthy destination for a challenging day hike. You might be able to hit 2 of 3 on an extended day hike, but taking in all three requires an overnight stay.  The more common routes are either shuttle hikes or require lots of backtracking. This is a 3-day, 35-mile loop that circumnavigates the entire valley, hits all three viewpoints, and minimizes backtracking.  In this route, you’ll hike the AT for several miles, camp at an AT shelter, cross the valley, return on the western side of the valley via the North Mountain ridge, cross the valley again, and rejoin the AT to return to your car at the Catawba Mountain parking area on Route 311.  As designed, this 35-mile loop is broken roughly into thirds. There are several parking areas, shelters and backcountry camping spots along the way, so you could divvy it up differently to suit your needs. 

This trek is not recommended for beginners as this route involves lots of climbing, rock scrambles, blustery ridges and a whole day without water sources (you’ll have to carry lots of water up North Mountain for Day 2).  

Please leave no trace and be mindful of trash. This trail sees a large number of traffic and has been having problems with rising trash, illegal camping and misuse of the area. The Roanoke Appalachian Trail Club maintains this section of trail and volunteers regularly pack out trash and maintain campsites to keep it beautiful.

Park rules and regulations are enforced:
Maximum group size, day hikes: 25
Maximum group size, backpacking/camping: 10
No alcohol
Dogs must be kept on leash at all times
No camping or campfires outside of 7 designated areas ( north of Va 624/Newport Rd, the only legal campsites are Johns Spring Shelter, Catawba Shelter and campsites, Pig Farm campsite, Campbell Shelter and Lambert’s Meadow Shelter and campsites)
No camping or campfires on McAfee Knob or Tinker Cliffs
reviews: It’s very strenuous but the views are spectacular it’s wild worthy

A gorgeous, must-do backpacking loop! All the crowns were gorgeous, as others have mentioned the North Mountain Trail was unpleasant to say the least. I did this in 3.25 days with the following itinerary:

Day 1 (2.2 miles): parked at MacAfee Knob and hiked 2.2 miles to Catawba shelter where I stayed for the night

Day 2 (10ish miles): hiked to MacAfee Knob and Tinker Cliffs, stayed at Lambert’s meadow shelter

Day 3 (17ish miles): Andy Layne trail to Catawba river trail to North mountain trail, stayed at Boy Scouts campsites 

Day 4 (12ish miles): AT to dragons tooth (stashed my pack at a campsite before the intersection), AT to parking lot 

Overall this was a good breakdown, but the north mountain trail day was killer. It would’ve been nice to break that into two days, but the lack of water on the ridge was a constraint. I’d definitely recommend this loop!

North mountain is no fun, 13 miles on an overgrown ridgeline with no water or good views. I used little side trail markers to break it up mentally but there was no good views orr waypoints to strive for. If you do it clockwise, you get to see the whole ridgeline of north mountain that you just hiked at tinker cliffs and McAfee's knob which is pretty cool.

the triple crown is beautiful (5stars), but If I had to do it again, I would just go out and back and avoid north mountain (1star).
what would have made my experience better (in the summer): 4 days instead of 3, packing 3L instead of 2.4L for catawba/north mountain trails, hammocking (lighter, easy to find a spot to sleep), not overpacking (I wouldn't bring jacket/poncho/jetboil/sleeping bag/extra clothes/food that needs water to cook (just eating granolas, crackers, nuts/nut butter instead)
do bring: ibuprofen/bug spray/water/trekking poles (save your knees/ankles

animals I have seen on trail: bear, deer, rattlesnake, turtles...

PS: catawba grocery is maybe 0.1 miles from dragon's tooth parking lot and it has some supplies for hikers and good food!
PS2: you don't need your phone to navigate, the trails are well marked and easy to follow, save your battery instead and avoid bringing lots of extra batteries

Hike was 5*.
The Alltrails water source info was not.  There appears to be a drought this year, and the only water sources were on Catawba Valley Trail (mile 11.8), Campbell Shelter (mile 21), and along routes 785 and 624 (miles 30-32). 
Be careful out there in Summer--it's hot!
I didn’t intend to do this in 2 days, but it ended up working out. Try it out, you might like it!

Beautiful. I just love this area of Virginia. We made this a 5 day trek, and here’s how. Parked at the Dragon’s Tooth trail head and started up North Mountain. There was no water on the mountain but there was a creek flowing where we made camp, about 10 miles in. Day 2 was short, about 4.5 miles or so, for some built in recovery slash chill time at The campsite just past Lambert’s Meadow on the AT. Day 3 we hit Tinker Cliffs and McAfee Knob, stopped for water at the Catawba shelter and kept going to John Spring shelter (no water). Day 4 hiked through a beautiful meadow and by several rivers and creeks which were nice for water and a dip. The waypoints did not indicate water at the Boy Scout camp, but THERE IS WATER there - so don’t camel up like we did if the Boy Scout camp is your goal. Day 5 we dropped our gear at the car and slack packed up the AT to Dragon’s Tooth and back down the Dragon’s Tooth trail to the car, For a final day of about 5.5 miles.

Splitting it up this way made it really enjoyable and pretty stress free in terms of mileage per day and elevation gain.
Wet, rainy and grueling

Rocky, steep and not much h20. Halfway 1: Started at Andy Lane, up to NM. Full Day 2: last 2 Miles of the NMT, Dragons tooth and finishing up at John Springs shelter. Full Day 3: JSS to McAfee, Tinker Cliffs and finishing up at Lambert Meadow shelter. Final half day: LMS down Andy Lane to the Vic.

My friend and I did the 31 mile loop, with the Boyscout’s trail shortcut near Dragon’s tooth. Did most of it in one day, then had to catch some sleep before doing the remainder the next morning. Some of the trail had a lot of small jagged rocks that weren’t too fun to walk on for a long distance, especially the northern part. Some great views. We saw a couple deer. I’m fairly fit, but I was extremely sore the next couple days.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Dark Hollow via Appalachian Trail and Story of the Forest Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Dark Hollow via Appalachian Trail and Story of the Forest Trail is a 5.9 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking and bird watching and is accessible year-round.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Two waterfalls and tons of wildlife. This circuit passes Rose River falls and the site of an old copper mine. Erosion has all but obliterated all traces of this mine. The circuit continues on past Dark Hollow Falls and offers view points from the Appalachian Trail as it circles the Big Meadows picnic and camping areas.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Drive to Big Meadows, just south of MP 51 on Skyline Drive.  Turn in and follow signs to Amphitheater parking area.  Trail begins behind amphitheater.
reviews: The part where trails runs along the creek is excellent. Multiple small pulls of water to dip in, scored of small cascades and waterfalls. Could have done without the whole side west of Skyline.

Lovely trail in a dark ravine with lush forest and stunning flowing water scenery. 
The waterfalls are magnificent. You can get right up next to them. Hopefully you don’t run into too many of those insta-wannabe-famous blocking your views.  

Jump into the water for a refreshing burst of cold. While most city slickers will abstain, I strongly recommend jumping in.

Loved this trail. 53 year old male, in pretty good shape. Agree with everyone who says take it clockwise. The descent is easier and less muddy/rocky/steep on that side and once you pick up the river it allows you to keep it on your right and enjoy the many pretty falls and pools on your way up on the ascent. The climb out is steep but not TOO bad. Really a great day.

Hike was awesome but didnt complete the Hawksbill section due to hiking with children that had struggled a little.  We ended up staying two nights in Big Meadows campground which was nice.  The waterfalls are incredible and well worth the trip.
A little bit muddy and slick in spots, but overall a pleasant hike.
Very nice and cool hike with nice side trails
Clockwise is definitely best! Less people. Good hike up while passing the falls near the end

Gorgeous loop! So many great falls (and swimming holes to return to in summer!). Not many others on the trail on an overcast Sunday, until we got to Dark Hollow. Definitely second everyone below and say do it clockwise!

Great trail. Going clockwise from the lodge early on a Saturday we saw no other hikers until we got to the Rose river section. As we made our way up the Hogcamp Branch and to the impressive falls, we started encountering other sizable groups.
Really fun trail. Some of the blazes are really fade so it’s easy to get turned around sometimes

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Three Ridges Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Three Ridges Trail is a 13.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Wintergreen Resort, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, bird watching, and backpacking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Situated in Central Virginia, just 30 miles southwest of Charlottesville, the hike has vista after vista along the Appalachian Trail, and many small waterfalls and pools on the Mau-Har Trail on Campbell Creek.
reviews: I was apprehensive about doing this solo in one day but I’m glad I did. I finished in 7.5 hours. My phone put me at just over 14 miles from the Reed Gap parking area. It was difficult, definitely challenging in some places, but the views were worth it.
Not for the faint of heart, but a beautiful hike and great swimming hole.

It was wonderful! My first time solo camping. I went clockwise and made it to the Harper’s Ferry Shelter. So beautiful! But holy heck - the number of millipedes there! Crawling over everything and falling from the trees! That was some Indiana Jones level s**t! Great waterfalls and swimming on the second day.

We only went to the three ridges wilderness which only supposed to be 4 miles based on AllTrails but it ends up being 6 miles. The incline is definitely hard especially if you try to camp over night and have a 30 lbs backpack.
We also found a snake in the campsite so we had to walk more to get to the next campsite which wasn’t that far but definitely challenging.
Fun!

Overall an awesome loop hike.  Hiked to looking glass several times but never did the whole loop.  I went counter clock wise from Reid’s gap as recommended.  I did this for the workout rather than views. I tried to treat this as a trail run/jog/hike.  Difficult to trail run because it is very rocky and some of the declines are steep but some sections are runable.  I started at 6am and finished the loop in just under 5 hours.  Bring a lot of water if do that.  I missed most of the views because of fog that early but there were a lot of swimming holes on the back end before getting back to the maupin shelter.  I only saw 4 people on the trail which was a bit surprising.  Highly recommend for a really long day hike or 2 day camping trip.  Lots of places to camp.

Really liked this hike. Clocked in closer to 15 mi from Reed's Gap parking. Clockwise, camping around Harper's Creek, as indicated on the elevation map here definitely seemed like the best way to go. Lots of water and swimming holes day 2-- wish I had remembered swimwear!
It’s actually 15 miles. The loop itself is roughly 13 but the path to the loop from reeds gap parking is 1.7. Beautiful views and a lot of ups and downs.

it's a challenge. it's 14 but my GPS didn't catch it all. The bugs be bugging. it can be hot, but cools down in the late afternoon. My only complaint is the views. Most of the trail is blocked by vegetation. Only some clearings for looking out. I would have rated higher if more vistas. Still worth it just to say you did it. It isn't easy.

Just did this hike as an overnighter, hiked CW and stayed at the Harpers Creek shelter. Water was pretty sparse on the AT side until we got to the shelter. Mau Har trail on day 2 is a killer climb out. Overall a great hike, great view from hanging rock and the waterfalls on the Mar Har are beautiful. One word of caution though, we saw two rattlesnakes directly next to trail, one just over the top and one about 1.5 miles from the car.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Ragged Mountain Natural Area Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Ragged Mountain Natural Area Trail is a 6.6 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Charlottesville, Virginia that features a lake and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, nature trips, and mountain biking and is accessible year-round.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This is a nice little series of trails for when the Parkway and Skyline Drive are closed or the mountain paths are too icy. No dogs allowed because of proximity to the reservoir.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
Very few markers. If you plan to do the full 7+ mile loop, be sure you have a fully charged smartphone. Most who wander the 5th mile will be lost. 

Cell reception can be tricky. Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.
reviews: Super nice. A little long if you don’t hike often, but if you are decently athletic and like variation in views and elevation, this is great for an afternoon adventure!
Awesome. Did part of the Lake Loop. Inclines for sure! Wished I lived around here bc I would be there often.
If you get out before the heat, it can be a great time.
Great!
Great hike! There are not a many people around even on a long weekend. It was great that the trees provided some shade along the way and we didn’t feel the heat in July.
Great hike. Lots of beautiful spots to stop and look at the reservoir. 95% of it is in the shade. No difficult parts to traverse but it was very long. Few bugs. Overall awesome hike.
awesome
Did a 6.8 mile loop. Some steep climbs out at the beginning. Beautiful forests and the lake is beautiful.  Loved this hike.
Amazing! Very few bugs, and not a lot of people.
Beautiful and green - Raspberries are everywhere right now. Great hike or bike ride.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/washi.name: Theodore Roosevelt Island
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/washi.overview: Theodore Roosevelt Island is a 1.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Fort Myer, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for walking and running and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/washi.description:
Wooded trail and boardwalk over swamp, tribute to the 26th President of the US.

The Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Association purchased this 88.5-acre island in 1932 and dedicated it to the public in memory of Roosevelt.  Frederick Law Olmstead, Jr., a leading landscape architect, worked with the Civilian Conservation Corps to bring a neglected island into a mature woodland sanctuary.  Architect Eric Gugler designed the memorial and Sculptor Paul Manship created the central statue.  The dedication ceremony took place in October 1967.

The island has a diverse history.  Evidence shows that Native Americans used the island as a seasonal fishing village.  The site was named "My Lord's Island," when King Charles granted it to Lord Baltimore.  

Today, the National Park Service protects the island, while providing for public enjoyment.  While you are here, savor the sounds of the outdoors as you travel through a marsh, swamp, and forest.

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of George Washington Memorial Parkway at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, wooden boardwalk, or natural surfaces (with railings along bridges), and typically at least 3 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.2, 0.5, 0.7, and 1.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/washi.getting_there: 395 N to exit 10C.  Follow George Washington Parkway pas the Pentagon, and exits for Key Bridge.  Parking for Theodore Roosevelt Island is on your left, and only accesible from the northbound side of the highway.
reviews: Nice trail for the whole family
Lovely, peaceful. Many of the trails have not been maintained during COVID and are not passable. The main gravel trail is fine.
Nice route, a little crowded but sufficiently shaded even for a summer morning.
Great early morning walk.
Easy street ride. Few cars and minimal hills.
Nice easy walk in the middle of the Potomac. During the fall/winter good views of the Kennedy Center and Georgetown.
Trailhead mixed but easy to walk.

Dont go on the outer most trail.  It is NOT maintained and is super muddy.  I fell and landed on an exposed tree trunk.  Got a deep laceration in my cheek.  Had to go to ER to get stitches.  I'm an avid hiker and this was my first experience like this.  They really need signs up regarding this.  Older people tried to go the way I went because it is a way go get to the bathroom and I told them to turn around that's how bad it was.
Nicely maintained, great morning walk, not busy during the week.
Nice run. Hot and humid, not along the shore if that's what you're looking for.  Interesting monument area.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Sand Cave and White Rocks Via Ewing Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Sand Cave and White Rocks Via Ewing Trail is a 8.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Ewing, Virginia that offers the chance to see wildlife and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, nature trips, and backpacking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
reviews: Great Hike loved the mileage the elevation change liked all of it!
Fantastic!!!!

Trail was strenuous at times but both views are beautiful and worth it! Took our two dogs and they handled the trail great. There was an active hornets nest that fell on the trail and stung our doggys and one of us. Otherwise, great trail!
Loved it! Can’t wait to come back!

I would argue for a hard rating over moderate. Consider: the ever popular Alum Cave to Leconte gains 2,900 feet if elevation in about 11 miles. That’s only about 600 feet more spaced out over an extra 2.5 miles-roughly calculated. Sand Cave and White Rocks is a steeper climb. Plan for a minimum of 2-3 hours to ascend for the average hiker. Heat will make it harder. 
Additionally, compared to trails in the GSMNP, this is not what I would consider “heavily” trafficked. 


That being said, it’s absolutely worth it. Both the cave and the overlook are amazing. Bring a filtration system as there is an excellent water source near the cave for a fill-up. I suggest kicking your boots off and enjoying the cool sand. It’s easier to navigate shifting sand barefoot AND the cool sand reinvigorated my tired, swollen feet. 

The climb to White Rocks is quite literally a scramble the last smidge. Again, it’s worth it. It’s only a few feet, but it’s over muddy rocks. 

You descend from the lollipop to Sand Cave. It’s steep. The ascent to get out is steep. The stairs are quad killers. But absolutely worth it.

I was there the last weekend of June, 2021, and there is a hornet nest very close to the trailhead. While they won’t bother you, you should keep your distance.
Overall a great hike! The trail is well maintained. Some places are a bit rocky. You won’t regret this hike.
Not an easy hike but we’ll worth the trip! While climbing for 2 hours, make sure you go to both locations, White Rocks and Sand Cave. Very unique cave in the middle of the forest!! It’s a must see!!

l
k
way to far of a hike to the cave. the cave is not 4 miles from the sign at the beginning
Great trail. Amazing view from the top. Easy to hike down after dark with proper flashlight.
One of my favorite hikes. Sand cave is an amazing place. Have to see it to believe it! A real jewel!!!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Doyles River Falls Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Doyles River Falls Trail is a 3.4 mile out and back trail located near Port Republic, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and walking. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Pets must be on a six-foot leash here at all times. You will pass by three different waterfalls: Upper and Lower Doyles River Falls, and Jones Run Falls.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. At mile 81.1, park in the Doyles River parking area where you will find a large trailhead with directions.
reviews: Starting from Doyle River Falls lot, steady downhill. Doyle Falls more impressive than Jones Run Falls. More gradual slope up to follow Jones Run trail to connect to Appalachian Trail than to do out and back. Total over 9.5 miles.
Hot!! lots and lots of millipedes

A very fun trail. Lots of ways to access and lots of other trails to do if you want to go a little farther (or cut it short). Clean and quiet, not in the middle-of-nowhere but you are in a national park.

BEWARE OF BUGS! The river and waterfalls are completely covered with worms/millipedes. COMPLETELY. Waterfalls were very beautiful but no swimming right now as the water flow is kind of low and every surface near them is coated in millipedes. If camping overnight— camp after the stone marker for Jones Run Trail (where the trail changes from Doyle’s River to Jones Run.) Big clear campsite to the right of trail.

Great trail, a good bit of elevation gain on the way out to get the blood pumping.  Today was a bit humid so we broke a good sweat.  The area is in need of rain as it's been fairly dry this year, as such the waterflow over the falls was not as good as I had hoped for.  You take what you can get.  I will definitely do this hike again and complete the loop when I know there is better waterflow over the falls.  This is probably a spectacular hike in the fall with the trees turning color.
Hike down was very easy. However the trip back up was very hard.
Watch out for the beehive in the tree by the second falls on the way down.
The trails were in great condition.  Started by going to the Doyles River Falls.  I kept going to the Jones Run parking area and took th AT back to the Doyles River parking area.
Great trail, very well maintained. Very steep and rocky especially at the bottom, poles or a walking stick definitely recommended!
What are all the worms in the water and on the rocks.  Millions

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: James River North Bank and Buttermilk Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: James River North Bank and Buttermilk Loop Trail is a 6.9 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Richmond, Virginia that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs and horses are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: The Reedy Creek parking area is on Riverside Drive at Hillcrest Road.
reviews: Once you find the trail it is nice but don’t do it alone
Pretty much flat and not hard. Wish it was better identified to where to go
GREAT TRAIL! 1st time here from NJ
Third attempt, third times the charm
Absolutely stunning but hot as h e double hockey sticks and no water fountains!!!!!  But an absolute gem, so gorgeous and fun.

Ital terps Grape Cola and Orangeade bless this whimsical morning. 
“Character is who we are when we think no one is watching.” 
Terp. 
Grind. 
Repeat.

I did the trail clockwise! I got lost once because I didn’t realize at once point you’re walking along the highway, this is at the point where the trail connects along the buttermilk trail. Overall really fun though this is a shared bike paths so you should always be aware of your surroundings because at times it can be narrow.

Yo. This hike on a hot day is hard! I am a fairly experienced hiker and this kicked my butt! Beautiful spaces. Tons of mountain biking - so be highly aware on foot. 

On the trail you pass by the wildlife preserve and I saw a bear playing in water.

Pack more water than you need. This trail can be super tricky. I made several wrong turns.
Would recommend to anyone that wants to see Richmond by the James! Trail isn't too bad right after rain, I would bring 40oz water at least if it's over 80 degrees!
Hotter than hell. Sweatin like a whore in church. Had to stop for water at the west end of NB again. Struggle bus. Lemon Mints.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Bear's Den Park Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Bear's Den Park Trail is a 1.7 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Bluemont, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
