reviews: Rocky and easy!! Great trail!!
Easy hike, great view at the end. Just very rocky at some points, so be careful of ankles.
Nice family trail the leads to beautiful views. A bit of a climb but not too difficult for kids.
Great day, great hike.

Clear path. Beautiful day 
WATCH OUT FOR COPPERHEADS
Excellent out-n-back trail to some great views. Easy for kids as well.
Rocky trail with some gravel and flat parts. Found copper head at the overlook.
Bear's Den is a great trail for beginners and amateur hikers. The kids love this trail.
Fun and great for families.
Clean, peaceful, and easy hike!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Roaring Run Hoop Hole Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Roaring Run Hoop Hole Trail is a 1.7 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Eagle Rock, Virginia that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Roanoke, VA: Take I-81, Exit 150 to US 220 north past Eagle Rock. At VA 615, turn left and go 5.5 miles to VA 621. Turn right onto VA 621 and go 1 mile to Roaring Run entrance on left. Driving distance from I-81 is 27.5 miles; estimated driving time is 40 minutes.
reviews: Awesome
Beautiful hike with fun times crisscrossing the stream! One of my favorites in this area.
Wonderful hike, short and sweet! Lots of places to get in water and dog friendly. Kids had a blast sliding down the waterfalls too.
Great hike. Lots of poison ivy though
Very easy trail for beginning hikers.

Extremely busy, but awesome “easy” trail.. we did it with our 4 year old and she CRUSHED it .. bring a bathing suit .. I would definitely do it again .. took us about an hour and a half but we took out time and we’re exploring
Easy trail to hike. Great waterfalls.

This is a great hike! Personally I would caution those who see the word “easy” and think “smooth, easy, level, no steep steps” because it is rocky, lots of mud, roots, poison ivy, there was a downed tree to climb through today, muddy ruts, and high, slanted rocks to climb up and around, especially if you want to go to the top of the falls. The only thing easy about it is that it’s short and a gentle rise in elevation.  We are seniors recovering from knee surgery, injury….and a year of being sedentary due to Covid, so we’ve been working out a lot and building up to longer and more difficult hikes. We use hiking poles and they help us a lot. This hike was perfect for us today! We were able (and determined) to climb all the way to the top of the falls. LOVED IT! Then we took the nice gentle rolling path down through the forest to make it a loop. Fun seeing the furnace and the forest is beautiful but the walk up next to the water to the falls was beautiful and memorable and definitely the highlight. For those with very young children, note that there are some steep drops in a few places, LOTS of tripping hazards, and in case you didn’t notice it earlier in my post, lots of poison ivy to deal with on the sides of the path and especially if you stray from the path. Otherwise this is a hike I’m happy we were able to complete today! Definitely five stars for the experience and a bonus for all of the scenic bridges and boardwalk.

One of the most beautiful and scenic trails I’ve ever had the pleasure of traversing. Go to the right at the trail head and climb to the top of the waterfalls. The views are exquisite. Yes the trail is rated easy but it is an upward climb and there were muddy places and lots of poison ivy so be careful, know your poison ivy.  At the top there are stone steps, but someone has started a trail to avoid them, stay on the steps, the narrow trail is pure poison ivy.￼
This was a great hike for families and kids of all ages.  The short distance, gentle incline, and beautiful atmosphere kept everyone engaged!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Union Mill and Bull Run Occoquan Trail Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Union Mill and Bull Run Occoquan Trail Loop is a 3.6 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Manassas, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
reviews: Rad!
There isn’t an overlook even, I think it just overlooks the water?
Awesome trail! Good water spots for dogs

Picked a cool day, at the trail by 8:30. Beautiful views along the river. Elevation changes are not bad, my 70+ mother-in-law had no trouble. Some rocky areas, but overall an easy walk. Some good spots to skip stones. Lots of big trees, lots of different species to see.
Muddy and no trash cans so lots of litter but great trail!
My GPS says 2.8 miles on this loop.  Trail is well marked and maintained.   Slippery when wet.
Beautiful path. Great hiking with dogs and kids!
Great trail, shorter than 3.6 miles though.

Was a nice trail! Arrived around 10:30 and had to pay $8 for overflow parking. Lots of shade and pretty flowers in full bloom. Also, enjoyed walking next to the water and seeing the abandoned building along the way. Not sure if I’d consider this an easy trail, elevations were a little challenging at times, but I’m not that fit either.
Nice 3.5 mile hike along the water. Mountain laurels in full bloom, saw several frogs, a black snake, and ended at Paradise Springs winery.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Mount Pleasant Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Mount Pleasant Trail is a 6.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Vesuvius, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
reviews: Great trail. Tiring but not too difficult. Mostly shaded as well. We went clockwise as suggested by others and totally agree it was best to have the easy downhill on the way back. We brought 2 kids (6 and 12) and a dog and they all had a great time. No streams for the dog to drink from until the way back down, so bring a little extra water. Views were great from both east and west overlooks. We did pick up a tick, so be aware of the tall grasses.
went clockwise and spend the night at the summit. hard part done first. Great views both east and west.

Great hike, very well-marked trail, not too challenging but a good workout, and amazing views at the end.  Definitely make sure to get all the way to the viewpoint, the views are worth it.  Concur with others- clockwise is the way to go.  Highly recommend.
Wow! This hike was incredible. I fully recommend going clockwise, as the second half is so much easier than the first.
Really great trail! Super well marked and kept up very well. The western overlook is the best!

Beautiful trail up to the summit with magnificent views east and west. Went counterclockwise and found the return on the loop very tiresome. Thought it would never end. The gravel road up isn't that bad once you get past the deep ruts with the dirt ramp on the left.
Quite a long and rugged gravel road to get to the trailhead. Nice, moderately strenuous trail. I recommend 40oz of hydration per full-sized adult. Nice views at the overlooks.

Road was very washed out on 5/29 (heads up for others who plan to hike over Memorial Day weekend). It's not my first time hiking this trail and we've made it up this road before in a sub-compact, but this time had to park 1.5 miles from the trailhead due to road conditions. 

The northern portion of this loop is lovely with great variety in terrain and a good combo of incline and downhill. Next time I might just do an out and back on the northern trail instead of taking the full loop, since the southern end doesn't have as much variety or scenery of interest.

If you love wildflowers, hike this trail! We saw trillium, pink lady’s slipper, fiddlehead fern, wild bleeding heart, hens and chicks, wood anemone, blue-bead lily, azalea, among many others. What a treat!
Nicely marked, but lots of rocks on the trail

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Saint Mary's Falls Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Saint Mary's Falls Trail is a 4.3 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Raphine, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from April until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
reviews: This was a great hike with a beautiful waterfall and swimming hole as a reward.  It can be a bit tricky to follow so watch for the oddly place red blazes. We are both experienced hikes and got off trail a few times and were a bit confused.   The water is cold and refreshing and a great place to hang out for awhile.  A thoroughly enjoyable hike!
Mostly flat and easy. Nice streams and falls. Very crowded with periodic trash on the ground and graffiti on rocks. Our past off-season visit was much better.

I've been trying to make it to the falls for about 2 years. have never made it. Got lost with kids once, one time the side of the trail wasnt safe to cross, another my group had no interest in hiking over rocks. and now this time. just me and the best hiking dog and 2.25 miles in we just couldn't go any farther. I believed we stopped about .25 miles away from the falls. Stopped for a snack and to filter water. a group of younger kids that were very loud passed and I chose to turn back. maybe we'll get there next time.

This was a great experience for a one day event with 3.5 hours driving to and from the trail head. We will do it again for certain!

It was easy for us to get off the normal trail. I think others have commented that there is a hard way, and an easy way. We somehow got onto the trail that ran more closely along the stream. Once we realized that we missed a turn, it was easy to get on the right path. Before that, however, it was progressively getting more difficult. Stay on the right path of you have a dog with you.

The falls were nice with a refreshing swim. There were two places to jump from the cliff into the pool that were a little of fun. The blueberries were abundant, delicious, and ripe for the picking in the area of the falls.

I definitely consider the trail moderate, be prepared to cross the river a few times. I wore regular tennis shoes and made it fine!  Many spots to stop and check out the views and the waterfall made the trek worth it. The trail had a little bit of everything, some smoother walking mixed with some rocky spots. Overall great!

Awesome trail with it's cool surroundings and multiple water crossings. We found refreshing swimming holes along the way to the falls to dip into. When we got to the falls we were surprised to find a really deep swimming hole that you can jump into, off the 25ft rockface! Super fun trip and easy hike. Like others are saying it gets crowded fast on the weekends. Would recommend and do again.

Beautiful hike! The trail can be tricky to follow at certain points (looks like an old route has been washed away), but keep an eye out for the red trail markers and you should get there just fine. Beautiful waterfalls with a fabulous swimming hole. Worth the trek!

beautiful trail. parkinglot does get full more towards midday. older kid friendly unless younger is use to hiking trails. there are some very rocky spots you have to go through. creek crossings, mostly shaded trail. it's a moderate trail. definitely a must see

Great trail - easy out and back but sections can be slippery. Bring bug spray as with the water nearby it’s buggy out. My GS puppy loved all the places to wade into the water. The water levels were low and I was able to get across every crossing without getting my shoes wet except the end one so I would recommend wear shoes  that you don’t mind getting wet. Parking lot can fit 15 cars in spots about but it filled up but the time I came back to the trailhead at 11:30 -‘d people had started parking down the side of the road leading up to it.
Great hike. On the split in dotted lines, there are 2 paths most of the time, one super hard and one moderate. I recommend moderate ones especially if you are with a dog.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Lower White Oak Falls via Whiteoak Canyon Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Lower White Oak Falls via Whiteoak Canyon Trail is a 2.8 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and running.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: Was a moderate hike. Not tough though. The swimming holes were a huge fun, I jumped in the water. It’s very crowded and trafficked so there would be people in the path. We visited in July 4 th but it was the most refreshing trail I did for summer ! Was a great experience
Waterfalls are a pretty awesome spot for swimming. Not the most challenging hike, but it was a nice change of pace after doing a 10 miler.
Just about 5 miles total. There were a lot of swimming holes for my 3 & 5 year old to swim and take breaks along the way. I paid $10 to park just outside the entrance since the lot was full.
Rocky but pretty easy. Beautiful hike. Falls are amazing and great swimming holes.
NPS listed this hike as easy, definitely closer to a moderate.

I really enjoyed the hike.  Very rocky terrain most of the way, so I suggest hiking boots.   Weather was perfect today, and there was very little mud despite yesterday's rains.  Very few people on the trail till about 12pm.

A beautiful short hike up to the spectacular White Oak Canyon Falls. A moderate hike in elevation over rocks and tree roots to a majestic view of the lower falls.  A relaxing hiking experience. Great pics!
great trail, not overly rocky. went after 2 days of down pouring rain and it was easy to navigate

Let’s start with parking- if you have a larger vehicle and see people parked in the overflow lots leading up to the main parking lot- park there. We drive a large pick up and almost couldn’t get out when other people don’t know how to park properly. The trail itself was well marked - even though there were a lot of cars people were spread out on trail. It’s rated moderate - I only would agree it’s moderate b/c it’s a rocky trail and can potentially be very muddy after a good rain. If not for that I’d say it’s actually easy if just doing the lower portion. To go to the falls and back will be 3 miles
June 8 there is water over the falls. Plenty of water in the "swimming holes". 5 and 7 year old Grandkids loved it. Very nice for all ages.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Pyrite Mine Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Pyrite Mine Loop Trail is a 7 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Triangle, Virginia that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Prince William Forest Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are $20 per vehicle or $15 per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot or bike the fee is $10 per person. You can also purchase a park specific annual pass for $35.

Explore the Pyrite Mine ruins and catch some terrific waterfalls, wildlife, and a good hike. Not into hiking? Put on the bathing suit and bring an innertube and float away on the river (nice and slow).

The trail starts out with small steep sections, and plenty of bridged water crossings. The trail gets muddy after rains, so bring a hiking stick as necessary, and bug spray. Most of the hike is along a river or stream.

Along the Pyrite mine section of the trail, you can see and explore ruins with interpretive signs.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
pack a lunch to have at the waterfall area halfway on the rocks
  bring bugspray and a hiking stick, if rain recently then its muddy
  bathing suit and tubing!
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: I-95 south to exit 150B (Triangle-Quantico), with sign for Prince William Forest Park; turn right onto VA 619 and in two blocks turn right onto entrance road for park.  Continue on entrance road to intersection and turn left onto the Scenic Drive.  Follow signs to Turkey Run.
reviews: We loved this trail. It was hot out, but comfortable because so much of the trail is shaded. There’s lots of variety in the scenery, everything from water views to ruins and gorgeous fern-filled forests. I highly recommend this trail and Prince William Forest NP in general.
nice walk through the woods, but nota lot to see in terms of overlooks etc
Wicked Sweet
Shaded. Quite. Peaceful
Confising
Beautiful park with lots of variety. Woods, creeks, waterfalls.  Cool and shady even In summer heat. We particularly liked the bridges that crossed the waterways

The park is my happy place.  This is my second hike there and longest.  Brought my fitness challenge team there to pump up our step count for this month's contest.  We also brought my wife and a dog.  This was my wife's second hike ever.  The trails are very well maintained and the park has beautiful scenery to motivate you on your trek.  The skill is rated easy, but I'd give it an "Easy+" probably from the heat and humidity.   Teddi the wonder dog loved the water for a spot to cool off..  The park staff are terrific and the facilities are immaculate.  Everybody in my group wants to come back again for fall colors.   It will be awesome.
Got very turned around, the signage was difficult to follow. Ended up going 10 miles instead of 7
Really nice areas with waterfalls to wade in

Nice shaded mostly flat trail with a handful of slightly challenging hills. There’s two camp grounds to take a quick break including restrooms. Recommend bringing bugs spray and there’s opportunities to dip in the water with small waterfalls.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Jones Run Falls Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Jones Run Falls Trail is a 4.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Crozet, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and walking and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Featuring one stream crossing, this hike through the woods brings you to a beautiful 42-foot tall waterfall.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Just beyond milepost 84 is a small parking area with the trailhead.
reviews: Great hike, definitely intermediate, water flow is low due to dry conditions. It’s always good being out to enjoy God’s creation.
Great hike. We started with Doyle falls then kept going to those falls. Beautiful hike, some areas a little challenging due to slippery rocks but take your time, totally worth it.
Nice hike! Did it with a 3, 4 and 6 year old. Last 1/2 mile was challenging
One of our favorite hikes in the park. It had rained the night before and the rocks were very slippery.
The trail was nice and easy, but if you want to get down to the falls you have to climb down the side of the hill. The trail doesn’t lead to the waterfall directly.
so lush and green! very nice hike. as others have said, the last stretch to the parking lot can be BRUTAL!
Very steep as you make your return to the parking lot. Great workout!
Beautiful. Last stretch to parking lot is brutal like everyone says. Totally worth it. The bottom part by the falls is breathtaking all the way down.
Good wide trails
Loved it. Definitely going to come back to finish the entire thing

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Rock Castle Gorge Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Rock Castle Gorge Loop is a 10.4 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near Floyd, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
The trail is great for hiking and normally takes a full day.

This hike is very strenuous, since most of the hike when done clockwise gains in elevation and offers views, forests, waterfalls, and wildlife.

There are demanding climbs, gentle hiking through meadows on top of the ridge and some steep descents. You will see an old Appalachian Trail shelter, the chimney of an old homestead and then the historic Austin House beside Rock Castle Creek.

There are multiple places to start this hike along the Blue Ridge Parkway.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
1. Be prepared for a strenuous and somewhat technical hike. Make sure to wear good hiking boots. Trek poles are a plus.
2. Only campsites are at the bottom and the top.
3. Plenty of water sources along the trail
4. You will need a backcountry permit to camp by the creek at the bottom of the gorge
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: The Blue Ridge Parkway connects Shenandoah National Park near Waynesboro, VA (Milepost 0) with Great Smoky Mountains National Park near Cherokee, NC (Milepost 469). Asheville and Boone, NC and Roanoke, VA are the largest cities along the way. In Virginia, Interstates 64, 81, and 77 all have directions for accessing the Parkway. The same is true for Interstates 40 and 26 in North Carolina.  To reach the Rock Castle Gorge trail, there are numerous entry points, but two are recommended.  One is at VA Rt 605 off VA Rt8 in southern Virginia near Stuart and Woolwine, VA, which takes you to the trailhead at the lowest elevation point on the trail (elevation 1700').  The other is from the Blue Ridge Parkway Rocky Knob Campground located at Mile Marker 167 on the Parkway (elevation 2860').  More information can be found at .
reviews: Done the trail twice now and I'd do it again.  It's that good.  Recommend hiking pole to help w/ the steep descents.  This trail is a good excuse to get a trail water filter.   Carrying all the snacks and water you want gets heavy.  Start early and budget 6 hours total.    If you're a novice or not sure you can complete the whole thing, you can position a second car on Rock Castle Rd parking area.  This is really your only shot for a bail out.

Well marked. Good challenge. Lots of overall elevation gain. Scramble over rocks, fences, trees. I don’t use poles. My large dog did well, a small dog might need carried a few times. Lovely views. Really enjoyed walking the field with the cows. Might suggest some bug spray and pack enough water!

The trail had some tricky spots and definitely some strenuous uphill sections. The views from the meadows were gorgeous. Hiking with cows was very cool. The waterfall was pretty. As far as it being rated “hard”, my twin seven year olds hiked it in Chaco sandals. I’d say it’s more of an upper level “moderate.”
Fun trails good but not the best scenery

This trail when done counter clockwise is a beast. That 1.5 mike incline is an elevation gain of about 1500. It’s very rocky and with tree roots and soft sand, all on a ledge about 2 feet wide. Turn you finish that and climb for 2 more miles. We were the only ones doing counter clockwise. Everyone else went the other way.  For us, up was better than down that 1.5 mile stretch but it makes it a much harder hike. 

If you do counter clockwise, do follow AllTraks to the trailhead. Start at the campground entrance so you can at least do it on fresh kegs. Otherwise you hike for 6.5 miles before you tackle it.

I don’t know where All Trails gets 10 miles from it was definitely a little over 11. Lots of bugs on the trail, pretty sure half of them ended up in my eyes or in my mouth. Highly recommend wearing long pants. Lots of prickly plants over the trail and my legs were really scratched up afterwards. My pole was great to get the over growth out of the way on many occasions.  You do get to walk through cow pastures twice. Super fun but I was a bit timid walking so close to them. Definitely do counter clockwise like everyone else suggested. Once you pass the Campground and start going up be prepared for a challenging climb. Once you get past mile 7 you get a straight shot for a mile or so and then you go up again. Around mile 8 we heard multiple gun shots which was quite unexpected. We were told it was probably someone having target practice. I am just happy multiple bears didn’t come running our way from all the noise. One of the more challenging hikes I have done but it was so worth it. Definitely bring lots of water along if you go on a hot day you will need it when you are going up.
Beautiful but a little windy. Not too much traffic on the trail.

Definitely a difficult trail. The trail is very steep and extremely narrow in some parts. Be sure to bring plenty of water. There were some snakes (the copperhead, as pictured), bear scat, and frogs along the way. It’s also very buggy—I’d recommend bringing bug spray or some other sort of repellent.

I’m a novice hiker on mostly flat terrain in FL. This VA mountain loop ate my lunch but I finished it and just before dark, and when the rain set in.  I feel like a Dali painting - completely exhausted of any energy but this is the hardest hike I’ve done to date…including other VA trails.  Other folks passed us carrying no water and in regular PE clothes but the change in terrain and elevation calls for some trekking poles.  Bring more water than you’ll think you need. Head counter clockwise as recommended and your best sites will push you to finish this amazing trail. This 5-star hike makes me want to modify my scoring for all previous hikes I’ve rated…maybe tomorrow - I need a soak and some zzzs.
Awesome hike! Will do this again. Lost of water during hike makes this a perfect warm weather hike.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Mary's Rock via the Appalachian Trail (Southern Approach)
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Mary's Rock via the Appalachian Trail (Southern Approach) is a 3.1 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from May until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Pets must be on a 6 ft leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park in the Meadow Spring parking area at mile 33.5. Trail begins across the Drive just a few feet south of the parking lot.
reviews: Fantastic views on the top made all the better by it being relatively less trafficked compared to other hikes in Shanendoah. Also, spotted a couple deer on the way which was a treat
Beautiful hike, not heavily trafficked on a Saturday afternoon. Views are well worth it, as well as the flora and fauna on the way. Highly recommended!
Perfect! Some brief, intense climbs separated by sweet little flats. Great views all along. Definitely recommend high boots for the uneven rockiness if you have any misgivings about your ankles.

Amazing views at the summit, and nice viewpoints along the way as well. Pretty consistently uphill and steep the whole way without very many breaks. It was starting to get crowded even on a Monday, so definitely go early, although most people do the northern route so there aren’t as many people on the trail along the way, just at the summit.

Trail was great. Lots of traffic but not too bad. One thing I will say is go as early as you can because many people don’t know hiking etiquette. Once we reached the top everyone was sitting and eating their snacks right in front of the view so we weren’t able to take a good picture. Go when nobody else is going..
Beautiful trail. A little muddy because of recent rain. Great moderate hike!
Awesome trail!  The view is spectacular!

Short but rewarding!  Initial blue blaze is about a mile of steep inclines but once you’re on the AT then it levels out a bit.  The top is amazing, wonderful views and a great place to have a bite. Be sure to climb to the top of the rock as well.  The out:back time ratio was about 2:1 so that gives you an idea of the initial slower pace.
Very well maintained trail and rewarding hike! I agree it’s a moderate climb for the first third and eases out a little bit. Our dog had a great time, too.
A bit strenuous on the way up but well worth it!!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Turk Mountain Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Turk Mountain Trail is a 2.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Crozet, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, camping, and bird watching and is best used from April until September. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. At mile 94.1, park on the east side of the Drive and begin on the Appalachian Trail. Take it for a short distance until you see the trail post for Turk Mountain.
reviews: Surprising amount of gravel and medium size rocks. Top of the mountain it self is not a simple scramble. If you have a problem with heights, you will need to be cautious.￼

Definitely moderate. Very rocky, recommend boots for dogs and their owners!
Go across street from parking lot, bear right at the first fork. Follow the blue marks on trees along the path and blue arrows
Stunning views. A lot of it was shaded. Make sure you go up the rocks at the end!
Quick stop off I-64 on our way home. No scrambling on trail, but plenty at the top if that is what you want. For some reason there were flies everywhere at the top.
Lovely hike thru the woods. I’d definitely say moderate. Some rocky trail sections. Very rocky top, be prepared for a bit of a scramble to make it to the best views

This is a nice quick trail for proficient hikers. The westward views are available after a minor scramble on some boulders. I got stuck at the top during a thunderstorm, which was not pleasant. But even while it was raining it was traversable and I was able to complete the trail with no incident.
Great west views! Just be sure to continue thru the boulders to the end for the WEST view.
Love this trail for a quick visit to SNP. We saw maybe 7-10 families on a Monday morning but it didn’t feel too busy. Saw many fearless deer!
a tough one for us flat landers. fairly rocky and steep in sections. our 6 and 8 year Olds struggled. but overall it was a nice hike.
I’d say the portion of the trail from the valley to the summit can be strenuous for some. Be prepared for a steep incline with a lot of loose rocks. Worth it at the top, but definitely a longer hike.
Narrow, rocky, some steep bits. There are a few side summits before the top. Good valley views.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Devils Bathtub Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Devils Bathtub Trail is a 3.9 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Fort Blackmore, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail offers a number of activity options. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Caution: This swimming hole is prone to flash flooding. For this reason, please do not attempt the trail if the water is above your knees. This trail requires several creek crossings.

The road to the trailhead can be rough and is washed out in places. An SUV is recommended to reach the parking lot.
reviews: The bathtub is pretty cool and worth the hike the trail is well marked with a lot of stream crossings didn’t count them but close to a dozen we were able to cross all of them and stay dry but my guess is that could change quickly with rain some of the crossings are not straight across so you will need to work up the stream we started at 1pm and there wasn’t much traffic but passed a lot coming down at 4 directions to trail head were good but you will lose service I recommend parking at lower parking lot unless you have 4wh driving up doesn’t save you that much and there is one short spot that needs good vehicle articulation or you wont get through and half to back down
The trail was such fun. The creek crossings were rock climbing across somewhat challenging. The trail was well marked & busy as the day went along.

PICK UP YOUR TRASH AND ANY CLOTHING ITEM THAT YOU BROUGHT WITH YOU PLEASE!!! It is just so sad to see how littered this trail is, the spring is amazing and refreshing. We need to take better care of our trails people.

The hike is not hard at all, I will say is borderline easy and moderate lots of river crossing.
Absolutely beautiful.   We took the dogs and they had a blast

Nice, clean beautiful trail. If you arrive early you’ll have it to yourself. As the day goes on it gets busy. Nice big parking lot about .5 miles from trail head. Parking at trail head if you go up the gravel road.

Great hike. I guess it’s rated difficult because of all the creek crossings. We were able to make it across them without getting our feet wet. The hike was actually pretty easy other than the creek crossing.  Devil’s bathtub is beautiful. It’s a neat destination. Definitely come ready to swim. My kids had fun. We parked in the designated parking off the main road. It’s a .5 mile walk to the trailhead. Might be worth riding to the trailhead to see if there was parking. They had plenty of parking on the Saturday we were there, but we didn’t know until we’d already made the walk.
Easy hike. People have thrown trash, tissue, old shirts, towels. But the swimming hole and Devils bathtub are beautiful.
Awesome!!!

2nd time there for me! 1st time with my 10 year old! she absolutely loved it! we loved going the creeks. but she really enjoyed the rope swing and the amazingness surrounding the bathtub itself! she wants to do this multiple times!
Rocky trail. Only went to the devils bathtub and back, didn't do the whole loop trail. multiple river/creek crossings. Water was chilly but beautiful!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Cole Mountain via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Cole Mountain via Appalachian Trail is a 5.9 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Montebello, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Keep an eye out for rattlesnakes on this hike.
reviews: Yay
Trail was a bit unkept at parts and have some pretty tall grass. Also def watch for rattlesnakes, we saw a few so wouldn't recommend for dog owners but other than that it was lovely!
Gorgeous!
Amazing spot!
A lot of tall grass early if you start at the top.  Very nice trail otherwise with two great overlooks before reaching the big open area with fantastic views.

Excellent forest hike! Great flora diversity. Cole mountain summit is great and the meadow 1/2 way back was beautiful. Awesome white pine section felt like giants. Not difficult. Overall a great hike!

Great hike - the loop is slightly longer than all trails says, we clocked about 6.2. The drive to the parking is a little muddy/rough so four wheel drive definitely helped. Not too tough of a hike, perfect amount of challenge, great views. Will definitely come back with a picnic for the top!

Loved this hike! We went clockwise. Moderate trail with a couple steep sections but mostly an easy grade. The areas through the woods were lovely but the wow moment is the 360 degree views from the meadow at the summit. We DID see a rattlesnake hanging out on the rocks at the top. My biggest suggestion is to know you'll be following The Hotel Trail to the AT as none of the trail signs specifically mention Cole Mountain. Also note the dirt/gravel road to the trailhead has some ruts...I was grateful for my truck!

Great hike. Went clockwise so you earn the view and it’s uphill so good leg workout. Just past the top on the right is a perfect view campsite, flat top area is tons of fun w amazing sunset. Wear tall socks for those grasses

We took our scout troop on this hike. We went clockwise and camped at the AT shelter. We drew lots of water from the convenient stream at the site. Two of the tent sites were large enough for a group of 30, the others were standard size. The trail was very scenic and the view on Cole mountain was great. This was the first time backpacking for many of our scouts, but everyone was glad they went, and we all had a great time. I would definitely recommend this route as a medium difficulty hike or backpacking trip.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Old Rag Mountain via Weakley Hollow Fire Road
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Old Rag Mountain via Weakley Hollow Fire Road is a 9.7 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Etlan, Virginia that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, camping, and bird watching and is accessible year-round.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

The typical route to the Old Rag Summit is via the Summit Ridge Trail. Most hikers climb the ridge, and then return to their cars via the Weakley Hollow fire road. The fire road ends after about 2 miles, and connects with the Saddle trail which consists of a series of switchbacks to the summit. The scenery along the fire road is very wooded, but as you approach the Saddle trail, you will have some nice vistas.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there:
The trailhead is located at the far end of the upper lot. During peak times, such as weekends, you will be hardpressed to get a spot in the upper lot, so you may need to walk here from the lower lot, which adds about a mile and half to your trek.

The trailhead is located behind the gate at the head of the lot.
reviews: Def a hard hike. Steep rock scramble on the way up. Mostly gravel fire road on way down. Despite the difficulty still saw some you get kids with family out managing it well. Amazing views at the top and at several points along the way. Bring plenty of hydration and fuel
Absolutely amazing!!! The rock scramble was so fun, definitely challenging but well work it! The views from the summits were amazing and there was a beautiful very refreshing breeze. Loved it!
Beautiful hike with tons of wildlife, bring good hiking/climbing shoes with tread and a LOT of water. I took a camelback plus two water bottles and ran out as I got to my car
Awesome
The scramble would be tough alone but with some help in spots, not too bad. Multiple overlooks were fantastic, the summit did not disappoint.

Hiked 10/18. We went counter clockwise so didn’t get to enjoy the full rock scrambling experience to the top. Towards the end, hardly saw anyone. Would recommend doing it clockwise for the full experience. But we still had a fantastic time. Great weather and views.
Amazing hike. Super tired and happy.
Amazing trail and the rock climbing part was awesome, I loved it!
Great trail for advanced hikers.  Lots of elevation gain but you are rewarded with lots of fun challenges and breathtaking panoramic views
Crowded at the summit but nice to have people to chat with along the way

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Hazel Falls and Caves
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Hazel Falls and Caves is a 5.3 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Sperryville, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and bird watching and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

A good hike to stretch your legs in the morning. The last section of the trail is very steep. There are two caves near the falls. One is obvious. The second is closer to the first pool of water. You do have to scramble up a kiosks bit but it is an interesting find.
reviews: It was pretty rocky, definitely a moderate hike. Waterfall was okay not sure if we got to the right part but it was ok￼
Great hike and would rate as easy except the last little bit where you descend down to the river.  Saw two large hiking groups. No other wildlife.

I would rate it as easy, the only portion that makes it moderate is the .2 miles down and up to the falls and the fact that the whole way back is a SLIGHT incline. Almost no one on the trail but a couple families popped their tents up at the falls. 2.5 hours round trip, went with my 9 pound fluffy butt. Very pretty!
Great hike!
The .2 miles to the falls is rough. It’s a bunch of very steep rock stairs. Otherwise, gorgeous hike, and the rest of it was fairly easy.
Nice hidden treasure. You need to work for it, but it was worth it

Really enjoyable hike. Super easy hiking to the falls pretty much all down hill with some flat stretches. Once you get to steps that heads to falls take your time. If you can manage to scramble there are two more smaller falls behind the main one. It is mostly uphill on the way back with the steps being the most difficult part.
Fantastic hike! It’s not as popular as other trails to waterfalls so I got to experience solitude and the wonder of Mother Nature.

My husband and I thought this was a little more difficult than moderate. It is a little more than 2.5 miles down to the falls and the same amount back up. it is all uphill on the way back. It was beautiful and a good clean path.
Steep climb back out, but worth it!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Berry Hollow to Old Rag Mountain Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Berry Hollow to Old Rag Mountain Trail is a 5.4 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: Easy route for a quick summit view of Old Rag.
Was an absolute blast! Definitely some challenging areas and the scrambling was very fun.
Definitely more than 5 miles! Woof! Uphill for the first part BUT VIEWS WERE GREAT!!!
Easy and moderate. Not difficult via this trail.

Arrived 8:00 on a Thursday morning and found only one car in the parking area. Nice hike up, only one other person on the summit but met 3 parties coming down who had done the rock scramble up. A lovely day with clouds wafting past the summit.
Lovely trail! Lots of rocks, but not nearly as many as the other approach to old rag’s summit. You still get some lovely views at the top, though!
first half is gravel road then onto well maintained trail up to summit.  very nice walk
Impossible hike but absolutely heaven!
Moderate trail. Nothing challenging really. I totally regret not going the more difficult route with the rock scramble. But the summit is beautiful no matter which way you go.

I wouldn't rate this as "hard". Everyone who is not out of shape can do this, including young kids. If you are not in a good shape, just take breaks. I like it very much because (1) it is front-loaded; (2) the last mile is a stroll; (3) great view at the top; (4) no rock scrambles. I didn't do "Old Rag" for years because I don't like rock scramble...until I discover this route...I'll be back. I went on a Tuesday (5/18...very nice hiking day) and arrived at noon (driving 2.5 hours from MD); there were only 6 cars in the parking lot. When I left at around 4pm, only a few cars left. I think the lot can take about 20 cars. It is about 1 mile north of the parking lot for Whiteoak Canyon.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Three Ridges Loop via Appalachian Trail and Mau-Har Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington National Forest - Lee District
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Three Ridges Loop via Appalachian Trail and Mau-Har Trail is a 14.6 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near Tyro, Virginia that features a river and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, bird watching, and backpacking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Users report that this trail is gorgeous. It is recommended to route clockwise around the loop. The view of the waterfall section is excellent, and getting there early in the morning is highly recommended throughout all seasons to avoid crowds, along with being able to complete the trail before sunset. 

This can be a tough hike, especially if not properly rested and hydrated as novices. The hike offers constant inclination and then long descents that can be tiring. However, the best view was not the peak of the summit, but just a bit before the summit on the right side of the trial if going clockwise, so if unable to complete this route, users note not to worry about summit views.
reviews: Didn’t have time for the full loop so did out and back from 56 to Three Ridges Summit counter clockwise on the loop). Phone pulled 11.2 miles and 3600+ elevation gain. Summit was in a cloud so didnt catch much from the vistas along the way. This is a solid hike if you’re looking to work. Saw a black bear on the way down to Harpers. Although everyone I passed on the way down was in shorts, I would recommend hiking/athletic pants this time of year - lots of high grass and brush on the trail once you get up by Chimney Rock on the ridge.

What a great hike.  Be prepared for a workout.  The entire 14+ miles is either climbing or descending.  We went clockwise as others have recommended.  The hike up the creek and falls was beautiful.  The last two miles of the descent gets long, but all in all a great way to spend 7ish hours.
Beautiful, somewhat challenging. Watch out for snakes, especially on the Mau-Har section.
Beautiful. Challenging in spots and easy in others. I lot of elevation.

Did it in one day; my Garmin smart watch shows 5568 ft ascent and 14.3 miles. Splendid hike and very challenging...started 7:30 am; few people on a weekday; huge timber rattlesnake on three ridges - otherwise the trail is clear and easy to follow.
Wow, what a great loop trail. Be in good shape if you want to attempt this as an overnighter. Great views, and much easier if you do this as a two night trip.

This was our first trip together and we decided to go the supposed “harder”, opposite route: Mau Har. It was certainly challenging, we went the weekend of July 11th 2020 (this is a late post). We averaged a 23 min/mile pace and finished in 1 night, 1 full day and half day (Sunday). The trail is a bit longer than all trails lists and by going the Mau Har route we camped on top of the ridge and the lull of the winds was the perfect night time meditation! There’s no water source on the ridge so just fill up at the campsite before going up the mountain.

I did this trail May 1-2, starting/ending at reeds gap rather than where AllTrails recommends. I did the at portion first and mau har second, camping at harpers creek campsites. Overall the trail was exciting, but very rocky and overall challenging. Be prepared for steep ascents/descents and some rocky portions where scrambling would be more helpful than trekking poles. The most reliable water sources were along the mau-har trail (with limited camping unless you are at the designated camping area) and at harpers creek. Little to no water along the AT portion. Overall a great 2 day/1 night trail if you are looking for a workout!

I did this trail as a 2 day, 1 night backpacking trip and it did not disappoint! We camped near the summit and he views were genuinely fantastic but I am glad we heeded the warnings to make sure we brought extra water up with us. This trail gets 5 stars for the views and if we were not in a pandemic I would have given it such. However, despite it currently being the law to wear a mask on public lands, not a single person covered their faces when passing. Not sure if this is a result of most people being vaccinated, but this is the first time I have been on a trail where NO ONE else had at least a buff to cover up with. Also, I get the feeling this is one of those touristy trails and so trail etiquette was a bit sketchy at times. Lastly, I am unsure of the actual mileage for this trail as the mileage listed by Alltrails appears to be more than if you look at the actual tracking map (off by about 3 miles).

Did the loop counterclockwise in order to complete the ridges on the first day. Took about 4 hours from the parking lot to get to the shelter and the surrounding campsites. If you decide to go counter clockwise (starting on the AT and then ending on the Mau-har) know that the shelter is the only reliable water source on the AT in that direction. There are plenty of campsites along the ridges but they are all dry.  Excellent hike, especially before the trees are in full bloom. Able to get approximately 360 views of the valley below when walking along the ridge. Made for an incredible sun setting experience. Trail was well kept and marked. Great combination of views on the AT and waterfalls on the Mau-hat) Took us approximately 7 1/2 hours hiking time to complete the loop, camping one night near the shelter.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Riverbend Park to Great Falls Overlook
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Riverbend Park to Great Falls Overlook is a 3.5 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Great Falls, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
reviews: Very awesome little workout

Beautiful and well maintained trail through woods along the river. There were a couple of small rocky outcrops that required some scrambles, but nothing we couldn’t easily handle as novice hikers. Otherwise it was a smooth and fairly flat trail that led to beautiful views and a fun morning out.

Beautiful trail! Not good for strollers or those with wheelchairs. There were a couple short/small rock scrambles, a few places where the trail gets pretty narrow, and a decent amount of crowds especially on weekends and as you get closer to the great falls overlook #1. Great for athletic dogs that don't mind hoping up and down some rocks at times. the main parking lot can get full on Saturdays after 1pm or so. There are currently porta potties at Riverbend and regular restrooms and water fountains once you get to the great falls visitor center. The trail was maintained and not muddy even though it rained tremendously 2 days prior. Most of the trail is in the shade so it stays decently cool in the summer.
Right after a rainfall so it was kind of muddy but rather empty of people
The trail is great! Short with beautiful views. Go early, before heat and crowds.
Beautiful!! Will come back again.
Breathtaking views and a nice mix of rock scrambling and soft dirt paths!
very wet and muddy
Great
Always beautiful ! A lot of spring flowers . Come early to get good parking spot.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Spy Rock Trail via Cash Hollow
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Spy Rock Trail via Cash Hollow is a 5.8 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Tyro, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, nature trips, and bird watching and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Not recommended for low clearance sports cars due to two stream crossings at .5 mile and 1.2 mile point. Not recommended for any vehicle if it’s forecasted to snow (it’s state maintained but not cleared in the winter).
reviews: Beautiful trail, relatively easy to navigate but definitely need to be mindful. Clearly marked which is nice. The views were beautiful but not quite 360. The drive in was fine in my Toyota Sienna just long.

I would rate the trail moderate. It was a great hike, with an amazing 360 degree  view from the top. We had great weather, mid 60s with a breeze. Great primitive campsites just below Spy Rock! Absolutely a must.￼ The 4 x 4 road going in was recently graded and graveled at the creek crossings. I still would not recommend a low clearance vehicle. If you park at the Crabtree Falls parking lot at the end of the road, you will have to backtrack up the road to catch the trail head for spy rock.￼

A great medium-length day hike. Is mostly agree with the other reviewers that the road doesn't fully necessitate 4WD, but you'd need to know how to keep your momentum driving some of the muddy uphills. The rock face about 2/3 of the way through provides a lovely window through the trees to view the mountainscape and I would guess there'd be continuous views during fall and winter. This is one of those hikes where there is no doubt at the end whether it was worth it. I only wish I'd had more time to chill and enjoy the views for longer, but sunset was approaching...

Great trail! The AT was really well marked and taken care of. The inclines are tough but so worth the view at the top. Take lots of water, it gets you sweating. I really do not suggest attempting to come up the road unless you have a vehicle that is 4WD and can take the bumps and rocks. This has become one of my favorite trails!

Amazing trail, not very busy at all on a really nice Saturday.  The 4x4 road was easily handled with my front wheel drive Toyota Corolla.  Your mileage may vary, but I had no issues driving on the road.  Just have to be smart.

echoing others to recommend taking a high clearance vehicle! our Honda civic scraped a rock on the first clearance & we decided to park on the side of the road and add an extra 2 miles out & back. Beautiful trail though, our first time back since they closed the fish hatchery entrance! perfect for a short overnight too, the sunrise is outstanding.
great hike for a half day to chill and enjoy nature. Road to trail head is fun if you have the proper vehicle, lots of big holes and lots of bumps. worth the hike. DO IT!!!!
Even on a rainy, cloudy day, it was a great hike. One member in our party recorded 8.8 miles for the whole trip up and back, (I didn't record the whole thing.)

Great hike, the trail was well marked and being a part of the AT, well traveled.  beautiful views from spy rock.  NOTE: take water with you...no springs or rivers to pull water from...we were going to camp within the allowed boundaries, but with no additional water hiked back to be able to have water accessable....will be back....and while we saw a few cars, I would not bring mine, a vehicle with truck like clearance is my recommendation.
With the old trailhead closed at the fishery, I gave this route a go. Absolutely loved it. Went on a Thursday, passed several though-hikers heading north, but not a single person at the rock.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Carvin's Cove Hay Rock via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Carvin's Cove Hay Rock via Appalachian Trail is a 7.7 mile heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Daleville, Virginia that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, nature trips, and bird watching and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: A nice, accessible, if suburban, section of the Appalachian Trail. The first section of the trail can be muddy, but there is evidence of ongoing trail maintenance to remedy this. Once you hit the ridge, there are great views for the remaining two miles to Hay Rock, but the footing is tricky and is slower going than the ascent.
reviews: New favorite easy trail in the area! There were gorgeous wildflowers and berries along the trail when I hiked here in July and the railroad crossing is a fun feature. The view of Carvin’s Cove at Hay Rock is gorgeous! I came for the view so I turned around at that point instead of finishing the last couple of miles but I plan to do the whole trail later.
Nice trail some pretty views

Great 2 day hike. McAfee Knob is spectacular, and Tinker Cliffs which you rarely hear about were almost as good.  Lambert Creek campground is a great halfway point, with a bear box and steady, easily accessible water.
Great trail. Great day.
beautiful views of carvins cove
Moderate climb to a beautiful ridge walk on the AT. Great views of the cove from several places.

It’s a bit sketchy at first you have to park on the side of Roanoke Rd in front of a guard rail and the trail is just a beaten path basically behind the guard rail and if you’re alone it’s a bit scary through out. I didn’t finish the trail unfortunately  I got 1.5 miles in and saw someone camping (my first thought was a homeless person but then I thought otherwise still not sure) . It was an older gentleman and probably harmless but I was already on edge so I turned back. The trail was beautiful and very clear but I’m not quite a seasoned hiker (only have 5 including this one under my belt) and I was alone so I decided I’ll turn back for now. My nerves got the best of me on this one. I will be back to conquer this one and see that beautiful mountain too view!
if you do this trail in mid-late spring, there will be flowers lining most of it. It was a very beautiful hike, the views were gorgeous as well.

Spectacular!!! One of the best in and out trails I’ve done since moving back to Virginia! The views were wonderful with several outlooks along the way! It wasn’t too busy and my dog enjoyed it as well! We will definitely hit this trail again!
Gorgeous views! Perfect spot for a couple hammock at the top.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Doyles River Loop via Appalachian Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Doyles River Loop via Appalachian Trail is a 9 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Port Republic, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and bird watching and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

This trail includes two Water Falls if hiking out and back and three if you do the loop with Jones Run Trail and the Applachian Trail. The upper falls is 63' and the lower is 28'.  Jones Falls is 42' and its parking area is at mile post 84.  Its a long downhill followed by a long uphill walk.  Short distance to Loft Mountain Wayside for Food afterwards. Trail is well marked with concrete pillars telling you directions.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: The parking lot is at mile marker 81 on the Skyline Drive (Shenandoah National Park).
reviews: Good exercise. Falls were anemic.
Nice hike , mostly shaded with a few nice water falls. Some rocks and roots but not too bad. Very relaxing
Start out with the falls. Ending on all those hills is killer
Beautiful!! It was wet so the rocks were super slippery, but all the waterfalls were so pretty. Too foggy to see the overlook unfortunately
Lots of up hill either direction you go, but a great hike! About 11 miles

Beautiful trail! Don’t be scared off by the “moderately strenuous” marking on NPS website. Started at Browns Gap parking and followed what other reviews said and went counter clockwise and it was great. Easy descent to the falls and a leisurely ascent to finish. Beautiful trails with lovely wildflowers in the spring. The falls were breathtaking. Did all 8.5 miles with our 18 lb pup and it was a great day for everyone! About 4.5 hrs hiking total with a couple of stops. Make sure you do a thorough tick check afterward! We found a few hitching a ride on our dog and on ourselves.
Nice trail heavily traveled water levels good but not spectacular it appears dry on the forest floor. highly recommend starting from browns gap vs Jones run or doyle.
One of my favorite trails in all of Shenandoah National Park.  Along this trail you will see 3 big waterfalls and a bunch of little ones.
Quite a workout.

Me: Day hiker, fit, rock climbs, Korean American, female, hikes 5 - 10 miles 

Hiking Notes:
-Start time: 10:00 AM Start temp: 47 degrees C; overcast. Parking lot had 1 car (other than mine).
-End time: 2:30 PM, End temp: 52 degrees C, light to moderate rain. Parking had 3 other cars. 

-Trail condition: Be careful while driving here because there are quite a few deer on the road (I saw close to 12 - 15 grazing in various spots on the side of the road). Also, it was not forecasted to rain today, even still I always keep a poncho in my bag. I am glad that I did because about halfway through the hike it began to seriously drizzle. Thankfully I did the wet/rocky path by the falls first (even before the rain there was a lot of muddy/wet parts of the trail by the falls, my trekking pole helped me not die), however the return trip on the AT was rather exposed. I ran into about 6 people during my 4.5 hours on the trail. Not nearly as crowded due to the weather. It seems cooler in the southern end of the park, but despite so there were quite a few early spring wildflowers. Lots of hepaticas starting to shoot up, and by the falls, hills of blood root wildflowers waiting for a bit of sun to open up; I even found several bleeding heart wildflowers. I can only imagine how gorgeous this trail is in "full spring mode". Also, there are waterfalls upon waterfalls. Waterfalls in every direction. I hope you like waterfalls (I love them). The trail was pretty clean, minus the buttload of tissue paper that, let's be honest here, is mostly women, who just throw it all over the trail. PLEASE DO NOT DO THIS, IT IS AN EYESORE. It also takes forever to biodegrade (just like tangerine peels O__O) and bears do not want your used toilet paper! Carry a plastic baggy and put your gently used PPTP in it. Otherwise beautiful trail.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Beaver Lake Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Beaver Lake Trail is a 2.3 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Chesterfield County, Virginia that features a lake and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This trail has beautiful vistas, moderate inclines, and a continuous view of the lake. Bikes are not allowed on this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Richmond, VA: Pocahontas State Park is in Chesterfield County, about 20 miles south of Richmond. From I-95, take Exit 61 and go west on Route 10 to Route 655, Beach Road; or take Exit 67, go north on Route 150 to Route 10; go east to Beach Road. The park is four miles on right; or take Route 288 from I-95 to Route 10 East and go one mile to Beach Road. Follow Beach Road to the park entrance. Continue on the main park road turning left into the CCC Museum parking lot. The trailhead is located next to the museum.
reviews: Great
Nice easy smooth hike with some rocks and roots. Great views of the lake.
Beautiful, quiet easy trail!

This trail has lovely views and is a well maintained trail through the woods around a lily pad filled lake.  We haven’t seen any beavers yet, but we keep looking!  We find starting with a left turn on the path vs a right is much easier - so you can pick the exertion level you are in the mood for!
Nice trail. Turned out to be 3 miles for us. First time here 7-70. Pretty good if you take your time.
nice trail around beaver lake. beavers were not out today though. saw 2 people on weekday in late may

It was decent, well maintained, I think a bit hard for kids under 8, not very good for bird watching really, you can’t see the water well enough.  We heard lots of birds but saw very few.  Kinda disappointed since it’s recommend for it.  Long walk back to the bathrooms too.  Prob won’t go again for our hobby.  $10 fee to get in.
nice way to clear your head and feel a bit independent
Awesome trail!
Perfect for a nice walk to get the heart pumping! Wasn’t too busy and the weather was great!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Overall Run Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Overall Run Loop is a 8.7 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Bentonville, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: great trail. definitely overgrown as some reviewers have mentioned. had multiple ticks on me half way through. went counter clockwise to end with the views. the waterfall was a trickle in mid July. seen bear skat about halfway through so be careful out there! a midday, weekday hike led to seeing only a handful of other hikers, mainly near trailhead. don't know what I was expecting with the swimming hole, but it was more like a slow moving creek and not tempting enough to warrant a dip for me! quite a few kids/families/camp groups seem to come here for that though. the pooch loved it as well. overall would recommend!

Great hike! A bit overgrown in some places but well worth it if you plan to go swimming in the holes after your hike. One nice lookout with a beautiful view. Pretty rocky at some places but fun to walk.

It was about 9 miles. Arrived at the trailhead at 830am was starting to fill up. You will have to walk about .5 miles to start the trail. There is a small road you walk up, and have to pass over a wire blocking the road. I went counter clockwise. The trail is mark as blue, but will turn to yellow. My phone had no service, neither did a lady that I ran into. You might want to download the map before you go. I only saw 3 people on the trail the whole time. must people seem to just go to the vista, waterfall, and the watering hole. Going counter clockwise you will end with them. It is well worth it.

started the trail around 1030am on a Tuesday, only one other car was parked.  went clockwise up the steeper side and it was definitely a tough 2.5-3 miles up but is well worth the effort the view at the top is awesome.  going down was quick and easy it does get rocky in spots. Only gave this trail a 4 star because it is getting slightly overgrown in spots.  check yourself for ticks they are bad this year, I found 1 on me. also watch for snakes I almost stepped on a 4ft black snake.

Great hike, I went clockwise to get to the falls earlier in the hike. Beautiful trail runs along the creek going  lock wise and counterclockwise with a few creek crossing throughout the hike. Going clockwise is quicker to the falls but the switchback is pretty steep and exhausting getting up. I started the hike at 7am on Saturday and there were already 3 other vehicles in the lot. When I finished at 11:30 there were probably twenty cars parked along the road and people waiting in line to park. I often find trails are rated higher than they should be but this trail deserves the Hard label simply because it’s pretty exhausting, nothing technical though.

It was quite muddy but overall it’s a pretty trail, with lots of river crossings and several beautiful waterfalls.  I found the hike somewhat challenging, as did my pups.  Parking is limited and was full on Easter Sunday.  Otherwise, it was a tough 4.5 mile ascent, and I clocked 8.3 miles total.

We started the trail from the SNP, mp 22.2 parking at the CCC camp above Mathews Arm Campground. Campground was closed so this added 1 mi decent starting and 1 mi ascend ending. Then a long decent on Overall Run Falls trail, beautiful waterfalls and views of Massanuetten Mt. Several creek crossings until we took the Beecher Ridge trail which is a steep incline after already hiking 8 miles. Beecher to Mathews Arm is another 3.5 mile ascend. If you can park at Mathews Arm this loop will be 11 miles, with a steep ascending ending, which ever direction you start. Strenuous return. 
Next time I’d start from Thompson Hollow as recommended by AllTrails, but this is an alternative approach.
Beautiful hike! Spent most of it in a cloud! Be prepared for some river crossings, though great logs to walk across on! Would recommend.
Well kept but muddy

5 stars for the second half. First half is nice. just nothing noteworthy. uphill. rocky. but the moment you hear water, it does not stop to the end and it's incredible. spent all day there frolicking lol. great day hike. parking sucks.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Whitehouse Overlook via Piedmont Overlook Trail Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Whitehouse Overlook via Piedmont Overlook Trail Loop is a 4.6 mile moderately trafficked loop trail located near Paris, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is accessible year-round.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
A very nice hike through wooded, fairly steep terrain.  The paths are well maintained, and fairly heavily traveled. This is a very popular park, so you can expect to run into other hikers here, especially on the weekend. There are many trails in the area to choose from, ranging from less than a mile to a loop of about 8 miles. The park trails connect up to the Appalachian Trail, south of where it heads into Ashby Gap.

This hike covers a popular loop: up the Gap Run Trail to the North Ridge Trail, then down the South Ridge Trail. Most of the trails are well shaded by tree cover, though there are a few nice scenic overlooks that are open. 

There are many facilities here, but the park is mainly geared towards hiking.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Trailhead is down at the Visitor's Center.
reviews: This was a great hike, but a little confusing at the beginning. There are a few trails that all inner connect and branch off of the other. The All Trails app takes you down Boston Road trail to start and you don’t see the Piedmont Overlook until the end. Also it was a 5.3 mile and not 4.7. There is a 10.00 parking fee to get into the park and get there early. It was a lovely trail and I highly recommend it!
Nice - scenic. Views from overlooks were ok. Nicely marked. Not difficult.
Nice night.  80s with a breeze. Trail a little overgrown but scent of honey suckle and clover everywhere.
Very nice trail

Excellent hike from Trillium Trail parking lot down the Trillium Trail to Thompson Lake then return on the unmarked path on the north side of the lake to the intersection with the AT. Headed south on the AT to the Trillium Trail and retuned to the parking lot. Well maintained and serene. Lots of wildlife.
Great trail
Very nice loop, but according to my GPS it was  5.2 miles, not the 4.3 (I think) that all trails said it was.
Always fun
Awesome. Was 5.5 miles not 4.6
nice landscape with nice variations between madows, woods and nice views. We did this in a Wednesday afternoon in rain so nobody else on trail.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Buttermilk Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Buttermilk Trail is a 4.5 mile out and back trail located near Richmond, Virginia that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This is a multi-use trail with hikers and bikers sharing the trail. Please be aware of the surroundings.
reviews: Did this in connection to the James river north bank trail for a total of 6.9 miles. What a great area! River and wooded views, some cool historic buildings…. You never get bored on this trail. Highly recommend.
Shade was nice
Trail was lovely. I was surprised it was so undisturbed and natural considering it's so close to Richmond. An amazing trail to jog and bike too!!
2nd time here got lost twice but back track was easy.
Park in the lot by the Belvedere Street trailhead. It was not buggy but there were several bicyclists￼.
You can take a super direct, straight route, or wind through smaller paths. Plenty of nice places to break and take in views of the river or chill on the rocks.
￼￼couldn’t ask for much better conditions

Love the hike! 
- Great for dogs :) 
- Pretty flat hike
- Pretty busy, we ran into a lot of people around the bridges but in the middle is pretty empty 
- Easy hike - nothing "moderate" about it other than the length. 
- Great for trail running
Beautiful but narrow trail with many mountain bikers; poor signage also.
lots of people on the trail today

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Snead Farm Dickey Ridge Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Snead Farm Dickey Ridge Loop Trail is a 3.4 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Front Royal, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Please note that though this trail is easy to follow, certain portions are overgrown. Look out for the farmhouse. From there, stick to the right to stay on the trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. To access Snead Farm Trail, begin on Fox Hollow Nature Trail which starts at mile 4.6. Snead Farm Trail (mile 5.1) may be accessed at the end of Fox Hollow. Park in the Dickey Ridge Visitor Center parking area.
reviews: Really only one view on the trail.  Trees not that interesting vs other trails in area.  Kinda boring.
Nice little hike with a bit of elevation.  Beautiful weather and views.
Nice easy trail, but I veered off.. so wasn’t full loop,  there weren’t any markers to guide.
Had to stop halfway because there was a bear near the middle
It was really nice! Saw a few snakes so be careful!

This is my favorite trail as a local. I combine the Fox hollow loop with this loop and it’s a very nice easy walk. Most of the time I don’t even carry water on this with me. I just take my binoculars and or camera.  Bears seem to frequent or live in the area as I have seen a few bears a few times. The last time was two Cubs and mama so be careful near any Cubs
If you go in the morning just after sunrise, your shoes and legs will get wet.
great trail best one I have done at the national park
