A little bit of everything! Views, wildflowers, power lines, tree tunnels, 10/10.
Great hike

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Apple Orchard Falls Trail

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Glasgow, VA: Head south on the Blue Ridge Parkway for about 15 miles to Sunset Fields Overlook, milepost 78. Trailhead is in the parking area.
reviews: Hard for this overweight, out of shape 53 year old - but I DID IT!
Beautiful!
Downhill all the way to falls then uphill all the way back

This is one of my favorite blue ridge parkway hikes to take people on. It’s fairly easy just down and back and you get to sit by a waterfall at the bottom with a bench and eat. I’ve found it’s a fun one for the late afternoon in the summer because there is the best sunset spot just a few miles north on the parkway at Arnold valley overlook to picnic at after the hike.
It’s also easy to take slow. it took only 2 hours when I went with a friend who barely hikes.

Decent hike to the falls, although harder on the way back (going up). The falls are okay but not good enough to make this a must-do hike. The trail is well-maintained and not very muddy or slick. The trail around the falls had bugs pestering me while I was trying to get some photos. I didn’t really notice bugs on the rest of the trail, but I’m a fast walker. The parking lot can fit about a dozen cars, and parking wasn’t an issue on Sunday morning / mid-day.

Alternate and somewhat shorter route to the lower falls for those who would rather have the moderate uphill hike at the beginning and a much nicer downhill hike out. Road was well maintained and should be passable for any type of vehicle with parking at the bottom.

First time to the falls but I had the impression the water flow was lower than normal. Tough hike back up after viewing the falls but the views of the creek along the way make it totally worthwhile. Parking lot was very full when we completed our hike around 1:00.
Water? Yes. Is the water falling? Appears to be. Is it a dandy? It’s okay. Gracie approves of this one but don’t bet your buck you can get a coffee.

Whew! This was a tough one, but beautiful. I forgot to turn on the app until we were partway down, but after doing the math our total walk was 3.6 miles to the bottom falls and back up. I’m not sure how the stated miles for the trail are determined, but our walk was significantly longer than what is stated. Great hike.

Well kept trail. Be sure to continue past the first set of smaller falls to the 2nd larger falls. And past that is a 3rd overlook. Beautiful wildflower (mountain laurel, rhododendron) in bloom today. Steep trail back up to the parking lot but not awful.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Marys Rock via Pinnacle Picnic Grounds
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Marys Rock via Pinnacle Picnic Grounds is a 6.6 mile out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a great forest setting and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and running. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: Beautiful section of the AT.  Lots of wildflowers in bloom and great views along the way.  Pretty secluded until you get to Mary’s Rock which is more crowded.
Excellent trail.  Great day hike.  Mild bugs so bring spray, can be overgrown but recently whacked.  View wonderful
It was great hike! Trail mark was easy. Good up and down. View from mary's rocks is werth it.
Excellent trail, we were able to do this with our three children 9, 9, and 14 and it was excellent. We also brought our leashed dog who did fine.
This trail was awesome. Clearly marked, well-travelled, moderate climbs and descents with a few great overlooks. I’ll be back.
Nice and clear; great overlook; little confusing with lack of signage; beautiful
Azaleas in full bloom.  Mountain Laurel about to bloom.  Easy hike along maintained portion of AT  with slight elevation change.  Popular.
Fun trail even in the rain and fog.
Fun but rocky. A bit tough on the knees

Beautiful trail! I'd recommend long pants as opposed to shorts as there's lots of tall grasses on narrow trails (tick protection). There's lots of loose rock around pinnacle. The wild flowers were all in bloom. Love this one!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Woodland and River Trail Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Woodland and River Trail Loop  is a 2.5 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near McLean, Virginia that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from June until September. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
This hike features river views, a waterfall, wildflowers, and ruins. Visitors have flocked to Scott's Run for years to witness the spring wildflowers that grow there. Sources say that trail-ing arbutus, Virginia bluebells and trillium blooming on the steep hillsides create a small oasis of rare and fragile plants. Remarkable and rare species grow along the precipitous cliffs, in steep valleys and throughout the mature hardwood forest of very large oak and beech trees, ancient hemlock and wild cherry trees that stand as tall as the oaks.
 
Scotts Run Nature Preserve consists of a rather hilly, wildflower-riddled tract of riverside woodlands scarcely 4 crow-miles northwest of Washington. For songbirds and other wildlife, it's a true sanctuary.
reviews: Nice quite trail

So sad my phone died in the middle of it but this was so amazing and I’m definitely coming back. Definitely a busier trail but soooo worth the views, Secret paths, and lots of nature. The waterfall was my absolute favorite part.
A little muddy but overall an easy hike with great views of the river.
small waterfall and beautiful views! hard steep hill but was worth it. lots of shade and only an hour long.
We love this place
Nice river views with an overlook. Quite a bit of elevation. Wide paths. Fun stream crossings. Harder than expected.

I did more than this one trail because I didn't follow from the app, I walked up the stairs & just started following trails. They have little map guides throughout & painted marks on some of the trees. Trails are clear   & easy to stay on course. Some are more moderate than easy. Recommend making it to the overlook, absolutely beautiful!!
Parts were muddy and it was extremely crowded on the weekend but the wander was lovely. Some parts along the Potomac got rocky and technical.

This trail was not at all what I expected. it was rated as easy, but I found it to be difficult in many areas. This could be due to the recent rain, but the steeper areas turn almost into scrambles. It was also heavily trafficked the day we went.
Muddy trail

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Conway Robinson Blue Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Conway Robinson Blue Trail is a 3.4 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near Gainesville, Virginia that features a great forest setting and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: SEASONAL CLOSURE: This area is subject to seasonal closure due to weather conditions. For more information, please visit http://www.dof.virginia.gov/stateforest/list/conway-robinson.htm.
reviews: Good ride for beginners to gain confidence. Enough features for lower intermediate riders to have fun. watch out for hikers.
easy going for a family hike.
good,easy, family hike
Clear cut with some fallen trees over the path. Several spots get very muddy after minimal rain.
Nice walk through the woods. Got off trail at some point and ended up on the orange trail but still beautiful.
Awesome
little wet and a few trees down across the path but passable. perfect temperature.
Great - short trail
Awesome

Well marked and maintained trail. Very crowded - parking lot was completely full and it was very difficult to find a space to park. Trails were very crowded too. Enjoyed this hike. It was very beautiful and quite flat.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Difficult Run Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Difficult Run Trail is a 9.8 mile heavily trafficked loop trail located near McLean, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is accessible year-round. Dogs and horses are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Great Falls Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, bike, or horseback the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.

Variety is the word to describe this hike.  Descend to Difficult Run and follow it as it winds to the Potomac River.  Enjoy the cool water in summer or view the unusual ice formations in winter.  After a short, steep climb to the ridge, follow the rim of Mather Gorge towards Great Falls - a channel believed to be 180 million years old.  Pass by remains of Matildaville, named by Lighthourse Harry Lee in honor of his wife, and the Potowmack Canal, planned by George Washington and operated for 26 years before being bought out by the Chesapeake and Ohio Co. and abandoned.  Follow the trail as it winds along to Great Falls Park, with overlooks of the falls, and then within a few minutes the Swamp Trail where wild flowers and wildlife abound.
reviews: Great hike. Dog loved it
1st section, off route 7, is pretty muddy and kind of boring. Prettier once you cross Leigh Mill. Not much elevation gain.
Loved it the first time and loved it today again! It is very shaded….specially for days like today 92 degrees! Most of the hike you are  surrounded by water …. The swamp trail is beautiful!

Loved it the first time…. Loved it today!
Even though it was too hot: 92 !!! Enough   
shade that helps !

Such amazing changes of context!!!
The swamp trail is gorgeous!
Was good but not amazing. Still recommended
Scout hike. Shakedown for Philmont.
With Amanda
Muddy with difficult river crossings.

The Difficult Run Trail is really composed of a few different trails. You need to know these in advance. The loop is very poorly marked. We got off trail more than a few times. Luckily I had my AllTrails app. Also, for those who are COVID exposure sensitive, the loop (Ridge Trail I think) is HEAVILY trafficked. My recommendation, and what we'll do next time is spend more time on the less trafficked, more quiet side trails. Grand total for hike was 11 miles (due to unintended detours). Weather was super and a great way to spend a Saturday.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Scott's Run River Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Scott's Run River Trail is a 2.3 kilometer heavily trafficked out and back trail located near McLean, Virginia that features a waterfall and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and nature trips and is best used from April until September. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
reviews: Awesome 30 minute little power walk
Beautiful! Was very muddy after heavy rains but wasn’t too hard to manage. Definitely watch out while hiking along trails close to the river because water is high and fast moving.

Awesome trail with running water 
Kids can do it
Well cleared, few visitors

Beautiful wooded trail, lots of options to add on. Great views of the Potomac and two waterfall overlooks. Trail is not marked well in some spots, definitely keep the AllTrails map handy. Great mix of inclines, flat trails, and some rock scrambles. Doable for kids and dogs. We went early (745am) & there was plenty of parking and the trail wasn't crowded. Lot was packed by the time we left at 10.

Even before I was born, there was a fight to preserve this trial in 1970. I’m glad the preservationist won. The sound of the cicada was deafening as you approach the waterfall. The terrain is varied—naturally occurring fords, hills, exposed rocks and roots. This place is a natural treasure, and an unexpected light workout. Get here if you can ... it is so worth it.
Great trail. Well kept and passable with a 7 and 4 year old. 9:30am the parking lot was already packed!
Beautiful but stinky
Hilly for a hot pup

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Signal Knob Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Signal Knob Loop Trail is a 16.1 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Strasburg, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, bird watching, and horses and is best used from April until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Challenging hike.  Lots of elevation gain over a very rocky path is the core of the difficulty rating.  Nice view of Buzzard Rocks, Fort Hunt Valley, and Strasburg on your way up.  Pack plenty of water as streams may be dry if it hasn't rained for a while.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Strasburg, VA: Take SR 55 east for about 5 miles to Waterlick. Then take SR 678 south for 5 miles to the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area. The trailhead is at the Bear Wallow / Signal Knob parking lot on SR 678 approximately 1 mile north of the Elizabeth Furnace Picnic Area.
reviews:
did it clockwise, nice work out in hot temps!
will do it in winter again
Nice trail, though quite rocky.

The trail was very well marked, and featured some nice views mainly in the first half. As others have said, most of the trail is rocky. But if you wear good footwear, in my view this trail is more moderate in difficulty. I hiked it in 3:45 without pushing too hard. Nice variety of scenery.

I did this trail with a 60lb pack and hiking this trail was a challenge. First this trail is super rocky and having that pack doesnt help. I saw the pictures of the view online and i thought they were good but i didnt see them when i went hiking. The view from the top is great, you can see Strasburg and Winchester from there. There was one section where it was .8 mi straight uphill with about 8 switchbacks which wasnt fun. If you are into hiking and want a challenge do this
Not my thing.
Definitely a pretty hike

Great trail and not that heavily trafficked. Went two Saturdays in a row and ran into very few people. Not much in terms of the outlook but the trail itself is beautiful. It takes you through lots of different foliage which we very much enjoyed. Mostly gentle uphill incline and only got steep for one small section. Would be good for training and there are lots of campsites along the way. Did the entire loop in ~5 hours. Clocked 10.9 miles.
Trail is VERY rocky. Make sure you have the right footwear. Starting to get overgrown in places

Nice challenging hike.  I enjoy the views on the way up more than the return loop.  Fire trail is pretty boring.  Recommend doubling back to maneka peak trail and retuning that way or do an out and back.   Good training hike for longer multi day hikes.
Loved the view. Lots of rocks. I thought it would be very muddy because of the overnight rain, but everything drained really well. I surprised a hawk and a deer along the way.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Mount Rogers Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Mount Rogers Trail is a 20.0 kilometer moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Troutdale, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as difficult. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from February until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This is the Mount Rogers Trail that begins at Rd 603 and ends in Deep Gap. It is all wooded and rocky in places. You can continue on to the summit of Mount Rogers by taking a left at the AT intersection, then taking a left onto the the MR spur trail,  which would be another 2.5 miles.
reviews: Well delineated trail and well marked. A few rock formations on the way but pretty much a walk in the woods like in your backyard.

Lots of flooded sections of trail, not too
 technical. Beautiful scenery the entire hike . And wild horses for the win!

Wonderful trail, I became a fiancée on 4/3/21 on the summit of this AMAZING mountain. But it’s not only a good hike cause of that - just like the reviews said there are 4 different settings/biomes and it’s amazing. The first part (maybe 2mi?) reminded me of Crabtree Falls in VA lots of trees and switchbacks. Second part absolutely the shire, so green and wet and lush. Then you get into the open field with the HORSES (which I love) and then onto that Pacific Northwest vibe with tall evergreens (it smelled so good here) and snow and ice....even in April. You get some views when you get close to the top but the real magic is the summit and the markers under all those beautiful green trees....this is where my man proposed to me while we ate lunch on a big rock. It was absolute magic. It hurt like hell coming down but we plan to camp the next time we return. Talked to lots of friendly hikers even met some hiking the AT....my first time on the AT.....11/10 highly recommend, we’ll be coming back for the rest of our lives until we can’t make that 13 miles anymore LOL. (It is much closer to 13 than 12.6 - 6.5 up and down!)
Good incline. Flooded when it’s raining. Stayed at Thomas Knob near by
Long trail. One or two views max. Lots of mountain springs (in March at least).

This is a serious mountain.  Alltrails says 12.4 roundtrip, but the signs put it at 13.  We saw very few people out on the trail today, not suprising as temperature was hovering around 20 at the top.

The first half of the trail is your typical woodlands trail: gently ascending, flat, dirt, very few roots or rocks.  About halfway in you will notice a change where you will pass through about a mile of moss-covered rocks and boulders, with numerous streams crossing the trail.  Then the second half becomes significantly more difficult, with a lot of roots and rocks to navigate.  You will make a giant counter-clockwise loop to get to the top of the mountain.  On the way, you will pass through an enormous pasture that affords some truly spectacular views.  Here is your best place to see the wild horses.  We saw 6 today.

The summit itself is baffling in that there is nothing there.  Nothing.  You're lucky if you can even find one of the brass discs put there by US Geological Survey.  The summit is also completely covered by spruce trees, and has no views of any kind as a consequence.  We nearly froze our fingers off just wolfing down our sandwiches.  The state of Virginia really should do something here: a plaque or a marker or something would be nice...an observation tower would be great!

We made it up in about 3.5 hours and down in about 2.5 hours.  We were really tired on the way down.  Most of the way down we ran into 3 wild horses, which really boosted our mood.

All in all, it's a mediocre mountain.  Really not much of a reason to do it other than to check off another high point.  But the wild horses are a very nice added bonus.
Decent uphill climb throughout with great scenery, not great views, and a meh summit. Look out for bear droppings and mice!

Didnt make it all 12 miles. Only did 8 of the 12. The first part of the trail winds through the hard woods. Once you get to the 3 mile mark you find some ever greens and big rocks. No awesome view from where I was but only saw one person all day. Peaceful walk through the woods and to top it off a couple navy jets ripped by even with the trail. Was cool. The only thing to note is the trail is covered in leaves. Makes seeing the rocks on the down hill hard so watch your step

Super pretty trail! Found this to be on the easy side, other than the many rocks and roots. The covering of fallen leaves makes it a bit tougher now, so just watch your steps!

Not much for views until you get to mile 5ish, but it’s still super fun to watch the flora and weather change on your way up. I started in the fog at 7AM, hit the summit right around 10AM and had amazing sun on the way down. Took me just under six hours round-trip.
Great trail. Nice sights once you get out of the trees.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Devils Fork and Devils Bathtub Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Devils Fork and Devils Bathtub Loop Trail is a 11.7 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Fort Blackmore, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, and bird watching and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Scenic hike to the Devil's Bathtub, a scoured rock formation within Devil's Fork Creek. Hike follows the creek closely along its entire course, crossing the creek multiple times and passing several scenic swimming holes, rock formations, and waterfalls. This hike continues beyond the Devil's Bathtub, climbing the mountain and returning to the original trailhead. Beyond the Bathtub, however, the trail is much less maintained and may be difficult to follow in some seasons.

Overcrowding at the Devil's Bathtub has become a problem, exacerbated by hikers ignoring No Trespassing signs and parking along private property when the trailhead parking area becomes full. Please be aware that ALL areas outside of the signed parking area at the trailhead should be considered private property and should not be used for parking. Access to the trailhead is only allowed through an easement from a private landowner, and disregard for property owners' rights by visitors can strain this relationship.

If you arrive at the trailhead and the parking area is full, consider going somewhere else: Little Stony Falls or the Guest River Gorge are alternative hikes, both of which are nearby, have similar scenery to the Bathtub.

This swimming hole is prone to flash flooding. For this reason, please do not attempt the trail if the water is above your knees.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.tips:
- Getting to the Bathtub is not an easy stroll to a swimming hole - it is a difficult backcountry hike involving some skill at route-finding and multiple stream crossings. People can (and frequently do!) get lost and/or injured when they attempt to hike to the Bathtub in poor weather conditions, without enough daylight remaining, or without proper experience or preparation. In short, this is NOT a good choice for a first backcountry hike. Always hike at your own risk, and consider taking some easier hikes in the area first to become familiar with the demands of backcountry travel if you are inexperienced. Above all, be smart and come prepared when attempting this trail. If you don't know what good hiking preparation entails, it may be best to choose an easier hike.

- While often easily navigated, the multiple stream crossings on this trail may require significant wading at high water and may even become treacherous during extremely high creekflow. Even at low water levels, some creek crossings are technical and cannot be made dry-shod. Use caution and good judgment before attempting any creek crossings in wet weather.

- Steep terrain and heavy forest cover along this trail may prevent adequate wireless internet access and/or reduce accuracy of smartphones' GPS while on the trail. Your location on the map may therefore not be precisely accurate if tracking your progress directly on the trail. As with all online guides, the information contained herein should only be used for educational purposes and not for use in backcountry navigation or as a substitute for a trail map, planning, and good judgment.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Fort Blackmore, VA: Head northwest on Rt. 619. Travel approximately 3 miles to the trailhead.
reviews: I did the full loop, counter-clockwise, and if you’re looking for a satisfying hike that’s the way to go.  In and out the other way is better if you’re just wanting to have a look and a swim and head back home.  The first bit up the mountain is a bit of an uphill slog, then a gentle descent, very enjoyable.  It was fairly damp, muddy, and rocky so lots of watch-your-step moments.  The Bathtub area itself is indeed picturesque and a lovely respite after the main hike.  Stream crossings on the way out were easily navigated without getting feet wet this year at mid-July; water was not high so rock crossings were not terribly difficult.  I wore trail shoes and would recommend them if you’re doing the full loop.
Awesome. Not sure why they call it Devils Bathtub. only God could make something that Beautiful.
Amazing! Veered right at the loop, and it was perfect. All the work on the front end, and lovely decent. The bathtub and creek crossings are amazing! Do the whole loop!

The hike to the bathtub was great. 5 stars. The back half was a 3. So 4 overall. I would recommend hiking the bathtub and to three forks waterfall, then turn and walk back the way you came in. But the basin and bathtub are stunning. Recommend water shoes.

The loop is fairly washed out on the side without the devil’s bathtub. Loved it, will do it again. Be careful as the parking for the trail is very small and the road is very washed out, so no compact cars.

The bathtub did not look as good as it does in the pictures online.  The blue wasn't as visible because of the fast moving water.  I think the pictures were taken when the water level was lower.  Still really cool though.  

I recommend turning around at the 3 forks waterfall which is a little past the bathtub.  The waterfall is really cool and there is nothing to see in the 5 remaining miles.

I thoroughly enjoyed the hike to the bathtub. The Devil's bathtub was gorgeous  with its turquoise and clear waters and surrounding scenery. Just past the bathtub is a gorgeous waterfall too that I highly recommend. We completed the whole loop but in the future I would probably just hike to the Devil's Bathtub and then to see the waterfall then turnaround as the scenery wasn't as beautiful beyond that. I will say that it was a challenge to hike through the rugged terrain for 5 miles through.

It was a great experience for family hike. The youngest liked it so much that they said they want to go more on such hikes.  There were 10 water crossings on each side of the shortest way to the bathtub. (We took the left at the fork which had a sign indicating 1.5m to bathtub). We appreciate the intel fellow hikers gave us on their way out. We also appreciate the gentlemans’ note that we were enjoying the waterhole and that the bathtub was just the other side of it. The hiking experience to the waterhole and the bathtub was awesome. The weather was superb. The rocks along either coast were picturesque. The trail itself was not hard. The only thing we could not figure out was how to get to the other side of the shore at devils bathtub. We did an out and back. It was about 5.5miles from and back to parking lot. It is a must experience trail and waterhole. Water crossings on our way back felt deeper. Water is absolutely clear and refreshing. It was totally fun.
Really cool hike. Loved the swimmable natural springs. Someone installed a rope where you can swing from which was perfect. Definitely leave before sunset because the valley cools quickly.
This was an amazing trail! There are quite many creek crossings and is difficult for beginners. Recommend 10/10

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Mount Rogers Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Mount Rogers Loop Trail is a 30.6 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Mouth of Wilson, Virginia that features a river and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, camping, nature trips, and backpacking.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Start at Grayson Highlands State Park Overnight Backpacking Parking
reviews:
Did the trail plus Mt Rogers summit over 2 days staying at Old Orchard and going counter-clockwise. Liked having nice vistas on the 2d day. Saw lots of ponies approaching and at Scales.  Old Orchard is a small shelter but there are literally dozens of good, flat campsites at or very near the shelter (three separate stone fire rings with makeshift benches) so don’t be concerned if you hear on the trail (as I did) that there are tons of people at the site. It had good, steady water when I was there. Best way to find it is to start at the shelter and follow the blue blaze trail downhill to the right (facing the shelter). 

If you go counter-clockwise remember that the directions on the All Trails map assume you are going clockwise. So if they say “Go right” at a junction it means you should go left.  

Someone made a huge directional “arrow” on the ground with logs at All Trails way point #7 at the junction of the Cliffside Trail and the Lewis Fork Trail that implies that everyone should turn left (again, if you are coming uphill on the Cliffside Trail from Old Orchard traveling counter-clockwise on the loop). But to get to the Mt Rogers Trail you actually need to turn right on the much smaller trail (Lewis Fork Trail) rather than the fire road type trail to the left indicated by the log “arrow”. The connection to the Mt. Rogers trail (to the right) is also NOT listed on the posted wooden sign — but that is the way to go (Lewis Fork Spur).  If you are going clockwise you should ALSO ignore the “arrow” which implies you should go straight at the junction rather than turn left and go downhill on the Cliffside Trail (as All Trails indicates).
Overall well marked. Plenty of horses to see. Trekking poles a must for terrain changes. Plenty of water access.

We did this loop in reverse over Memorial Day weekend and had horrible weather the first two days,  but the third day was glorious....challenging climgs, but scenery was fantastic!  We saw lots of wild ponies and there were many spots to get water along the way.
Awesome!!!!
Absolutely beautiful. The wild ponies make this a near one-of-a-kind hike.
Love it! Enjoyed a surprise visit with the ponies!

Absolutely amazing hike, my favorite in Virginia. I took the loop clockwise and camped on Wilburn Ridge night one. That seemed to be the pony hot spot. The hike was difficult but doable, especially if you give yourself multiple full days. I would maybe do it the opposite direction next time so you are rewarded with a ton of ponies and amazing views towards the end.

Make sure you reserve your spot at Grayson Highlands State Park. If not you can start Elk Garden and hike 2 miles into to the loop along the AT. awesome camping spots, beautiful sites, The ponies made the trip

Hiked with my 13yr old daughter as our annual backpacking. We went clockwise from the 28th of March to the 30th and started late (5pm) after arriving from the coast. Made it just under Wilburn Ridge (going clockwise) before hail and dark chased us into our tent. Through the night and in the morning, 25mph+ winds blew out the clouds and brought a 24deg.F wake-up call (feels like 11) to frozen boots and frozen water in the water bottles. We waited till later to climb out of bags and get moving, so we had to adjust the loop, which is one of the great things about this loop, there are so many options. Download and you can’t go wrong. Also, pretty solid camping anywhere along the loop. Just have to hunt more in some places than others. So many camp spots we’d like to return to. The other great thing was the change in scenery between the AT of Wilburn Ridge and the AT around Scales. Gorgeous highland views on one and more regular firs, rhododendron, creeks and woods on the latter. Only negative, the trails flow like creeks with rain, so the trip was a bit muddy, but a small irritation compared to the beauty. The bulk of the pony herds seemed to be near Scales where we watched them play and meander from our tent in the morning. Horse droppings are plenty, so watch where you gather water and play it safe. Going clockwise sets up some climbs coming out, but manageable. Great area. Great loop(s). Can’t wait to come back for other variations!

Challenging loop especially in the mud and rain. Went in 3/28 from Lewis Fork Spur, up Mt Rogers Trail, to the Thomas Knob Shelter on AT for 7 miles total. Woke up to frozen boots and 25°. Moved a good chunk day two along the AT in the ice, mud and wet with beautiful weather to Old Orchard Shelter (good water and plenty of camp sights). Finished up with an easy day.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Ball's Bluff Red and Orange Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Ball's Bluff Red and Orange Loop is a 3.7 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Leesburg, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking and running and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: There are many trails in this park if you wish to extend or shorten your hike.
reviews: Lots of trees down, but a nice hike.
Beautiful well marked trail. I’d say moderate given the steep ups and downs with loose gravel.
Our dog's first hike! We noticed a few of the color coded trails cross paths, thus causing us to switch colors a few times. Overall enjoyable.
Well marked. Lots of trails.
Great trail. Many different ways to hike. Bug repellent recommended.
Very nice loop.  Some up and down.  Trail markings not the best, but very quiet.  We will  definitely be back.
Trail leads to several beach areas on the river. Easy hike with numerous sign posts about the battle here. Saw a red fox up in the rocky cliff staring back at us.
Nice hike with several historical sites and informational signs.  Nice trails that would be great for running. Bring bug repellent!
Great mix of waterfront shade and sunny fields
Not many people. Lots of up and down.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Hanging Rock
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Hanging Rock is a 11.7 kilometer moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Roseland, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, rock climbing, camping, and backpacking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This hike is part of the Three Ridges backpacking/camping trail and follows along the AT to a viewpoint. It has a pretty steady incline the majority of the way up but the view from Hanging rock is definitely worth it. Hike back is mainly downhill so it is recommended to take trekking pole/stick for the rocky parts of the trail. This trail can be hiked year round, but in the winter it can be icy and will be more challenging.
reviews: The trail is very rocky which makes this hike especially challenging but the view at Hanging Rock is totally worth the effort.
This was a beautiful hike and the view at the top was great! Saw a rattlesnake and black snake on the trail, so keep your eyes peeled.

This trail is a great balance… active terrain, moderate inclines, vegetation and then a beautiful pay off at the summit!! The trail is well marked throughout. Did encounter a rattlesnake (see pics)… Kept a safe distance and went around. One of my favorite trails to date.
Amazing trail! Highly recommend!
It was great.
This hike is absolutely great. It’s a good workout along with every type of hike you can do. The views at the summit is beautiful. Is a must do.

Great day to be in the woods.  Trail was not crowded- a few day hikers and a few through hikers start to show up. Views great from hanging rock. Less so along the way. ￼￼ rhododendrons and Mountain Laurel in full splendor. ￼
Beware of rattlesnakes!

This is my new favorite hike in the area.  I just loved the broad rock viewpoint with gorgeous sights.  We had it all to ourselves for 30 minutes for lunch last Tuesday.  Moderate is a good rating for this hike- nothing like the Priest.  It took us 3 hours 50 minutes (not including lunch) with a 9 year old, 14 and 16 year old.  I was concerned that going back up the ridges coming back would make it difficult, but it was not a problem.  The change in terrain made it interesting.  We will definitely be doing this again.  We didn’t go to the actual summit, because other reviewers said it was tree covered and my son was disappointed.  So next time we’ll do it so we can look back at the top and say we’ve been there.
Nice Moderate up and down hike with some pretty views for a reward.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Appalachian Trail: Jones Run Trail to Pinefield Gap
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Appalachian Trail: Jones Run Trail to Pinefield Gap is a 11.7 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Crozet, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and walking. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: Did it clockwise and it was easy. The nice parts of the trail are more or less concentrated between the falls on Doyle creek and Jones Run. Otherwise pretty much green tunnel with some nice spots along the creeks. The AT and the fire road sections are pretty forgettable. Would venture to guess that views are good in the winter but they’re obstructed now. Tons of dead little larvae that resemble centipedes at the falls. Curious to know what they are.

As a 67 y.o., moderately fit, occassional hiker I would rate this trail easy EXCEPT for the mile between Jones Fall and Upper Doyle.  Pretty challenging in terms of steepness; prob took me 45 mins for that mile.  15 min break at Upper Doyle.  Glad I went counter clockwise as the 1.8 mile end on the fire road is relatively flat.

trail was in good shape and like others said, better when traversed counter clockwise.  finishing uphill on the fire road was way better than finishing uphill on a rock scramble.  there was nothing wrong with the fire road either - heard lots of birds and saw lots of foliage. the falls were pretty although this time of year there wasn't much water.
Very dry today, but still beautiful.

Great hike! Be advised the NPS labels this as the Browns Gap loop and it is marked as moderately strenuous. I did it clockwise as my NPS map recommended, and it meant some pretty steep/longer climbing toward the end before meeting up with the AT. The Jones River waterfalls was my favorite though, so it was nice to have that one last.
Beautiful!

Love this loop. Hiked it in the winter and spring - it was interesting to see the different water levels. Counter-clockwise is the way to go, although the fire road and AP seems a bit boring after the beautiful trails by the streams. Clocked in 7 miles in about 3 hours - the info board states estimated time as 5 hours which is very odd.
This trail was absolutely amazing! So many waterfalls along the way!! Highly recommend!!

Beautiful trail! Don’t be scared off by the “moderately strenuous” marking on NPS website. Followed what other reviews said and went counter clockwise and it was great. Easy descent to the falls and a leisurely ascent to finish. We wound up extending our hike a few miles by continuing on Doyle’s trail until it connected to the AT rather than taking the fire road and that was well worth the extra mileage! Beautiful trails with lovely wildflowers in the spring. The falls were breathtaking. Did all 8.5 miles with our 18 lb pup and it was a great day for everyone! About 4.5 hrs hiking total. Make sure you do a thorough tick check afterward! We found a few hitching a ride on our dog and on ourselves.

Fantastic trail. We went counter clockwise and it was worth it. 
 Looking forward to going back in the summer.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: River and Matildaville Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: River and Matildaville Trail is a 6.0 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Great Falls, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, nature trips, and bird watching and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Great Falls Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, bike, or horseback the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: View along the River was nice. Overlooks were beautiful
Nicely maintained and marked trail. Stunning views of the river along the way!
Fabulous. Easy but good exercise. Fabulous views.
Loved it! Amazing views :)
Amazing views of the Potomac River. Easy hike for all hikers.
Shorter than I thought, but can add trails and length wherever. River trail was way more fun along the falls, doable for an active dog too!
Wonderful day. Get there early!!  Always more for those who want more!!  Happy hiking!!
Trails don’t match very well. You have to find the marked trail. Very untouched but worth it
Beautiful river views on the River Trail and soo peaceful on the Matildaville Trail. Wonderful bird songs, snakes, deer, wildflowers.
Not bad sort of easy and has rocks you have go up. Great views!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Lewis Spring Falls Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Lewis Spring Falls Trail is a 4.5 kilometer loop trail located near Stanley, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and walking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Front Royal, VA: Skyline Drive travels the entire length of Shenandoah National Park. Mile markers are placed along the right-hand side of the road heading south. They are numbered from north to south beginning at the northern terminus in Front Royal, Virginia. Facilities, trails and park features use the mile markers as points of reference. Park at milepost 51.2 in the Big Meadows area. Look for the amphitheater where below, you will find a trail post for Lewis Spring Falls.
reviews: Went on a Saturday. Great hike — not nearly as popular or crowded as Dark Hollows, White Oak, etc., with plenty of parking near the Big Meadows amphitheater. Agree with others that counter-clockwise is the easier way to go. Starts with moderately steep, long descent that could be challenging coming the other way. Very rocky trail, so definitely recommend boots, not sneakers. The falls are a bit underwhelming. Definitely go across the rocks and find the metal railing and overlook for the best vantage point. From there, it’s a long and steady, but manageable, incline. Take the short spur up to the Black Rock Mountain overlook; it’s pretty close to the end and well worth the extra effort. After that it’s an easy .5 mile or so to the end.
Falls we're a bit disappointing, but the trail itself was fine
I liked the summit view on the loop better than the falls. Still a nice hike!
Good hike.  Wish we could see the falls from down below.￼

Not sure about the clockwise vs counter clockwise debate. I went clockwise and it was a pretty tough go, going up for so long. Kind of regretted not going counterclockwise, guess I'll have to do it again to see! When you get to the falls, you have to cross the wet rocks to get to the other side. You'll see a handrail to get to the look out. Great views of the valley, the falls are deec. Definitely worth a little challenge for an inexperienced hiker.
Easy trail, kind of disappointing when you get to the falls. Vey rocky to get to the overlook. Can't really see the face of the waterfall.

it's amazing the amount of people we saw going down to the falls in Sandles, zip up dress boots, running shoes,etc... my advice, good boots, healthy legs and lungs. The falls and views were worth it! Remember as far as you go down you have to come back up!

Trail was solid. I took the advice of some other hikers on this thread and went clockwise around the loop. I don’t know if they made a typo, or if they meant to send me through ascension hell. Lol! Descending clockwise is a very slick and rocky road. And the ascension after you reach the bottom is straight up. I thought the falls were going to be the reward for this hike but there is a rock outcropping that is simply amazing with its views. I like the trail, challenging but in the best way.￼￼
Nothing terrible about this hike. It was quite nice for this area. During this time of year, most trees were relatively barren/brown.

took this trail counter clockwise, was very rocky on the path down to the falls, took the AT back to the parking area was fairly easy. there is a trail that leads over the water to a viewpoint for the falls

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Hightop Peak Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Hightop Peak Trail is a 4.8 kilometer heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Elkton, Virginia that features a great forest setting and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and bird watching and is best used from April until October.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: The uphill part (the whole way, really) was indeed very steady and challenging for me. My phone reported the gain was more like 3k, which doesn’t seem right, but 900 might be low too. View was worth it in any case.
Well-traveled trail with beautiful north-facing lookout on the top. Pretty consistent and steady incline to the top. Some rock sections in the middle.
I highly recommend this hike! There's a gorgeous overlook and stunning views!

I've hiked this trail twice now - during the drier foliage season it offers a great view of the GW forest at the top. However the most recent time was very foggy so while the hike up was nice & eerie the view didn't come through. The trail itself will get your heart pumping but isn't super strenuous.
You’re going up, but doable. I’d say this is moderate. View is beautiful

Humid, so very humid. This trail is basic, lots of dirt lots of green kind of feels like you’re in a tropical jungle with the humidity. Decent incline steadily rising. Too foggy to see anything so can’t report any views. Another upside is it’s right near a park entrance so it saves some windy driving time!
great hike. came on a Saturday at around 830 and trail was pretty empty. had the overlook to ourselves for 10 min. nice steady, muddy incline on the way up
Quick 2 hr up and down trail with great view of GW Forest to east.
Beautiful and peaceful. Definitely gives you a good sweat as it’s all uphill. Had the top to myself! Ate lunch, journaled, and read for a bit before heading down. So worth it!
Awesome trail. AT trail all the way up to overlook. Little rocky at times. If it’s been raining will be slick

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Belle Isle Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Belle Isle Trail is a 2.7 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Richmond, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and mountain biking and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
The suspension bridge over James River is just the first thing you will be amazed by as you wander to and around Belle Isle. There are several other, more narrow and uneven paths within this loop to explore.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are designated accessible spaces in the paved or unpaved parking lots off of Brown's Island Way at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at the suspension bridge), packed gravel, or natural (dirt, roots, etc.), and typically 3 to 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep (8-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.1, 0.6, and 1.4 miles when going counterclockwise. 

Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.
reviews: Lots of people on the rocks in the James River.
Easy going. Went through a small movie shoot on the river bank
Easy loop with beautiful views! You can also chill on the Rocks by the river if you need a break. Highly recommend!
Great walk with lots of spots to sit on the rocks near the water.
Beautiful and historic!
Great for a dreary day since it wasn’t crowded. Plenty to see, easy walk, bridges and rapids.
Saw quite a few snakes in the water!  Gorgeous hike and great swimming holes.  Also significantly cleaner than some other parts of the river
Beautiful!
made a loop with Potterfield bridge
Graffiti

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: White Rock Falls Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: White Rock Falls Loop is a 7.6 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Montebello, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Users have reported that cell service is poor in the area. It is recommended that you download offline maps prior to arriving at the trailhead to avoid getting lost.

Starting at BRP MP 18.5 Parking.  Proceed on the White Rock Gap Trail for 0.4 miles. Turn left at the marker to hike 1.7 miles along the Slacks Trail. The Slacks Trail is mostly level, meandering through a hardwood forest.  The trail is popular with mountain bikers, so keep aware. There are a few views through the trees, but no notable stops.  Head to the Slacks Overlook Parking and cross the road. Head a bit left to find the entrance to the White Rock Falls Trail. Hike downward through numerous mountain laurel and rhododendron, crossing several wood bridges over the stream. As you gain elevation, look for  several great views from the rocks on your left. The trail will start to descend sharply as you near the falls.  After the first major switchback, look for the spur trail to the upper falls, just past the large rock overhang. The 40 ft falls base has plenty of rocks and pools for resting and wading, not deep enough for a full swim.  Retrace the spur back to the main trail - the stream bed drops off and is too dangerous to maneuver.  The trail has its most significant elevation drop for the next half mile until it crosses the stream.  The remainder of the trail is mostly gentle ups and downs, passing through what was once a beautiful hemlock grove.  Look for some sweet views of The Priest as you continue on the White Rocks Falls Trail back to the parking area.
reviews: Great hike but HOT and humid! Waterfalls are nice but not much water this time of the year.
Beautiful hike and the falls are absolutely magical!

Not the most interesting hike in terms of things to see but a decent hike nonetheless. Trails are clearly marked but quite overgrown in places. Consider wearing pants to avoid scratching up your legs. Plus there’s quite a bit of poison ivy￼

Great trail with a of open vistas, waterfalls, and narrower ethereal paths thru the forest. Also a nice mix of steeper inclines and flatter ground to give your legs a break. Did it with our dog and he loved it. Parking at the trailhead on Saturday afternoon was surprisingly easy. Beautiful ride out to the trail on the blue ridge parkway, too. Overall one of our favorite trails in this area and will definitely do again!

This loop combines three separate trails: The "White Rock Gap" trail, the "Slacks" Trail, and the "White  Rock Falls" Trail. We went counter-clockwise. Liked hitting the falls after the walk in the woods portion of the "Slacks" trail. Agree with previous reviewer that the first short bit on the "White Rock Gap" trail doesn't add much except distance to the overall loop.  Next time we'll start with the leftmost trailhead from the parking lot, a shortcut to the "Slacks" trail. The "Slacks" portion is just a nice walk through the woods with a couple nice views, but this time of year it really stands out thanks to the beautiful Mountain Laurels flanking both sides of the trail in dense clusters at points. Beautiful!

After the "Slacks" portion ends at a parking lot cul-de-sac off Blue Ridge Parkway, it can be a bit confusing to find the "White Rock Falls" trailhead ... head left following the road from the parking area back to Blue Ridge Parkway ... head left on Blue Ridge Parkway and look for wooden stairs on the right side of the road. The spur to the main falls was after   the few rocky lookout spots (when going counter-clockwise). Not a lot of space to spread out but a worthwhile stopping point if it's not too crowded. Near the end there is a stream crossing with another great opportunity to enjoy the cool water and lots of space to spread out of it's crowded. 

We took our Giant Schnauzer on this hike ... his very first ... and he did surprisingly well. Great hike for dogs ... he loved cooling off in the cool stream water. Lots of other dogs on the hike, too.

Amazing trail. I did it with my pup counterclockwise. The falls and little swimming hole is just 1.4 miles in if you go that way. I wanted to get the steeper part out of the way first. Some elevation gain and switchbacks that weren’t too terrible, a nice workout, and then smooth sailing from there! Multiple points to access the water but you have to walk just a little bit off the trail on not as well-maintained side trails￼￼. Tons of blooming mountain laurel and azaleas along the whole trail (early June). Highly recommend! Wasn’t too crowded. We started at 9 and there were maybe 5 cars. Many more by noon though. Saw maybe a total of 12 people the whole way.

Absolutely gorgeous, forested trail with streams, blooming spring flowers, and some nice views. We went counterclockwise and found the hike to be easy-moderate with a nice lunch spot by the falls. The falls are not on trail, so keep an eye on the off-trail routes. The falls we found were secluded (about 3-5 min off trail) that had a few orange blazes leading to it. 

If you’re looking for an epic view, I’d suggest humpback rock up the street. But if you’re looking for a pleasant walk in the woods, this is the trail!

Nice hike! The most beautiful views for me were between the falls and the slacks overlook. I went clockwise because I don’t like ending my hike with an uphill, and it wasn’t so bad. It was steep along the falls, but then had a nice cruise the last two miles or so. The slacks trail was a nice wooded trail with gorgeous blooms in the spring, but if you are looking for overlooks, you won’t get many on that side of the trail. Heard reports of rattlesnakes from other hikers but thankfully saw only a small harmless brown snake. All in all, a nice hike.
Absolutely no signal on this trail! Took it counter clockwise and am glad I did. Definitely look for little off trails and take them to see many little waterfalls. A good range of views!

I hiked this trail CCW early on a Saturday morning in early May and loved it! There were very few people on the trail so it made for a very peaceful hike. The terrain was fairly easy to hike with a few more significant slopes, step-like areas, and one stream crossing spread across the trail. Given the time of year, some of the local flora was beginning to bloom which made for a subtle yet pleasant fragrance in the air. There were a number of impressive views of the surrounding mountains. My favorite part of the hike was the creek, which I discovered could be accessed from several somewhat hidden trail spurs. Keep an eye out for these spurs because they take you down to the creek where you can see several small yet still graceful waterfalls. Some of the terrain in this area was a little more challenging and there were certainly spaces where you could risk falling, so it’s probably a good idea to hike with someone else as a precaution. The trail seemed to get more active later in the day as I noticed more and more groups passing by me as my hike approached the later morning hours. All in all, this is a great hike!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: White Oak Canyon Trail to Upper Falls Overlook
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: White Oak Canyon Trail to Upper Falls Overlook is a 7.9 kilometer heavily trafficked out and back trail located near Syria, Virginia that features a waterfall and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: If you do the full loop it’s 11 miles. You can extend that to hawksbill if you’re really into it. This trail is challenging with almost no flat areas and lots of rocks on the trail that make it easy to sprain an ankle. It’s a crowded trail but very beautiful.
Great hike!  Beautiful river beside you the whole way up, and some pools you can get in to cool off on a hot day.  Wear hiking shoes!! This is a very rocky trail.

Pretty challenging hike in the heat. Taking a swim in the falls on the way up and down was awesome. However, please be aware of your surroundings as best you can. I came across a copperhead right next to my bag when putting my clothes back on after swimming. They’re very hard to see in between the rocks. I got lucky not to be bitten frankly and it’s best to stay directly on the trail.
Amazing, rocky and steep!

Beautiful and scenic! Definitely a nice workout and the final waterfall is rewarding. We went early and there was an overcast from rain earlier. The rocks were super slippery so wear your best shoes for this hike. I look forward to revisiting soon! We saw a copperhead snake so be vigilant!
Enjoyed it. Go early it got crowded around 10:30. Six mile out and back from Boundary trailhead to upper falls.
Mildly difficult due to rocks and boulders on trail. Absolutely beautiful trail. So green. Soothing water entire way. Highly recommend
Beautiful hike water falls are everywhere there amazing the only thing is I wish you could camp there.  But overall worth doing!
This is definitely a difficult hike! Bring lots of water. The waterfalls are gorgeous though and the view at Hawksbill is great

What a beautiful trail! We parked in the lower parking lot and hiked up to just under the fire road (white oak canyon 1/2 way mark) and back down. We passed several large beautiful falls and stopped to rest a couple times. Saw many dogs hiking with people. Definitely a moderately rated trail. It took us about 3.5 hours to hike up to the 1/2 way point and about an hour to hike back down. We were just hiking with friends but would bring kiddos who love to hike. We did go after it had rained the day before but felt like the trail was safe enough. There’s not a ton of rock scrambling or anything. The trail is very well traveled.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: River Trail Mini Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: River Trail Mini Loop is a 2.6 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Great Falls, Virginia that features a river and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from April until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Great Falls Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, bike, or horseback the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: Really great trails with wonderful scenic views. Lots of people, but still lots of open trail.
Gorgeous falls
Excellent trail.  Amazing waterfalls.
BEAUTIFUL day for a hike with friends.  Trails are pristine and everything is blooming.

I wish the names of the trails on this App matched the ones at the park. Never saw a sign for River Trail Mini Loop so not sure if we followed it. But the puppy and I explored the easier sections of the park...gorgeous views of the river! A bit muddy in places but otherwise great hike!
Even though the trees were bare, it was still beautiful
lots of rocks to either climb or trip over, fairly steady dodging, but boy were the views worth it
Very crowded today but gorgeous weather
Easy trail beautiful scenery. Many rocky overlooks where you can get a good view of the river from.

Excellent trail that allows you to see the historic remnants of the Potowmack Canal built by George Washington, along with the amazing river views and Falls views. Lots of people in places, but enough overlook areas for everyone to have a place to stop and enjoy. Definitely recommend continuing the short distance down to Canal Cut at Mather Gorge as there are amazing views from the rock outcropping.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Knight, Johnston, and Duval Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Knight, Johnston, and Duval Trail is a 7.6 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Bent Mountain, Virginia that features a lake and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Bottom Creek is a powerful mountain stream that forms a stair-step series of broad-basin waterfalls known as the "kettles." One of the headwater streams of the South Fork of the Roanoke River, Bottom Creek boasts a 200-foot high waterfall. Flanking Bottom Creek are forests of mixed hardwoods (tulip poplar, maple, oak, hickory) and upland meadows. Five rare species thrive in this habitat.

This route is a combination of several trails within the Bottom Creek Gorge Preserve including the Knight Trail, Johnston Trail, and the Duval Trail.

Please note the stream and waterfall may be dry dependent on seasonal weather conditions.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there:
From Roanoke and points north: 

From I-81, take exit #141, Route 419 south, to Salem.
Go south on Route 419 for about eight miles to Route 221 at Cave Spring.
Take winding Route 221 south for 13.8 miles to Route 644.
You will pass through the town of Bent Mountain, then pass an entrance to the Blue Ridge Parkway on your left. About 0.6 miles past the Parkway entrance, turn right on Route 644. 
After 1.1 miles, the road forks. Stay to the right on Route 669.
Continue straight on Route 669. DO NOT turn right on Bottom Creek Road.
After 1.5 miles, you will come to a "Y" intersection. Bear slightly right, staying on Route 669. Travel past the apple farm.
Soon you will be driving alongside Bottom Creek on your left. After 1.3 miles, you will cross a small bridge. Look for the Preserve sign on your left. Turn left at the sign and go up the gravel driveway to the gate.
Park on the side of the road at the gate. Walk about half a mile up the gravel road to the trailheads where you will find another sign and trail maps.

From Blacksburg and Christiansburg: 

Take Route 11/460 northeast to the town of Shawsville.
At Shawsville, turn right on Route 637 (Allegheny Springs Road).
Stay on this road all the way to the first stop sign in Simpsons. [NOTE: after about seven miles, Route 637 turns to the left while Route 653 continues straight. DO NOT turn left on Route 637, but stay straight on Route 653 to Simpsons].
At the stop sign, turn left on Route 610.
At the next stop sign, turn left on Route 221. Stay on Route 221 for about seven miles.
You will pass through the town of Copper Hill. Turn left on Route 644.
After 1.1 miles, the road forks. Stay to the right on Route 669. Follow the above directions from this point.
reviews: Nice hike. A lot of vertical grade to start then levels off.  I did the yellow to red then red.
Met a fantastic new friend, Will, on the hike and we took it together. This trail is magical and gorgeous. Love it every time.

Absolutely breathtaking. The river itself was wonderful, and the waterfall at the end is incredible. The biodiversity of the area was absolutely insane, so many different types of plants and brush. However, because it is a nature preserve, there are no pets allowed and you can’t swim or go fishing or anything like that. The trail itself is very overgrown and bug spray IS recommended because of that. It is also a very strenuous hike, at least if you do the yellow trail (the Knight trail), the red trail (the Johnston) wasn’t nearly as bad, but felt more overgrown. All-in-all, with preparation, this is a wonderful hike.
Not too well marked and we hiked 31/2 miles and never found the falls just heard the rushing stream. Nice paths, Rocky in places but very quiet and pleasant in woods
Beautiful, peaceful trail with lots of diverse views. Not at all difficult to get to the trailhead

Beautiful waterfall, very interesting old cabin and grave yard. The trails were over grown with several down trees. The trail to river was very muddy so we decided to skip that part. The trails are one way direction right now but well marked. We saw a snake, fresh bear poop and lots of bright colored lizards. We will definitely go back in fall when trail isn’t so over grown to check out river. Also no service at all in area.

I love this trail. It’s such a magical spot, full of great plants, fungi, and newts and fish in the pond. Pretty easy hike, great for a relaxing afternoon. I also really appreciate the lack of dogs, as they state at the info kiosk it’s to try to keep the local wildlife from being scared off by the dogs. Not sure what the previous reviewer is complaining about, the dog rule is clearly stated at the top of their website and in the tags here.

The road to the trailhead is definitely really narrow and has a lot of huge potholes, so be aware. Bring bug spray.

No dogs allowed!! This is a horrible place to get to! First of all, I drove almost 2 hrs to get here only to find out that dogs were not allowed! It is terrible that you dont make this more easy to find on your website. How many of us go hiking with our best friends? Most of us who have dogs will take them on hikes AND pick up their poops! This is very upsetting. Please, post that announcement where everyone can see it so that they know and make plans to leave their dogs at home. Second, the road is super narrow and there are signs up everywhere with 'no hunting', no this, no that,,,what is up with this place? Apperantly not very welcoming, but i can understand if you live there and there are a bunch of bad and disrespectful neighbors. Im sure many people have had a great time here, but dont waste your time going there if you want to take your dog with you.
Beautiful trial.

Quite a few blow downs to go around/over/under on the Blue trail. Trails were in good condition but lacked proper signage to indicate one-way travel—lots of hikers going the wrong way due to not knowing about one-way travel. One-way rules are only posted on the map at the first kiosk near the parking area. Great views and lovely forests!

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Osmanthus Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Osmanthus Trail is a 5.0 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Virginia Beach, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and nature trips and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Directions from Norfolk, VA: Take Interstate 64 to Exit 282, Northampton Boulevard/U.S. 13. Continue on U.S. 13 for about 4 miles then turn right onto Shore Drive/U.S. 60 and travel approximately 3-4 miles. The park is accessed from both sides of the U.S. 60. Camping and visitor center is on the left and cabins are to the right. Osmanthus is off U.S. 60 on the right. Go past the contact station and veer left toward the restrooms. Begin on Bald Cypruss Trail for about 100 feet where Osmanthus branches off.
reviews: Mosquito
Plenty of bugs (git some bites) but a picturesque trail! Loved it!
Beautiful walk through the cypress and lowlands. Wide trails able to push a jogging stroller through.
Nice easy trails. Well kept, the swamps are pretty cool
Very swampy, buggy, and no scenic views. A lot of discarded poop bags along the trail also. Good for beginners not advanced

Very Clean!.. one of the best places in Norfolk to get fresh air with nature... everyone respect each other on pathways... great for all ages and they're benches for anyone to sit throughout the trails... I was just jogging and some parts walking... 
$7 to park until sunset and it's worth every penny... I will definitely visit again while I'm in town for school..

Great trail & well maintained. Fairly flat and a decent length. Good for running and casual hiking. Be careful when going back to the parking lot because I missed the bridge and had to back track.
0.6mi of the trail are part of the bald cypress trail and then it splits off for a 2.5mi loop
Very nice, well maintained, and amazing scenery.
Rainy and windy
Very nicely kept trail! Not crowded, pine needle / sand floor, lots of swamps. Dog friendly.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Turkey Run Ridge Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Turkey Run Ridge Trail is a 11.7 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Triangle, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking, running, and nature trips and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Prince William Forest Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are $20 per vehicle or $15 per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot or bike the fee is $10 per person. You can also purchase a park specific annual pass for $35.

The first and last sections of this hike are through the deciduous woods of the rolling Piedmont terrain, while the middle section follows the bank of the South Branch Quantico Creek as it tumbles over the rocks cutting its way to the Potomac.  A watchful eye will detect the presence of beavers in numerous spots along the stream.  Although you're not likely to see one of the furry fellows, the indiscriminately felled trees and the pointed stumps are sure signs that they're nearby.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: I-95 south to exit 150B (Triangle-Quantico), with sign for Prince William Forest Park; turn right onto VA 619 and in two blocks turn right onto entrance road for park.  Continue on entrance road to intersection and turn left onto the Scenic Drive.  Follow signs to Turkey Run.
reviews: Fast fitness hike. Trail was great!
It was a nice simple trail. Great way to spend the Sunday morning!!
Nice trail with beautiful gardens
Shading and smooth    AmyK and Andy
Very nice loop, well maintained, and well marked. No wet stream crossings. Lots of up and down but nothing hard. Not busy.
Pretty flowers
Great undulations. Beautiful.
Great!
Beautiful trail in full bloom.
Awesome Hybrid Bike Ride Turkey Trail.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Ridge Trail to Old Rag Mountain
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Ridge Trail to Old Rag Mountain is a 11.3 kilometer out and back trail located near Etlan, Virginia that features a river and is rated as difficult. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, and running.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: Shenandoah National Park charges a fee to enter. Fees are per vehicle or per motorcycle. If you are entering on foot, horse, or bike the fee is per person. You can also purchase a park-specific annual pass. Please check with the park for current rates.
reviews: The bouldering section on the ridge was the most fun I've had in awhile.  going down the fire road was meh but it was better than going up it. Beauty of a day!

It was extremely hard, took us about 7 hours to complete the whole loop. We did have lunch at the top and took many breaks though. The rock scrambling is pretty difficult and and be treacherous so I would make sure you have good weather. Very rewarding at the end
Nice trail. I hiked a trail last week that was considered moderate and this trail was a lot more challenging. I would consider it hard.
amazing  brutal.  but amazing
Much better going up and back down Ridge Trail, to experience the scramble both ways! The fire road is boring and tedious anyway!
Very strenuous...but worth it... make sure to arrive very early ... and be ready to spend 4-5 hours at least

Awesome day for this trail. Not too hot. Mostly shaded in the morning. To be clear, ALL of the SCRAMBLE for Old Rag is on the Ridge trail. It’s easy but uphill for 2.5 miles and then it’s time to scramble. Be prepared to complete the loop. Very few people do the scramble back down. Start with the Ridge trail and then the way down is easy, but a little longer. Don’t be intimidated, the scramble was the most fun, even for someone who is not in great shape. If you can do 6 pull-ups in a hour, you can probably handle the upper body requirements. It helps to be a little flexible or above 5’2”, but don’t let that stop you. One of the best hikes I have done.

Great trail unfortunately couldn’t go all the way to the top because my pup needed help. We made it 2/3 of the way and was still a great hike, but a nice family on their way down said the view at the top is worth it to go back. (Update: I was informed today by a friend that dogs actually aren’t allowed on this trail. Luckily mine was fine along the way and no one we encountered was mad or said anything to me.)

Nice hike! Definitely an uphill trek but totally doable for the first 2/3 of the way. It was icy towards the top so we decided not to summit, ate our lunch in front of a fantastic view and made our way down easily (some muddy/slippery sections). Was a lovely day hike on a forested trail in spite of the ice higher up.
Trail was well-maintained and relatively easy, just a few rocky sections

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Sky Meadows Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Sky Meadows Loop is a 10.9 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Paris, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and nature trips and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This popular trail can be done in many variation with several other connecting trails to explore.
reviews: 9.5 miles, 1640 ft assent. Clockwise from Visitor Center, up Southern trail, across old AT and AT, down Ambassador Whitehouse trail. With Dan & ML, plus 25 Birds. Annetta and Bob led.
First time being here and it was amazing. I loved the view and the hiking trails were moderate for me that was still a challenge. Would definitely visit again
The trail was very overgrown with weeds for about 5 of the 8 miles. We saw a black racer back snake, just a heads up.
More elevation and distance than stated but a good hike. Old trail in the back is not well maintained and overgrown. Pretty views but not as good as some other nearby places.
Fine. Cut in half due to heat/humidity and dinner reservations.
Gorgeous :)
Good!

Great trip.  Turned out to be about 10.5 miles with the offshoot to Whiskey Hollow for lunch. On a hot day I strongly recommend taking the path to the overlook in the morning.  Beautiful, but almost no cover.  Bring lots of water.  The only place we saw with filterable water was near Whiskey Hollow.

I liked the trail, but did not love it. I wanted to run all of it, but there are areas which have challenging inclines. LOL. It is also several trails strung together ( just be aware). I had to use the AllTrails app, so I didn’t get off course. It was a good workout and I ran 90% of it, with the exception of some areas with some rocks and I didn’t want to break a leg, and as mentioned the incline at the start is challenging without a good warmup.
Gorgeous, varied trail with beautiful wildflowers and birds galore.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Massie Gap and Wilburn Ridge Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Massie Gap and Wilburn Ridge Loop is a 3.7 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Mouth of Wilson, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is good for all skill levels. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until November. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
Easy loop with views of the mountains, rock outcroppings, and wild Grayson Highlands ponies.
