Passenger Vehicle Entrance/Parking fees (larger vehicles more expensive):
$7 Mon-Fri
$10 Weekends and Holidays (April-October)

Day use parking is along the road at Massie Gap with overflow at the Visitor Center. Overnight parking is now limited to the Overnight Backpackers Lot and reservations are required. Backcountry camping is not allowed within the state park boundaries, so you must hike onto USFS property before setting up. 

Check the park’s webpage for the most up to date information on reservations, trail status, fees, and requirements at .
reviews: Too rocky to be easy.  Few views.
Gravel-y start to the left.  Make the extra off trail climb to the top of the rocks.  It’s worth it!  Nice day at 58 degrees

Very far from what I expected, so I’m bummed I wasted my last day at Grayson Highlands doing this one. A good 60% of the trail is wooded and/or without much of a view or ponies. 

The only good section is the rhododendron trail section because you’re on the top of the mountains and there are always ponies. It’s rocky, gravely, full of roots, and again - no views. 

I strongly suggest the Wilburn Ridge trail over this one. So disappointed.

Easy hike. We had fun climbing the rocks and taking in the views. Got to see two small herds of ponies. A baby pony was curious about our dog and came right up to him, then as he walked back to his mom he came right up to me. Highlight of my trip! We also enjoyed a picnic lunch. I highly recommend this hike if you are an animal lover.
Loved the views
Beautiful hike today.  Windy but clear and sunny.  Lots of ponies to see.  Can’t wait to come back to see more of the park.
Ponies!!
You’ll have an amazing view the whole time, you just need to look up. Lots of rocks and a steady incline. Took me 2 1/2 hours to get to Mt. Rogers and 2 1/2 back including the extra loop.
Awesome!!! Loved seeing the wild ponies and fun boulders to climb, too. Great views! A little busy on a Monday afternoon during spring break.
We had a great time on this sunset hike, even with parts of the trail being essentially underwater. Beautiful area as always.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Kennedy Peak Loop
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.region: George Washington and Jefferson National Forests
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Kennedy Peak Loop is a 15.3 kilometer heavily trafficked loop trail located near Fort Valley, Virginia that features beautiful wild flowers and is rated as moderate. The trail offers a number of activity options and is best used from March until October. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description:
This hike to Kennedy Peak includes an old fire tower that provides a 360 view of the entire area.

Follow the orange Massanutten blaze across the parking lot. The trail is mostly level with a steady moderate incline.  One you hit the Kennedy Peak / Stephen's Trail split, follow the white blaze on your right. This portion is a bit steeper. Great payoff at the peak.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.getting_there: Take US 675 from Luray.  Once you reach the top of the mountain  park in the lot on the left.
reviews:
7/10: Lost my beloved black Benchmade knife somewhere after the peak, heading counter clockwise. Would love to hear from anyone who finds it! (646) 820-8788

I’d recommend the out and back to the shelter at the peak, probably best in the winter for better view & fewer bugs. Didn’t think the whole loop  was really worth it. It’s all cover and lots of low, rocky ground. I did see two wild turkeys though! And it’s quiet- did not pass one other person the whole way through.
Only did a short bit as we just stopped to let our dog stretch her legs but we will be back. Very well maintained and picturesque trail. And exceptionally quiet. Easy trail
Xd
Awesome hike! Very rocky, but worth it! The view from the top is incredible!
Good moderate trail; well-marked. We started at 8 am on a Saturday and only met one other person. The second part of the trail was somewhat monotonous that’s why 4 starts.
The fog was beautiful and serene. Nice well traveled trail.

We really enjoyed this trail. The mountain laurel was in full bloom, birds were singing and beautiful scenery the whole walk. We walked counter clockwise hitting the fire tower in the beginning. This is definitely a moderate trail. We were glad we had our boots and not hiking sneakers. Took us a little over 4 hours.

nice trail, the fire tower was awesome, the views made it totally worth the walk. make sure you park where allowed and don’t block the access road (you will get ticked and towed) lot can hold about 6 cars.
Great weather - ridge line held a nice breeze.  The walk up to the fire watch was rocky.  Did about 5.2 up and back
Great 360 views at top... little to no foot traffic during the hike. Beautiful and quiet.

https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.name: Noland Loop Trail
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.overview: Noland Loop Trail is a 7.7 kilometer moderately trafficked loop trail located near Newport News, Virginia that features a lake and is good for all skill levels. The trail is primarily used for hiking, walking, running, and nature trips and is accessible year-round. Dogs are also able to use this trail but must be kept on leash.
https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/virgi.description: This semi-paved trail is very well-groomed with lots of twists, turns, and hills and beautiful views.
reviews: It was a nice trail, plenty of shade…..just hot right now
Well maintained and shady.

God developed and structured path. Clearly marked and suitable for hikers and runners; the trail heads is fairly easy to find with the map but can get mixed up in the various office sidewalks around the museum
Absolutely amazing spot to run and train your body

I wasn’t a fan of the amount of traffic and how urban parts felt, but all in all it was well maintained and there were many nice views of the water. Perfect hike for a hot day because of the trees but that’s all that it really brings to the table.
Great shady trail! Very nice views. Came out close to 6 miles at the end
Humid today, great trail, good traffic
Awesome day with nature
Easy to follow, lots of shade, perfect!
There were no bathroom facilities or Porta johns even though the trail map showed some.   when they open museum there will be one but for now, those of us with small bladders need to plan!  lol
